PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are addressing a meat industry package of amendments to 14 bills. These bills are intended to give the meat industry a greater role and responsibility in deciding its own affairs and to move it to a less regulated environment. The government asked the Industry Commission to undertake a study into the meat industry. It reported in July 1994, pointing out that Australia produces livestock at a very low cost by international standards but efficient processing is necessary if Australia is to take full advantage of our comparative advantage in livestock production.

PARA.TAB: The report said that the reason Australia remained world competitive was that processors were able to buy livestock at very low prices compared with processors in other countries. This was recently borne out when it was found that US beef could be landed in Australia at competitive prices after paying cattle producers 60 per cent more for their livestock than the money received by Australian farmers.

Of the 23 recommendations, three deal directly with industrial relations reforms; seven with the AMLC; seven with actions which the government should undertake in relation to market access and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service; one is a matter for local government; one concerns licensing; one is about R&D; one recommends the restructuring of the Policy Council—this legislation; and one suggests the Policy Council investigate the scope for the AMLC to fund individual projects by way of direct charges to beneficiaries and concomitant reductions in general levies. In relation to its recommendations on a restructured Policy Council, the IC said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission considers that the AMLIPC should be restructured, that its membership should more directly reflect the views of levy payers and major stakeholders such as employees, with government and quasi-public bodies currently represented, such as AQIS, AMLC and MRC as non voting members.

Restructured in such a way, the AMLIPC would be able to play a valuable role in setting major policy priorities for the industry on an ongoing basis. Recommendations made by the Commission on the scope for project financing in the AMLC and the possible introduction of multiple export inspection standards should be considered by the AMLIPC, as could issues such as the benefits of an industry-wide system for grading of Australian meat sold in domestic and international markets. A restructured AMLIPC could also be responsible for undertaking external evaluation of the effectiveness of AMLC and MRC programs.

The Meat and Livestock Industry Bill 1995 is the major bill in this package. It establishes a new Meat Industry Council to replace the AMLIPC and redefines the roles of the AMLC and the MRC. The MIC—that is, the new Meat Industry Council—will be responsible for developing strategic industry policy which will then provide the framework under which the AMLC and MRC will develop their corporate and operational plans.

PARA.TAB: The bill is transitional. It is to start on 1 July this year and will sunset on 30 June 1998. At that stage, it is intended that the three statutory industry authorities will revert to a non-statutory status. The government says that it will also enable the industry to identify its problems and devise commercial responses to them. In other words, the government expects it to implement the other recommendations of the Industry Commission because they are just too hard for the Labor government to implement. Under the government's industrial relations laws, this will not be possible.

The MIC is to establish guidelines for evaluations of the AMLC and the MRC programs and review their corporate plans prior to submission to the minister. The MIC will also be responsible for funding the AMLC and the MRC through the power to recommend levy rates to industry annual general meetings. This will ensure that programs of the AMLC and the MRC conform with the industry's strategic direction laid down by the new MIC.

The MIC will be accountable to the minister and parliament, and will have to produce a corporate plan and an annual report each year projecting three years ahead. The corporations will only be accountable to the MIC.

The MIC is to be a body corporate, as it will be holding money on its own account and will have the ability to employ staff and consultants. It must hold an annual conference and organise an annual general meeting of each statutory body during the conference. At conferences there will be the discussion of broad industry concerns but no motions of a general industry nature.

Let us look at the composition of the MIC. There are to be 18 members comprising a chairperson and government member. Both of these will be appointed by the minister, who will also appoint other members on the recommendations of the Cattle Council of Australia, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia, the Australian Meat Council, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Livestock Exporters' Association, the Australian Lot Feeders' Association, the Australian Supermarket Institute Limited and other members prescribed by regulation. Before the appointment of a chairman, the minister must consult the above bodies, and a person employed by any of these bodies is not eligible for appointment as a member.

Part 3 of the bill deals with the AMLC. The objects of the AMLC are to promote, control, protect and further the interests of the industry with reference to the export of meat and livestock from Australia and the sale and distribution of these after export. Also included are promotion, control and furthering the interests of the industry with respect to interstate trade and commerce in meat and livestock, the improvement of meat and livestock products and the encouragement of meat consumption in Australian territories. Its functions are to improve meat and livestock production domestically, promote domestically and internationally the consumption and sale of Australian meat and the sale of Australian livestock, encourage and control meat and livestock exports from Australia, recommend to the minister on regulations in relation to licences for the export of meat and livestock, and grant or refuse export licences.

The MIC takes over the AMLC's previous function relating to recommendations to the minister for levy and charge rates. However, the AMLC will be able to charge fees for services. It will also be able to market goods other than meat and livestock so that private equity can be introduced into CALM or Ausmeat and these services can be used for other species. It is intended that CALM will eventually be fully privatised, but its current restrictions make it less marketable. These types of plans must be explained in the AMLC's corporate plan, which requires ministerial approval and agreement of MIC.

The AMLC must conform to the broad policies of the MIC and must keep a register of levy and charge payers to determine eligibility to attend general meetings and conferences and voting rights. Powers to be removed from the AMLC are the funding of industry bodies for consultation purposes, ability to trade in meat and livestock, and ability to set conditions on the shipping of meat and livestock from Australia. The AMLC will consist of seven members and, with the exception of the managing director, all will be part time.

Generally speaking, the Australian meat processing sector is not internationally competitive in its operation due to high labour and capital costs compared with those of our major competitors. Despite the inefficiencies in our processing sector, the Australian meat industry has been able to remain price competitive. This has been achieved by paying Australian producers less for their livestock than their overseas counterparts receive. These facts are borne out by a report prepared for the Meat Research Corporation by Booze Allan and Hamilton in 1993. The Meat Research Corporation study also shows that productivity in Australian meatworks is abysmal compared with that of overseas.

The inefficiencies of the beef processing sector were again highlighted by the Industry Commission in its 1994 report, which recommended a major overhaul of work arrangements. Despite the findings of these two reports and numerous others over the years, the government has chosen to ignore them in responding to the Industry Commission report. Instead, it concentrated on a narrow group of recommendations about the industry's administrative structure, which although useful will do nothing to boost international competitiveness in the meat industry. The key IC recommendations in this regard were those to establish a minimum rates award, preferably nationally; the abolition of the tally system; and greater flexibility in working hours and hiring conditions for all plant to be used for longer periods. The proposed minimum rates award was to be used as the basis for enterprise bargaining but has still not been instituted, except in a very small number of works.

The Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has been running a major industrial campaign under which it has sought wage rises of at least four per cent before it will begin enterprise negotiations. Several companies have agreed. Recently, my colleague the shadow minister for primary industries, Mr John Anderson, made public the findings of a consultant's view of progress in work place reform in the export meat processing sector. It was conducted by Fellows Medlock and Associates for the Department of Industrial Relations.

That report was highly critical of progress to date. Among its conclusions were that enterprise bargains achieved to date have not been particularly innovative nor successful in encouraging improvements at the plant level. In many cases, they have been little more than a means to achieve a general wage rise. The industry's individual employers generally display a traditional and narrow approach to relations with their employees, and unions have failed to acknowledge change where it has occurred. Also, the union has adopted a narrow view of enterprise bargaining and has been reluctant to allow direct discussions between management and employees. Of course, all of these issues pose a number of questions that require further and detailed consideration.

I am certainly aware that there have been representations from wide groups, and at the committee stage I will ask the minister for clarification of the issues raised by the Australian Council of Livestock Agents, which has sought undertakings from Minister Collins with regard to observer status on the Meat Industry Council. I note in a letter to the minister that the Australian Council of Livestock Agents stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We understand that observer status will allow ACLA to attend all meetings, receive minutes and agendas, and participate in all discussions. We acknowledge however that we would not have voting rights. We would welcome confirmation of the above.

I understand that, as of yesterday, that council is still looking for a response to that. We also need to ask the question: when will the government acknowledge that its policy is failing so badly that it threatens not just Australia's export potential but also our capacity to import and replace, and, therefore, the prosperity and jobs of battlers as well as farmers?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of nine bills—
—Fourteen.

—I am sorry, 14 bills. I think that the size of the package is not an accurate reflection on the quality of the legislation. There has been a lot of window dressing and some adoption of the IC recommendations, but the real work remains to be done. The shadow minister for primary industries, John Anderson, has said that it is a totally inadequate response to the Industry Commission inquiry into the meat industry.

PARA.TAB: It was intended to give the industry a great self-determining role, and the key point is the establishment of a new Meat Industry Council. It is responsible for developing industry policy—as Senator Tambling has so eloquently said—overseeing the AMLC and the MIC and assessing its funding requirements. Interestingly, it is also supposed to identify industry problems and devise commercial responses to them. In other words, it is doing the government's job because the government cannot tackle issues such as labour reform within the meat industry.

Costs in Australia are absolutely astronomical compared with other countries. One of the costs associated with meat processing in Australia is about $170 a carcass. Compare that with the cost in New Zealand, who we compete with for the markets of Japan and Korea. Its cost for the carcass is about $70, so there is a heck of a difference between the two countries, and it puts us at a disadvantage.

Australia's record of cost efficiency in meat processing is basically appalling compared with some of the other countries. The Booz Allen study shows Australia to be way above the US and New Zealand and even higher than Argentina. Argentina, with the foot-and-mouth business getting under control a little now, will be competitive with us in the future, as will Uruguay. We have to compete against those countries, so we have to get a lot better. We cannot remain uncompetitive.

The overview of the IC report has made some different points about meat processing costs. One of them says that the results indicate that processing costs in Australia are higher than those in other countries with which Australia potentially competes. It is not only me that is saying this; it is the Industry Commission report that is also saying it. We have got to go somewhere along the lines of fixing that up so we can become more competitive.

The Meat Industry Council will also have to tackle questions of Australia's move to quality assurance inspection, and it will need to examine current and future methods of selling and marketing both domestically and for exports. For those two, we have to develop different techniques and different movements for the future as we move into the post-GATT trade environment under the World Trade Organisation.

There has been some criticism of the council. The first is the size and composition of the council itself—and I think that one could argue that 18 is rather large but, obviously, there are difficulties when determining who should be in and who should be out. With regard to the 18 members, including the peak commodity councils, there is some argument about whether the livestock agents ought to be included or not. I think that argument will continue for quite some time. There is a sunset clause to the legislation, so there will be a further opportunity to re-examine the composition in 1998.

The major criticism of the package is that it is simply inadequate. The meat industry has to become efficient in a hurry. The year 2000 is only 4 1/2 years away and we need to be ready to capitalise on new market opportunities. We will not be able to do that with the impediments we have at the moment.

The overview of the IC report says it all. The industry has significant scope for growth. For the rest of the decade it will enjoy progressively improving access to export markets as a result of the recent Uruguay Round of GATT. Access to the United States will improve markedly, although for some years the Australian industry will have difficulty in fully taking up the access negotiated.

The IC says that access to north Asian markets, such as Japan and the Republic of Korea, will also gradually be liberalised over the rest of the decade, allowing significant export growth. It also says that the major threats facing the industry relate to competition from other meat producing countries. Some of our competitors, such as New Zealand, are lifting productivity at a rapid rate, while others, such as a number of South American countries, will pose an even bigger competitive threat when they are granted foot-and-mouth disease-free status—which, as I have already mentioned, is something we will have to take into account. As a beef producer myself, and as somebody who has been in the industry for a long time, I think that if we do not get that right, we will jeopardise our balance of payments, which is absolutely abysmal at the moment, because we will not be able to maintain market share.

One thing that impacts on the industry as much as anything else is the performance of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. At the moment there is an inquiry into that. In the move towards quality assurance, we cannot afford to have any doubts about the efficacy of our premier inspection body. But there are widespread complaints in various rural industries about AQIS. Certainly, within the meat industry, complaints are rife.

Recently, at the inquiry in Sydney, the New South Wales Regional Abattoirs Association talked of the problems it has with meat inspection and how that should be cleaned up. I know that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, supports the inquiry. Hopefully, when the report is brought down these matters will be fixed up. If it comes down after the next election, it will be something that Mr Anderson, the member for Gwydir, will be able to fix up as the new minister for primary industry.

The IC report also said that we should do something about our selling methods. I am not saying that everyone should move to CALM but, obviously, a lot of the handling of stock on the way to the abattoirs is a bit antiquated and we might have to look at that if we are to become more cost effective and cost efficient.

We must make sure that our meat research dollar is spent in the most effective way. Recently, there has been criticism of grant allocations. Obviously, the debate surrounding that will go on for quite some time. One area that must be fixed up—not just by the window-dressing of changing some authorities and that sort of thing—is that of meat processing costs. If we do not do something about that we will not be competitive in the future.

The meat industry is a wonderful industry and it is up to us as legislators to do something more to bring about labour market reforms in an industry which produces great export income. Without labour market reform in the abattoirs and in the whole of the handling chain, it will not be cost competitive and the industry will suffer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to make some brief comments in relation to the Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill 1995 and associated bills. In this package there are some 11 different bills. I particularly wish to deal with the meat and livestock industry reforms, with particular emphasis on the cattle industry.

PARA.TAB: I do that against the background of three things. One is the Harrison report of some years ago. One is the Industry Commission report of more recent times. One is something that should have brought home a message to us all recently, and that is when we found that US beef could be brought into and sold in Australia at prices competitive with those of Australian producers.

That highlights the fact that there is something very dramatically wrong in Australia. We are a major exporter of beef, but when things became a little difficult during the drought we saw beef imported into this country from the United States even though plenty of beef was available in Western Australia. The simple reason is that the meat industry and the government have not had the courage to address the issues that were raised in the Harrison report or in the Industry Commission report.

The bottom line is very simple. I asked this question when I first came into the Senate in 1990: why does it cost $180 to kill and process a beast in Australia when it costs only approximately $85 to $90 in the United States and $50 in South American and other major exporting countries? That is the crux of the matter. We have to ensure that Australia's beef industry prospers and grows. Because Australia has not been prepared to address that particular aspect, our producers will continue to receive much lower prices than those received by our cousins in other countries.

Because this has occurred we have seen the development of the live cattle trade. Many cattle are being exported from the Kimberley in Western Australia, from the Northern Territory, and, more recently, from Queensland. Producers receive a better return by exporting live cattle to countries such as Indonesia where they are put in feedlots and processed. That is costing Australian jobs. It has created the situation in Australia where the industry is not expanding as it should be. The impact of value adding and marketing processed product overseas should be increasing our export dollars to offset the imports coming into the country. At the moment Australia is economically worse off.

This will be brought home to us at the end of this week when we will see, once again, a $2.5 billion current account deficit. One of the reasons this figure is continuing to grow is the inaction in the meat industry. It is being predicted that this month's current account deficit will be the worst in Australia's history. As has been well said, we are well down the path to the Mexican scenario in terms of our current account.

In recent times, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook, has been trying to blame the opposition for any possible increase in interest rates in the near future. That is one of the greatest furphies that has ever been tried on this parliament and on the people of Australia. The fact is that what happens to the current account will put pressure on interest rates. Until such time as we have the courage to address some of the problems I have highlighted with the meat industry—which is consistent with many other industries—we will continue to have a current account that stays at similar levels; thus we will continue to have close to the highest real interest rates in the world. The government has to wake up to that, otherwise the situation will continue.

We have the formation of yet another committee in the meat industry. Over the years I have been amazed at the number of committees and structures that have been set up in this industry to supposedly address the issues. I have no faith whatsoever that this Meat Industry Council will do any better than its predecessors. There is no reason to suspect or believe that it will do any better. It is just window dressing; walking away from the real issues which exist in the meat industry.

When one looks through the explanatory memorandum one finds such things as the continuation of the AGM in the industry. That is the greatest nonsense that has ever been thrust on the Australian meat industry—or any other sector of industry that goes through this particular process. It is absolutely impossible for producers to be involved other than on a very cursory and simple level if the AGM happens to be held in their particular town at a particular time. Western Australia is a significant producer of beef—though not as large a producer as Queensland. This measure totally isolates Western Australia from the decision making process. The process concerning the AGMs does not carry any real weight.

It is time that we looked at a proper and effective representative base for the production side of the industry. Until such time as we effectively address the reforms that are required in the slaughtering and processing of meat in this country we are going to find ourselves at a significant disadvantage when competing on the world market. We will continue to see increasing imports of beef. This should not occur because we should be able to compete favourably against other countries in price and quality. We will continue to see jobs in the meat industry being taken offshore to our northern neighbours. We will see more live cattle being exported and being slaughtered and processed elsewhere. We might even have the ridiculous case not too far down the track where we will find that meat which is being processed offshore is being imported back into Australia for the Australian consumer.

With those comments, the challenge is really for the government—or, after the next election, as Senator Brownhill said, for us—to address these key issues in the meat industry and allow it to thrive on its own merits, which it has the capacity to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank opposition speakers for their contributions. I do not agree with some of the points that have been made in the debate. However, the opposition is supporting the legislation and has facilitated its passage as non-controversial legislation.

PARA.TAB: I want to address and put on the record a number of matters. Senator Brownhill put the wrong emphasis on one aspect of this legislation, in asserting that the role of the MIC is to oversee the operations of the AMLC and the MRC. It is not the intention of the design of the legislation for the MIC to oversee both the AMLC and the MRC. The role is rather a strategic one, with the AMLC and the MRC having greater flexibility to manage and implement programs within the context of the industry strategic plan.

A couple of constant themes in the contributions from senators opposite were the issues of industrial relations and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. As mentioned, the Industry Commission inquiry into meat processing did deal with these matters to varying degrees. The point I want to make about these two issues, both industrial relations and the quarantine service, is that they are being pursued, but they are being pursued under separate processes and they are not the subject of specific reforms under this legislation. Nevertheless, this legislation addresses well over half of the recommendations made by the Industry Commission and, indirectly, other recommendations will be pursued under the new statutory arrangements.

The Meat Industry Council, established by this legislation, is an appropriate body to develop strategic policy and planning to address industry costs and competitiveness issues. Representatives of producers, processors and the union are on the council. The interim council has already identified industry cost as a priority issue and is in the process of finalising research to assist with its strategic assessment.

The government is fully aware that improved workplace relations can contribute to lifting the productivity and efficiency of the meat processing sector. Progress on enterprise agreements is being made, but from a low base. The recent report commissioned by the Department of Industrial Relations found that, in general, despite efforts by some employers and union officials, the work force was sceptical and distrustful of change. In the context of industrial relations, it needs to be understood that enterprise bargaining is not about imposing change from above on the work force and the employers; it is about a cultural shift by the work force itself together with its employer. Government's role is to set out a framework within which that cultural shift can occur.

The recent report to which I was referring found that the industrial relations climate has improved and that the number of enterprise agreements is increasing. But the quality of the agreements does vary. Some areas of Australia—for example, Victoria—have had more experience in this type of negotiation than other areas in Australia. The steady increase in federal agreements shows the viability of the government's framework for conducting and supporting enterprise bargaining.

As I said earlier, it is the commitment of the parties to enterprise bargaining that is important, not government imposing from above change on the parties, particularly in an industry which has had deep traditions of scepticism—and that would be putting it mildly in terms of the attitudes of the parties in this industry—in the area of industrial relations.

The reform of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service over the past two years has been very significant, certainly since I have been parliamentary secretary to, firstly, Mr Simon Crean and now Senator Bob Collins. I do not want to spend a lot of time on this issue in the debate today, but I think it was Senator Brownhill who acknowledged that he is involved in a further review of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. We remain firmly committed to the ongoing reform of the quarantine service. There have been major changes, such as the downsizing of the work force by some 500. There have been significant changes and, in many areas, reductions in the charges made by AQIS.

The inquiry that is currently being undertaken by the Senate was agreed to by the government. The further restructuring of AQIS is under way, and that is in response to Industry Commission recommendations. AQIS is responding constructively to the concerns outlined in the Industry Commission report. At the same time we have to understand that we need to retain the integrity of its export certification and quarantine programs. It is appropriate to await the deliberations of the Senate committee of inquiry in this area.
There are two other matters. I noticed in a media release of the opposition spokesperson, John Anderson, what I think was certainly not just uncharitable but grossly unfair criticism of my—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not right. John Anderson would never do that.
—Just wait till I read out the particular paragraph in the press release. Mr Anderson, in the last paragraph of his press release of 8 June, said:

SPEECH.PARA: To add insult to injury, the Government took 14 months to come up with this package and then presented it in the second chamber,—
and I do not know how my colleagues in the Senate feel about being referred to as the `second chamber'—
not the main parliamentary chamber, during a week when the Minister responsible wasn't even in the country.

That is a bit uncharitable when we all know that Senator Bob Collins, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, flew to the US and back over seven days. Senator Boswell looks a little embarrassed at the criticism by Mr Anderson—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the least.
—We all know that Senator Collins was over in the United States working his guts out to try to convince the Americans—
—That is a big job!

—I had better be careful here; I am supposed to be defending the minister. We all know that he was in the United States lobbying very hard, as have a number of us, both opposition and government, who have been involved in an attempt to rectify some of the wrongful subsidies that the US has in the agricultural commodity area. That is why the minister was overseas. Indeed I am sure the opposition would welcome the fact that the second chamber, the Senate—
—That was not the second chamber.

—I agree with you, Senator Boswell. Go and tell Mr Anderson that. I want it on the record that that is where Senator Collins was, and I think it is an unfair criticism of my minister to put out a press release like that. There has been some reference to the composition of the Meat Industry Council. At 18 persons, the new Meat Industry Council is large but it represents the balance of membership that has been agreed to in negotiations with the major levy-paying organisations of the industry. I think it is important to note that.

PARA.TAB: Interim meetings of the council have been positive, productive and manageable. Needless to say, there are other organisations—and Senator Tambling referred to the Australian Council of Livestock Agents—which believe they should be represented on the council or should at the very least have observer status. Inclusion of other organisations as full members or observers on a regular basis is not supported by the peak industry councils or the government as it would undermine the necessary ownership this body will need to have if it is to achieve the significant leadership role proposed, as well as making the council unwieldy and unmanageable. I am sure we all have experience of organisations with 18 people. Once an organisation gets over that number it becomes very unwieldy and difficult to hold reasonably detailed discussions in a manageable way.

The peak councils also believe that it is inappropriate for service organisations such as the ACLA—and the livestock organisation is not a levy organisation—to be on the council, but there may be occasions when input from organisations such as the ACLA may be needed in developing specific industry policy where such service organisations have some involvement or expertise. Such bodies may then be asked by the council to participate on an informal basis in committees or in other working arrangements.

Section 29 of the legislation, which specifies the composition of the council—which has been agreed to by the major levy paying organisations—provides, subject to subsection 22(6)(ii) and on a recommendation of the Meat Industry Council, for other members to be prescribed by regulation. Also under subsection 36(10) of the legislation, the council may regulate proceedings at its meetings as it considers appropriate. Therefore, if the council wishes to decide on the provision of observer status, this matter should be taken up by the livestock organisation and it should approach the chair of the Meat Industry Council to seek observer status where it is appropriate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of related questions I would like to pursue with the minister. In his summing up comments a few moments ago, the minister referred to the report that had been prepared for the Department of Industrial Relations by Fellows Medlock and Associates. I understand that this was an independent review of progress into workplace reform in the meat processing sector. Would the minister acknowledge that that report established that those few enterprise bargains that have been achieved to date, in the context of the report, lack `innovation', fail to `encourage significant improvement at the plant level' and `generally have been little more than a means to achieve a general wage increase'? I ask the minister: what action is being proposed to redress these issues and how will the government ensure that its own policy will not threaten export potential but does complement the objectives that we are seeking?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I covered this matter in my concluding remarks on the legislation. I emphasise that the progress in this industry at an enterprise level has been very mixed. It has not occurred as rapidly as some parties and some employers would like to have seen. Set against the context of our general industrial relations reforms, which have put much greater emphasis on enterprise bargaining, as I said earlier, it is not for government—other than to set the regulatory framework for enterprise bargaining in the context of industrial relations, which we have done—to get together the employees, the union and the employers and sit them around a table and bang their heads together and say, `Look, get on with it'.

PARA.TAB: We are all aware of the cultural difficulties in this industry. It has been an industry where traditionally there has been a great deal of suspicion in industrial relations on both sides and a great deal of tough approach to industrial reform by both sectors. We would like to have seen more occur but we believe the government's policies in the industrial relations area will mean that as time goes on in the various discussions in industrial relations in this industry, we will see a greater pace of change and a greater adoption of meaningful outcomes under the enterprise agreement provisions of the Industrial Relations Act.
Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill amends the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Act 1991. The principal act ensures that the total of the annual telecommunications carrier licence fees must not exceed the total cost of running the industry regulator, Austel, in the previous financial year. This amendment changes the upper fee limit. It will allow the government to also recover the cost of Australia's contribution to the International Telecommunications Union. It is the implication of this that I want to particularly dwell on today.

PARA.TAB: The government's policy has been to make Australian carriers fund the cost of the regulator, Austel. In 1994-95 Telstra, Optus and Vodaphone paid $12.6 million in carrier licence fees to cover the costs of running Austel. The coalition supports making the carriers pay for the regulator while maintaining a ceiling that prevents carrier licence fees producing a surplus that could be transferred to general revenue.

The International Telecommunications Union also has fees which have to be covered. This body is a United Nations body and its role is to prescribe world telecommunications standards and radio communications planning. So it is appropriate that the government pay fees to this body and it is also appropriate that the government recover those fees from the industry.

Prior to 1991, Telecom, OTC and Aussat paid the government's ITU contribution. Now the carriers make their own separate ITU contributions and the government pays a contribution. This was $4.86 million in 1993-94. This amendment raises the ceiling on the money paid by the carriers in licence fees to recover the costs of government in the contribution to the ITU.

The financial impact of this bill will be favourable because, the government's payments to ITU having been transferred back to the industry, the general burden on the taxpayer will be reduced. So the coalition favours these arrangements. We do not oppose the bill but there are a number of implications about what is happening in relation to fees and charges in the international area that should be brought to the Senate's attention because the legislation is going to impact on the costs of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The government believes that the likely level of ITU fees in the future is going to increase. The extent of this is unpredictable because it depends on the activities of the ITU. This is difficult to gauge into the future because the very rapid evolution of the telecommunications revolution means that such an international body will play a larger and larger role in international telecommunications. This means there will probably be an increase in fees in the future.

PARA.TAB: Another thing that would actually increase the cost to the carriers and, ultimately, the consumers is the fact that these fees are paid in Swiss francs. Changing exchange rates can put up the costs quite significantly as they have done when things have been paid in Swiss francs in the past, given the strength of that currency relative to the weakness of the Australian currency. All this places the industry under an increased cost burden. The size of the carriers' contributions will be determined from time to time by regulation. I believe that this needs to be watched closely by the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has a number of concerns relating to the way in which the government has arrived at its position on this bill. It is disturbing that none of the carriers appears to have been consulted about the bill. The coalition did consult with all the carriers. Given what I have said so far, the Senate would not be surprised to learn that the carriers are less than enthusiastic about covering the payments that were formerly made by the government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean to tell me that the government didn't even ask?

—It seems that way, Senator Boswell. It seems that the government has determined, without so much as a by-your-leave, that the carriers should cover this international charge. The coalition does not disagree with the principle of the carriers covering it, but one would have thought it to be courtesy to consult and discuss with the carriers the implications of this bill, particularly as it affects the bottom line of all the carriers.

PARA.TAB: There is also no provision for a reduction in the fees the carriers pay to the government in the light of the fact that they are now covering the cost to the ITU. It should be noted that a carrier like Telstra, because of its size, will carry the bulk of offsetting these increased licence fees and will be cutting its present ITU contribution accordingly. But the bottom line is that its overall cost level will go up.

Australia's contribution to the operation of the ITU is quite high, relative to the size of our economy. We support in principle the carriers paying telecommunications licence fees to recover public interest regulatory costs incurred by Austel. We also recognise the need to pay our way internationally. Nevertheless, the impact of the increase in licence fees to take account of the international contributions that are needed should be assessed carefully. The coalition supports this bill before the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will very briefly respond. I thank the opposition for its support of this legislation. The bill is non-controversial and the opposition has dealt with it in the context of the difficult time constraints we have.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the official notification and consultation of the carriers, the proposal to attribute and recover the telecommunications standardisation component of Australia's ITU contribution was developed in the budget context. In that context, the department considered that confidentiality should be maintained until after the budget announcement. However, the report of the evaluation of Australia's ITU involvement, which has now been widely distributed, includes reference to attributing cost recovery of the contribution.

In developing and representing Australia's position at the ITU plenipotentiary conferences, the department consults closely with telecommunications carriers and encourages carrier representatives to join the Australian delegation, as does Austel in carrying out its lead role in the ITU's telecommunications standardisation sector. Further, the department is writing to the telecommunications carriers to fully explain the attribution and cost recovery of ITU expenses. As has been mentioned in the debate, the result of this legislation will be a reduction of approximately $1 million in costs and return to industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1995PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 June, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1995 and the Passenger Movement Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1995 represent the second stage of the government's reforms to the departure tax system. In the 1994-95 budget, the government announced that it would replace the departure tax with a passenger movement charge, which is a $27 tax on international passenger movement. The new charge is linked to the cost of providing customs, immigration, quarantine and short-term visitor visa processing services. It is a form of hypothecation without hypothecation.

PARA.TAB: The government announced that the charge will be collected through the airlines rather than the cumbersome departure tax booths that have long been an irritation to international travellers and a bit of an eyesore at the airports. The government implemented the new system in the Departure Tax Amendment Act 1994 and the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Act 1994. It did not, however, update the exemptions to the tax that were available.

The old system defined 24 categories of international passengers who were exempt from the charge. The categories were awkwardly split between the act and the regulations. These bills will replace those 24 categories with 12 broadly defined categories to facilitate the collection of the charge by the airlines and to clarify the operation of the new system. The new categories will take effect from 1 July 1995.

The bills will also implement a range of transitional amendments. For instance, a passenger who already holds an exemption stamp issued under the old system for a departure after July 1995 will not be reassessed under the new arrangements. The bills will eliminate a number of exemption categories that were available under the old system. For example, members of the ADF travelling on official duty will no longer be exempt from the charge. The charge will instead have to be met by the Department of Defence. The elimination of exemption categories like this one reflect the transformation of the departure tax from a general revenue measure to a charge for service. The bills also tighten the exemption category relating to transit passengers. I believe that this is expected to raise an extra $1.5 million in 1995-96.

The coalition does not oppose the bills, but I ask the minister on duty: at the time of the debate on the previous bills which have been enacted it was stated that some negotiations were going on between the airlines and the government in respect of paying the airlines for collecting the tax; has a figure been agreed upon and, if so, how much?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only point I wish to respond to is the last point that Senator Parer raised. There is agreement in principle with the airlines for the government to pay establishment and running costs. The detailed proposal from the airlines has not been received yet. Once it is received, negotiations will be concluded on what those final costs will be.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 is an important piece of legislation and one which is supported by the coalition. Basically, this bill seeks to add to the schedule and therefore confirm the basic tenets of an agreement which was reached between the Central Land Council, the traditional owners of the area covered by the Western Desert (South) Repeat Land Claim and the Northern Territory government. I think the important part of this legislation is that it puts into law what honourable senators on all sides of this chamber would recognise as a healthy and productive process, where issues can be concluded by agreement with a large dose of commonsense and certainly without having to go through the tedious and lengthy processes set down under the Native Title Act—processes which can take years and years for Aboriginal applicants, mining companies or any other persons wanting to use land to go through the very complicated and complex processes tied up in the Native Title Act.

PARA.TAB: We are all aware in this chamber that the processes under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act are very lengthy. Firstly, hearings are conducted by the commissioner, then there is an investigation of the claims, and then determinations are made and reported to the minister and the Northern Territory government. Then the minister would recommend to the Governor-General whether or not the land in question should be granted to an Aboriginal land trust.

In the case of the Western Deserts (South) Repeat Land Claim, which is the subject of this amending bill, an agreement was reached relating to some parcels of land not granted in the original claim. After a series of consultations and agreements reached between the parties, the land has been granted. If my understanding of the bill is correct, I think this fundamentally puts that into the schedule. The coalition congratulates those associated with this successful claim—particularly the central land council—those traditional owners of the area covered and the Northern Territory government for creating what was a constructive and positive outcome.

In view of the time that we want to devote to this, I will use the opportunity to briefly raise another matter that is associated with this bill; that is, the actions of ATSIC and the Indigenous Land Council which have had an enormous impact on the Northern Territory. I refer to the decisions taken by the Indigenous Land Corporation and ATSIC over the past few weeks. I reiterate to the Senate and remind the Senate that those decisions had two effects. ATSIC made a decision in March ensuring that $20 million of a total of $24 million available for land acquisition under ATSIC's land acquisition and management program would be dedicated to purchasing properties in the Northern Territory for conversion to land rights inalienable freehold title under the act that this bill before us seeks to amend.

This upset a lot of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people around Australia because it ensured that there would be a massive distortion of funding, under the land acquisition and management program of ATSIC, towards Northern Territory properties capable of being converted to inalienable freehold title. I said in a previous debate in this chamber—I think it was in the debate when we censured the minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for their misleading of the Senate about the ILC legislation—that not only would this ensure that those people in the southern parts of Australia, and even Western Australia, would be disadvantaged because of that decision, but that they would be disadvantaged for generations to come.

While welcoming very much the constructive process that the Central Land Council, the Northern Territory government and the traditional landowners in the Northern Territory have achieved under this bill, you should contrast it with the cynical decision taken by ATSIC and, subsequently, with another decision taken by the ILC just a fortnight or so ago relating to funding for Aboriginal land purchases. While we are very happy—as I am sure many Aboriginals around Australia will be—for the traditional owners who will be the beneficiaries of upholding the Western Desert (South) land area in inalienable freehold title, we must think of those Aboriginal people in other parts of Australia who, because of the ATSIC decision to spend $20 million out of $24 million in the next two years solely in the Northern Territory, feel that they have been dispossessed, many of whom will have that dispossession entrenched because of a decision by ATSIC.

We cannot entirely blame ATSIC because, as documents tabled in this place—documents that are the subject of a return to order moved by Senator Chamarette—would show, that the government indeed set out to create a legislative scheme when it created the land fund to ensure that this would happen. Our investigations into the Prime Minister's involvement in what can only be described as a grubby deal relating to the provision of funds for Aboriginal land purchases around Australia will show that this Prime Minister—if not the minister for Aboriginal affairs, but I do not suspect that he was part of that deal; I think it was Prime Minister—effectively ensured that all Aboriginals outside the Northern Territory, and I include in that some Aboriginals in the Northern Territory who do not live on traditional lands, will fundamentally have their dispossession, or their access to land at least, further entrenched because of the actions of the Prime Minister.

Mr Acting Deputy President, we should recall the fine words and the rhetoric of the Prime Minister during the debate on the native title legislation, and his pronouncements in relation to the land fund. I remind the Senate that at the time of the debate on the so-called Mabo legislation the Prime Minister said that only about five per cent of Aboriginal people would benefit from native title claims. That is not disputed by the coalition or by any experts in that field. But, while that legislation is coming up to its second anniversary, the record to date shows that not one Aboriginal on the mainland has had native title granted yet. Of course, there is a number of claims before the tribunal that may be successful in the longer run.

The Prime Minister went on to say that there was a need for a land fund to ensure that the 95 per cent of Aboriginals who could not achieve a successful claim under the native title legislation should have access to moneys under the land fund so that they could gain access to and benefit from the ownership of land. Through the legislative structure that the Prime Minister had a very close hand in establishing, we now find that the 95 per cent of Aboriginals who do not benefit from native title claims are unlikely to derive any benefit for many years to come because the land fund has been established to ensure that the majority of land acquisition funds available to Aboriginal people for at least the next two years will go to the Northern Territory. So those many Aboriginal people in New South Wales, and, Mr Acting Deputy President, in your home state of Tasmania—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We give a fair degree of latitude and allow a certain amount of goodwill in a debate but, while for the first two or three minutes of Senator Campbell's contribution he dealt with the bill before the chair, he is now ranging far and wide over general policy and that is not appropriate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: it has always been the situation in the Senate that a fair amount of latitude is allowed in debate. I think Senator Campbell is being very relevant. He is presenting to the Senate the problems that have been caused by a particular decision taken by the government that refers to the Northern Territory. I would say that he is being most relevant in his remarks and I ask you to allow him to continue.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to Senator Sherry because I have been choosing my words very carefully. We are dealing with a bill to amend the Northern Territory land rights act. The hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory and in all other parts of Australia are fundamentally affected not only by the Northern Territory land rights act but also by ATSIC's decision in recent weeks to ensure that $20 million out of $24 million was spent in the Northern Territory and by the ILC's decision to ensure that no money over the next two years is spent in the Northern Territory. Those decisions go right to the heart of the matters involved in any debate on the Northern Territory land rights legislation and that is exactly what we are debating here today.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not want to detain the Senate too much longer. I was in the middle of saying that Aboriginals in your home state of Tasmania, in Queensland, which Senator Boswell represents, in Western Australia, my own state, and in New South Wales, where Senator Woods represents tens of thousands of Aboriginal people, miss out because of the actions of the Prime Minister.

I will keep saying it from now until kingdom cone: long after this Prime Minister has gone. When the Prime Minister goes on radio and tells people what is so great about his government he says, `We are not economic rationalists. It is not just that. We are a government with a heart. We want to get rid of the flag. We want to get rid of the constitution. We have this Mabo thing'. I suspect that deep down—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to a point of order. What on earth does the untrue allegation that we want to get rid of the flag and the republic have to do with the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995?

—What I am arguing in this second reading debate—which needs to be broad ranging—is that the Prime Minister has told Aboriginal people that a big part of his government's social agenda is to deliver justice to them. I am explaining that, as with the range of his other policies, that justice is illusory.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Perhaps, Senator Campbell, you might bring yourself more directly to the issues before the parliament, given the time constraints that are relevant at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. The point that I make in relation to Aboriginal people, who are the subject of this bill, is that the promise that the Prime Minister makes is illusory. He established with the land fund legislation, which has an important link to this Northern Territory land rights legislation that we are today seeking to amend, that Aboriginals will get more justice. The Prime Minister's legislative package that has gone through the chamber this year under the land fund bill was created with the Prime Minister's own personal involvement to ensure that many Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory would miss out. As I have said—and I will not say it again after this—Aboriginal people from Queensland, New South Wales, Tasmania, South Australia, Victoria and Western Australia who have suffered a lack of access to land for their economic, cultural and religious enjoyment will miss out because of the actions of this Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: I say to those people in the gallery, to those people who listen to this program on the ABC broadcast network, and to those who read this Hansard in years to come, that when we see the Prime Minister standing up and talking about justice for Aboriginals, what he is really talking about is justice for a small group of Aboriginal people who have the Prime Minister's ear. For those hundreds of thousands of other Aboriginals who do not have the negotiating power and are not able to access the Prime Minister that justice is illusory. When people look back at this period in Aboriginal affairs they will understand that the Prime Minister's rhetoric—which is very fine—is not matched with a delivery of justice for Aboriginal people, particularly when it comes to land.

With those words, the coalition quite genuinely commends the Central Land Council, the traditional owners of the Western Desert (South) Repeat Land Claim area, and the Northern Territory government for the process that was successfully concluded to ensure that the traditional owners will have ownership of this portion of land. We welcome and support the passage of this amending bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I thank the opposition for its support for this legislation. I do not thank Senator Campbell—
—You are being precious.

—The first couple of minutes of Senator Campbell's contribution effectively dealt with this legislation, but I am not going to sit here and accept, without some response in concluding the debate, by far the largest part of Senator Campbell's 10-minute contribution. I do not accept it because: firstly, it was irrelevant to the legislation—and I respect the chair's ruling on that matter; and secondly, the stream of allegations, which were repetitive in nature—he repeated them at least two or three times, and he has said them on previous occasions—are not correct. As far as this government is concerned we do not accept Senator Campbell's assertions.

PARA.TAB: I conclude the debate by saying that the opposition's stance is regrettable. I point out, as Senator Campbell was keen to point out to the gallery and the public listening on the ABC broadcast, that, unfortunately, this continuous repetition in debates of this nature is an example of the way in which time is wasted in this chamber and the reason why today we have to deal with legislation in the way we are dealing with it. For the first six days of sitting this month, the Senate dealt with legislation for only three minutes. That was absolutely appalling. On those remarks, I conclude.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: although the minister has concluded his remarks, he was talking about something that was totally irrelevant to the second reading debate on this bill.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! The minister has concluded. There is no point of order.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.57 to 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Yesterday you said that the measures taken over the past week, including the recall of the Australian Ambassador to France, in protest against the resumption of nuclear testing in the South Pacific `amount to the most significant I can recall of any country imposing against any other country with which it has friendly relations, in a peacetime environment'. Why then—according to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade internal publication DFAT News, dated as at 15 May, under the heading `Senior officer movements'—was the Australian Ambassador to France already scheduled to return to Australia on 18 June, prior to the 23 June cabinet announcement to recall him? Could this, perchance, be a Clayton's recall, or could this be a recall made on the basis that a genuine recall might have adversely affected your chances of becoming Secretary-General of the United Nations?

—There is no foundation whatsoever for that imputation. What matters in these particular essentially symbolic gestures, as the recall of an ambassador is, is the way in which the movement in question is characterised. If you describe it as an ambassador being recalled for consultations, it has exactly that status and that impact, whatever the truth of the matter may have been.

PARA.TAB: The ambassador's leave that he was planning to take in Australia had, in fact, been cancelled as a result of the development of the situation on the ground. He was expected to be back in Australia at the time that the South Pacific Forum mission was set in train. He had been expected to be back in Australia before then, a day or two earlier. He was asked to put all that on hold, to in fact cancel it, and to wait for further instructions.

The instruction could have been to stay on there in France as a channel for communication; the instruction could have been to proceed with leave, as he had originally planned; or his instruction could have been to come out on the basis that he was being recalled for consultations, with the situation being formally so described and communicated to the French. That is a well understood course of events that I have described. What matters, I repeat, is the way in which these things are characterised. The meaning is, if you like, in the message.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask, in terms of this symbolic recall, which it now is: was the French government aware that the ambassador who was going to be recalled to Australia was already coming back to Australia? Was there a nod and a wink to the French government to say, `Look, we'll pretend to recall him, but actually he is already going back. So you don't need to get upset and, in fact, you can still vote for me at the UN'? Why weren't you open and honest about this to the people of Australia? Why didn't you tell them that this Australian ambassador was already coming back here and the whole thing was a very empty gesture?
—You are trying to white-ant the significance.

—Exactly—that is a very fair point, Senator Collins. The matter in issue is the Australian government communicating to the French government a new set of measures which are demonstrably stronger in their range and their extent and the message they communicate than the original stage of the response was. That is the message we are trying to communicate, and you are doing nothing other than undermining that.

PARA.TAB: The French, I am sure, had no difficulty, and have no difficulty, in understanding the nature of what is involved here in a recall exercise. I think they probably were originally aware—I would have to check that—that some leave was involved, because there is a normal provision for notification of who is going to be the charge in that sort of situation. I am sure it came absolutely as no surprise that we chose to go down this particular path and to characterise the recall in these terms. If you do not understand that, you are just demonstrating, once again, the total ignorance that exists on that side of the chamber about the nature of these particular diplomatic exchanges and the character and the significance of the messages that are involved when you send them. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Recently there has been a great deal of public comment about Australia's plans and objectives for APEC and the position of the United States and Japan. Could the Minister for Trade clarify the state of play in APEC on implementation of a commitment by APEC leaders in Bogor last year to achieve free and open trade and investment in the region? In doing so, could the minister advise of the strategic approach Australia is taking on this matter and the position of other key APEC members?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to correct the record in this matter. I think we can say, to slightly paraphrase what has been said in the past, that never in the course of Australian trade policy has so much been got wrong by so few about so much. We have had some very seriously misleading and untruthful remarks made about Australia's position in this matter, and I would like to take this opportunity to correct the record and, hopefully, then go on and deal with the more constructive aspects of Senator Evans's question.

PARA.TAB: Recently, in the last week or eight days, there have been two important, diametrically wrong, fundamentally flawed comments made that seriously undermine our capacity effectively to present our position about APEC. One statement was:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has been trying to persuade the east Asians to support the more discriminatory preferred model of the Americans.
That is absolutely wrong. The second statement was:
Why is Australia doing the dirty work for the United States?
That is absolutely wrong. Who made those two comments? The first was made by Alexander Downer and the second was made by Tim Fischer.

PARA.TAB: I do not suppose we should be surprised they have got it wrong, but they have got it absolutely wrong. It is a misunderstanding amounting to deliberate misinformation. I suspect it is misunderstanding, but it does not seem too much to ask for the opposition to get its facts right before it starts to make assertions, which are read in the region, about what Australia's position is. Just as Senator Gareth Evans is concerned that they are undermining our position on other matters, they are doing so here, although in this instance at least it is not deliberate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everything that goes wrong is the fault of the opposition.

—It is just incompetence, that is all. It is not deliberate on this occasion. The opposition has been trying to differentiate itself from the government on APEC by pretending that Australia is changing its fundamental position about MFN and trying in some way to undermine the non-discriminatory principles. I will come to that in a moment. It would be helpful if they were not at the same time running around Australia telling industries about all the protection they might get, while trying to say overseas what free traders they are.

PARA.TAB: Let me make it very clear. The action agenda which Australia has outlined and put forward on every occasion is fully consistent with an MFN non-discriminatory approach. Certainly Australia's exporters have no difficulty in understanding our position and endorsing it. They do not want Australia to close off its options, although they support our strong preference for the MFN alternative.

The confusion is causing some difficulty in our region, so I set out this morning to try in a speech to the Institute of International Affairs to clarify our position. I hope, at least for the interested and objective observers, it will do so, even if not for Mr Downer and Mr Fischer. But it will at least demonstrate how wrong they are.

Let me make it clear. Our distinct preference is for an MFN approach. Every proposal we have put forward has been consistent with MFN. All we have said is that, at the end of the day, if our preferred position is not acceptable—because, after all, we do not own APEC; we are only trying to influence it—if an alternative proposition comes forward that advances Australia's interests and the regional interest, we will not rule it out. There is no proposal for a preferential trade agreement in APEC on the table. It has not even been discussed. Nobody has raised such a proposal with me or with any other Australian representative.

MFN is important. We support it. We hope that is the outcome. But it does not mean that we have to include it in every statement that is made about APEC as if it is some sort of phrase like `open sesame' or a religious mantra. The issue of APEC will be advanced if people stop deliberately misinforming. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to your claim yesterday that a UN resolution on French nuclear testing would most likely not succeed, thereby demonstrating Australia's weakness in the international community. Is it a fact that in 1972 the United Nations General Assembly passed by 80 votes to four, with 29 abstentions, a draft resolution—
—Have you ever demonstrated against the bomb?

—Listen, clown; you might learn something—co-sponsored by the coalition government calling for a halt to the atmospheric testing of nuclear weapons in the Pacific or anywhere else in the world? Is it a fact that this draft resolution ultimately lead to the cessation of atmospheric testing by France in 1974 after further pressure from Australia and New Zealand by way of proceedings in the International Court of Justice? Is it also a fact that during the 1980s Australia repeatedly co-sponsored successful UN resolutions supporting a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, despite not having the support of the United States, the Soviet Union and France? Minister, on two occasions you have refused to rule out your candidacy for the position of UN Secretary-General. Will you now do so and, if not, will you tell us why you have gone soft on nuclear issues? (Time expired)

—There is no foundation for those aspersions, Mr President, but let me respond to the substantive question. Resolutions have been successful in the past so far as nuclear tests are concerned. The 1973 resolution, I think it is, to which Senator Alston is referring, involved a plenary UN General Assembly vote—65 affirmative, seven opposed and 57 abstentions. It was passed, but with a very significant body of abstentions and with a very significant number of countries not actually participating in the vote. By UN standards, the way in which these resolutions are measured in terms of their success, that was regarded as an extremely poor result and one that hardly reflected the sense of passion on the subject of atmospheric testing, which was the case at the time, that was certainly felt in those countries like us that were sponsoring and supporting the resolution.

PARA.TAB: The concern, among others, about a resolution in similar terms being moved now is that on the negative side it may well produce, if it did pass, a similar pattern of a high rate of abstentions and a very high rate of non-participation, which would be at spectacular odds with the almost unanimity with which in recent years resolutions in favour of a comprehensive test ban and so on have been passed. That is just a matter for concern and something that does have to be taken into account.

Another question that has to be taken into account is that the kind of language that would probably be necessary in order to command a majority vote would need to be so soft and so moderate that it would unsatisfactorily represent and unsatisfactorily convey to the international community the nature of the concerns that we really do feel about it.

I have just been making the point that these are matters to be taken into account before you blindly embrace that kind of option. Yesterday, very deliberately, I did not rule out the option of a General Assembly resolution or the pursuit of a resolution in any one of a number of other multilateral contexts. In that particular context we are obviously exploring what the art of the possible might be. That will continue to be the case in the period ahead. There is plenty of time in which to contemplate that because the General Assembly does not start until mid-September, the first committee does not start meeting until a week or two after that, and there is an opportunity to well and truly focus on what the options might realistically be. But there is no point in carrying on in this particular fashion and just identifying avenues for possible action unless you are sure that in their impact they will in fact be productive, that they will be effective in conveying the message you want to convey and will not be counter-productive to our larger policy objectives in order to achieve a comprehensive test ban treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I take a point of order, Mr President? There were two distinct parts to this question. The first was about the UN, on which Senator Evans has now spent 3 1/2 minutes, but I would not like him to miss the opportunity to definitively rule himself out for the UN job. Will you or won't you do that and, if not, tell us why you have gone soft?
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I have completed my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The minister will be aware that under the recently announced Accord Mark VIII the federal government and the ACTU have set a job creation target of 600,000 jobs over the life of the Accord. I note that this objective has been applauded by Bert Evans, the Chief Executive of the Metal Trades Industry Association. However, some others have claimed that this target is unattainable. Can the government assure the Senate that the new jobs target is a realistic objective?

—The question asked by Senator Forshaw does highlight the achievement of the government in reaching agreement on Accord Mark VIII. As Senator Forshaw said in his remarks, Mr Bert Evans from the MTIA has made a number of complimentary remarks about the outcome of the Accord. In an interview with the Australian Financial Review today Mr Evans claimed credit that the MTIA was involved behind the scenes in discussions and some of the Accord outcomes. That probably explains why the headline in the Australian Financial Review is `MTIA breaks ranks on Accord'—that is, it supports the Accord, unlike some other industry organisations. I think it reflects the maturity of sensible people in the business community that the Accord delivers a very good outcome for industry and the economy in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The parties have agreed to ensure the creation of a minimum of 600,000 additional jobs over the life of the Accord for the next 3 1/2 years. As the Accord states, this is essential to the achievement of a five per cent unemployment rate by the year 2000-01. To achieve this, the union movement has agreed to assist in the implementation of strategies in Working Nation. For our part, the government will encourage individual unions to seek accreditation so that they can carry out case management for job seekers. We will encourage them to participate directly in labour market programs at both the community and national levels.

But, most importantly, the parties to the Accord have agreed that the five per cent unemployment target is so fundamental to the social and economic well-being of Australia that wage claims will be assessed against satisfactory progress towards this target. This is the crucial element of the agreement. The MTIA, as Senator Forshaw has commented, knows that it has had a constructive input to the development of the Accord.

Who is now claiming that these targets are not achievable and that we will not deliver 600,000 new jobs? It is members of the opposition. We promised at the last election that we would deliver half a million jobs in our next term of government. We have already well exceeded that. Mr Howard was one of those who made carping criticisms that this was unachievable. When we achieved it there was no comment and no mention of it from the opposition.

The Accord is an outstanding achievement. We make no apologies for the fact that it is central to our success in government in achieving stability in the economy and being able to achieve above all else a low inflation outcome for Australia—an inflation outcome to which the trade union movement is committed. I remind those opposite that when they were last in government there was never such an outcome of low inflation. When they were last in government they achieved the trifecta—high interest rates, high unemployment and high inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was 13 years ago.

—Of course it was many years ago, but the problem is, Senator Brownhill, that you have not advanced any policies since 1983 to show that you would do anything different from what you did then. Let us see your policies to show that you will achieve low inflation and good job growth because since 1983 you have not put up any new policies to show that it would be any different from the last time you were in office. That is why the Accord is one of the centrepieces of this government's economic achievements and it is why you hate it so much.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the present status of the Australian-Indonesian agreement for the supply of uranium and/or nuclear technology to Indonesia? Is Indonesia still planning to build nuclear reactors in one of the most seismically active areas in the world—reactors that may be fuelled with Australian uranium? Has the minister's department made an assessment of the relative risks to Australia of a nuclear accident during the proposed French nuclear tests and an accident involving a Chernobyl-type breach of a nuclear power station following a major earthquake in Java? If so, is it not the case that the risk from the latter is the larger?
