—The state of play so far as the nuclear agreement is concerned is that the text of it has been negotiated—indeed, that was true some time ago—that there has been an agreement stated by the Indonesian side now to sign it, and that it is just a matter of finding an appropriate opportunity in the not too distant future to do that.

PARA.TAB: The terms of the agreement, although they have not been released and will not be until they are signed in accordance with normal practice, simply cover science and technology cooperation in essentially utterly uncontroversial areas, one would have thought, like medical technology and areas which are related not to the nuclear fuel cycle but rather to safety of nuclear waste disposal and issues of that kind. The agreement does not address, as I have said on many previous occasions, the question of the supply of Australian uranium to Indonesia. Were it to be the case at any stage in the future that that were to be contemplated, that would need to be the subject of a separate and distinct agreement.

The state of play as far as the Indonesian nuclear industry debate is concerned is, I think, that there are significant differences of opinion evident in Indonesia as to whether the development of a nuclear power capacity is likely to make economic sense. I do not think that is an issue that has been yet definitively resolved, quite apart from the questions as to the siting and location of a power reactor, which obviously are questions that need very careful consideration by the Indonesians if they are going to go down that path, given some of the uncertainties about the geology of certain parts of the country—a country which is obviously prone to seismic upheaval.

My understanding is that any such move to establish a power industry is still some considerable time away and that no definitive decisions have been reached on that, but if there is anything more I can usefully add to that part of your question, I shall be happy to do so after having had an opportunity to look again at the current state of my briefing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister advise the Senate whether the government is planning to reopen the Australian embassy in Beirut and, if so, when?

—Senator Jacinta Collins and other honourable senators will no doubt recall that last year the Prime Minister committed the government to reopening Australia's embassy in Beirut by July 1995. I am pleased to say that that schedule has been adhered to and that Senator Nick Bolkus, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and I will be in Beirut on 18 July to mark the occasion of the embassy's reopening.

PARA.TAB: The fact that Australian diplomats will once more be resident in Beirut is, of course, testimony to the impressive progress that we have witnessed in Lebanon in recent years. Since the signing of the Taif accord in October 1991, Lebanon has experienced a resurgence in business activity, a regeneration of its infrastructure, and a renewal of interest by foreign investors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to interfere with your private conversation, but do you mind if I get on with this? Lebanon recorded an impressive economic growth of around eight per cent during 1994. That performance seems likely to continue.

PARA.TAB: Trade between Australia and Lebanon is not large—around $10 million annually at present—but has strong potential to grow as Australian firms seize opportunities arising from the reconstruction of the Lebanese economy.

The process of national political reconciliation in Lebanon is now well advanced. Calm prevails in most of the country. The tragic exception to that situation is, of course, in the south, where a deplorable cycle of violence and counter-violence continues between Hezbollah and Israel. We look forward to the early implementation, as we have been doing for some time, of UN Security Council resolution 425 as the basis for a long-awaited and much overdue settlement of that problem.

The return of our diplomatic presence is also a tribute to Australia's Lebanese community as a whole for the work that community has done to bring Lebanese-Australian relations back to their traditional level and for the very important contribution that community has made to Australian society. Lebanese migrants to Australia, together with their descendants, now number around 200,000 people. They have brought with them a vigorous entrepreneurial spirit, a devotion to family and community and a strong desire to be identified with their new homeland here in Australia.

The Lebanese can be very proud of their contributions to Australian society, in business, politics, education, sport and the arts. The re-opening of the embassy will foster the strengthening of ties in all areas between our two countries. It will provide services to all Australians dealing with Lebanon, promoting commercial activity and providing visa and consular services.

I am looking forward very much to going back to that country. During the three years since my last visit the face of Beirut has changed considerably. I am confident, as is Nick Bolkus, the minister, that this new chapter in Australian-Lebanese relations will mean even closer ties at all levels and will enable Australian companies and business people to participate directly in Lebanon's future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the report by the pilchard mortality task force which was tabled yesterday. It states:

QUESTION.PARA: One of three possible scenarios for the large pilchard kill around the Australian coast is the introduction of a pathogenic organism in imported pilchards cannot be discounted and that further testing is recommended on the virus.

In view of the possibility of the introduction of disease from imported pilchards, will the government now reconsider the risks of the introduction of disease that could arise from similar, more accessible protocols on imported pork, egg products and salmonoids?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as quarantine—
—And chicken meat.

—And chicken meat? You could tack almost anything else onto the end of that. Separate, well-understood quarantine processes are in train for all those products. Those processes will continue. I did advise the Senate yesterday that I intended tabling today the interim report of the pilchard mortality task force—and I will do so now.
—It is alright; it has been provided.

—It is no great achievement getting a leaked copy of it. Over 40 people were involved in the production of it, so it has been widely circulated. It is important that everybody reads the whole report rather than bits of it being selectively quoted. The chief veterinary officer advised me that this report has been agreed to by all state fisheries authorities and by all state members of the animal health committee. The report—and this is important in the context of what you just quoted, Senator Boswell—indicates:

ANSWER.PARA: That the underlying causes of the mortalities are complex and relate to a number of factors. A likely hypothesis is that the initial factors involved stress associated with environmental changes coupled with agents such as a herpes-like viral infection and/or amoebic infestations.

There have been reports that the report has disclosed that an imported virus caused the problem. I have seen reports that indicated that; but they are wrong—the report says nothing of the sort. The relevant section of the report says:

In addition, a herpes-like virus has been visualised using electron microscopy in gills from affected pilchards obtained from Western Australia, Victoria and New South Wales. Samples from Tasmania were too deteriorated for examination. Viruses have not been visualised from imported pilchards or pilchards ahead of the wave. Viruses have not been isolated from cell cultures from infected, apparently normal or imported pilchards.
The report goes on. It is also important to point out that the report also comments:
In relation to media reports that the mortality is spread from a single point source in South Australia—
that is, for those people who are advocating a disease initiation—
the balance of probability is that this is not the case.

The first observed deaths occurred 1,000 kilometres and 24 hours apart in the Great Australian Bight and south of Kangaroo Island. With regard to the general quarantine policy approach to the importation of fish products—and Senator Boswell asks what will happen—a number of other initiatives have also been finalised. The work of enhancing the AQIS database that has been under way for some time has now been completed. As of yesterday, a new system is operational which will collect data on the nature of all imported fish products, their source and proposed use.

PARA.TAB: AQIS will also continue collecting samples of imported pilchards to further assist in the ongoing work of the pilchard mortality task force and to supplement the retesting, which is already under way at the Australian Animal Health Laboratory. Using information provided through this new database, samples are now being taken from imported pilchards from import consignments to ensure that tests are run to cover all the existing sources of supply. The more general issues relating to imported fish and fish products are extremely complex, and I intend to pursue a coordinated national approach in dealing with those longer term considerations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for reading his brief, but it did not have a great deal of relevance to the question I asked. The question I asked was: because the report was not able to conclusively rule out that imported pilchards did not bring in a disease that could affect the salmon industry and other industries and as other imported products are being looked at by AQIS, will the government tell AQIS that this minimal risk it is carrying on is not acceptable to Australian primary industry and that any risk is not acceptable?

—Can I just say with a bit of strength to Senator Boswell, as someone who purports to represent rural Australia, that I hope the countries to which we currently export billions of dollars worth of beef and other product every year do not impose a process of zero risk. I hope for the sake of Australia's balance of trade and for rural Australia the concept of zero risk that Senator Boswell is advocating Australia propose is not introduced overseas against our exports. The reality is that this minimal risk concept you are talking about is simply a recognition of the fact that, when you have open borders and millions of people coming in and out of Australian airports and seaports every year, you do not have any concept in the real world of something called zero risk. For example, if someone is irresponsible enough in terms of blight of apples—an important crop for Tasmania—to bring in a bag full of infected apples in his suitcase, that means there is no zero risk. I table the report. (Time expired).

—I also direct a question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In his answer to Senator Boswell, the minister referred to a coordinated national approach. Can the minister provide the Senate with any details about how such a coordinated national approach will be achieved?

—As it happens, I can. In the light of issues raised by the pilchard mortality task force, the national strategy for aquaculture in Australia and the soon to be released BRS review of quarantine policies and practices for aquatic animals and their products, I have decided in consultation with the Minister for Resources to establish a national task force on imported fish and fish products. This proposition for a national approach was first raised by the Western Australian minister Monty House. I rang Mr House today and advised him of the Commonwealth's positive response to his proposition.
—Did he take the call?

—Yes, he did. He was very pleased, in fact. The task force will comprise representatives from key Commonwealth agencies, state agencies, research organisations, industry, recreational and environmental groups. The task force is to conduct a broadly based review of aquatic uses of imported fish and fish products. This reflects the shared Commonwealth and state responsibility for these matters.

PARA.TAB: The task force's terms of reference embrace all relevant matters relating to aquatic uses of imported fish and fish products in Australia, including industry implications, fish health, quality and environmental aspects. Particular issues to be addressed by the working group include the nature and extent of reliance by the Australian fishing and aquaculture industries on imported fish and fish products. As I have advised the Senate before, when AQIS became aware of the booming industry that has occurred over the last couple of years, it commissioned the BRS in 1992 to go ahead with the study which is now about to be released. This task force comprising both state and Commonwealth officials will have a far broader role.

The terms of reference will also include the implication of aquatic uses of such products for current and future fisheries operations and management and the development of appropriate responses to the BRS report on aquatic animal quarantine. The task force will be asked to report jointly to the Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture and the Agricultural and Resources Ministerial Council of Australia and New Zealand by the end of this year. In my view, the new task force will provide a timely and effective forum for developing a nationally coordinated approach—at both a Commonwealth and state level—on issues of vital interest to the fishing industry and marine resource managers in all states and territories.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Cook, representing the Treasurer. Can you assure the Australian taxpayers that there will be no delays in receiving their income tax refunds this year, given an environment of threatened industrial action resulting from suggestions of rolling strikes over workload disputes and problems in income tax design changes that, according to Shane O'Connell, a union representative, could result in greater ATO processing errors in determining taxes payable with the possibility of delays of up to six weeks for refunds?

—I do know that the tax office has an enviable reputation for efficiently dealing with tax returns, and I do know that the intention of the tax office is to continue to uphold that reputation. I do not have any information about the potential for industrial disputation of the tax office as this question suggests—although I am aware that, where there are industrial relations difficulties, it is not surprising that one side of the equation often emotionally or dramatically proclaims what might be the effect of industrial action, which can create some uncertainty.

PARA.TAB: Often these things are settled without any complaint in the end and things go smoothly, so one ought not to be frightened by any claims that might be made about industrial action. One ought to concentrate on what the details are, but I do not have those before me, Senator. I will contact the Treasurer and see whether he can provide me with any additional material to answer your question about alleged threatened industrial disputation in the tax office.

As to the issue of tax form design, I will have to take that matter on notice as well. Allegations have been made just this week about the tax pack. I think that those allegations have been very well dealt with by the Commissioner of Taxation. Through those allegations, I think that we do have a somewhat shameless attempt to undermine the credibility of the tax pack. The Taxation Office was in the process of correcting some of the errors that might have been in there—but they are certainly nothing like what has been claimed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know a lot about errors, Cookie.

—That is right, I do—I have become an expert in them. It seems to me that to undermine the credibility of the tax pack is a self-serving exercise for some tax consultants. Senator, on the merit of your two questions, I do need to get further briefing to give you a fuller answer, and I will attend to that as soon as possible.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister explain what internal evaluations took place in ensuring the correctness of the tax pack in the first place?
—I am sure I can explain that, and when I obtain the briefing from the Treasurer I will; and I will provide it to you with the rest of my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to the government's decision to provide $6.6 million of Australia's aid budget for light water nuclear reactors in North Korea. Is this part of a deceptive ploy on the part of the government to hide Australia's ongoing involvement in the proliferation of nuclear technology through the aid budget—technology exchanges with countries such as North Korea and Indonesia—as well as uranium sales to many other countries, including France? How does the government justify its involvement in the nuclear cycle when it is against ALP policy and strongly opposed by the vast majority of Australians?

—It seems that no matter how many times I answer questions on this subject, none of the information penetrates the Greens' heads. Over and over again we have made the point that there has been a $US5 million contribution made by the Australian government to the Korean Energy Development Organisation, KEDO, which has been set up in order to implement the agreement reached between the North Koreans and the United States to have the North Koreans abandon their acquisition of weapons capability and their existing nuclear power generating technology, which is capable of producing the necessary fissile material for that particular capability, and to subject themselves to complete safeguards. In return for that, the United States will fund—others in the international community will assist it in so funding—the supply to the Koreans of light water reactors, creating a power capability.
—Anti-nuclear New Zealanders are helping.
—New Zealand, as I am reminded by Senator Ray, is contributing also to this exercise to the extent of $300,000.
—From their aid budget?

—The point is, you make a separate decision to make this contribution—which happens to constitute, according to the criteria of the Development Assistance Committee of the OECD, legitimate aid to a developing country—because it is an assistance with infrastructure development in a manifestly developing country. It is the subject of direct supplementation out of the budget, on top of the global aid budget that was originally identified. It is described as aid but it constitutes an addition to our aid, not a particular slice of it.

PARA.TAB: I further make the point that the particular money that Australia is supplying is not directly being given to the acquisition of a nuclear capability; it is for the supply of fuel oil as an interim step to enable energy to be supplied in Korea by means other than its existing power generation capacity. So you have struck out on all fronts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister suggested that we are out of touch. We have heard his previous answers. The question we asked related to the way in which the views of the Australian people about what aid involves are being so ignored by this government. When is the minister going to abandon the priority he gives to his bureaucratic and diplomatic stance and realise that the people of Australia feel so strongly about the end of nuclear testing that they do not accept Australia's continuing involvement in any part of the nuclear cycle, whether it is technology exchanges or uranium sales, which keep countries like Korea and Indonesia within the uranium sales markets?

—This is a classic example of a supplementary question being written and delivered without reference to the answer just given. The point of this whole exercise is to defuse what was previously a very volatile—indeed, quite alarming—security situation in which North Korea seemed hell-bent on acquiring a nuclear weapons capability with the potential of that capability being applied and triggering a nuclear holocaust in one of the most volatile areas of the globe, the Korean peninsula. All of us, for a number of years, have been watching this situation develop with a mounting sense of concern, and it was a very considerable diplomatic triumph, I believe, on the part of the United States to pull off this particular agreement. The price was high, yes—there was a reciprocal obligation entered into—but it made perfect sense in all the circumstances of that case.

PARA.TAB: The Australian people might well have strong views, as you say, on all the matters you have identified. I have strong views on all the matters you identify but I also have strong views on the virtue of avoiding a nuclear war in our part of the world. I am sure that those views are shared by the Australian people. It is a rational decision and Australia is making a welcomed and much appreciated contribution to the defusing of a serious security situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, do you recall that George Gear, the Assistant Treasurer, told Labor members in a briefing note to tell the Australian public that the increase in the price of a house from the increase in the wholesale sales tax on building materials would be about $300? In question time on 6 June you changed that to between $300 and $1,000. I have here, and will table by leave, a certificate from a professional quantity surveyor in Townsville which shows that the price of a $100,000 house will increase by $1,950 and that the price of a $136,000 house will increase by $3,445 as a result of your new tax. Minister, will you now concede that you had set out to mislead the parliament and the Australian public—you will need some help from Senator Evans on this one; he is just briefing you—as to the effects of this tax and that you are now stopping ordinary Australians from achieving the Australian dream?
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. Is the honourable senator seeking leave to table that document?
—Yes, thank you, Mr President.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a question that is probably out of order because these bills are on the Notice Paper. Nonetheless, the question has been asked and has been allowed, so let me give the answer to it. What George Gear referred to, and what I referred to when I gave those figures to the Senate, was the median price of a house and land package which, from recollection, came to about $131,000-plus for Australia. That is the effect on the median house and land package. But we have also given a range of between $300 and $1,000. The reason why we have given that range is that not every house and land package in Australia fits within the median band.

PARA.TAB: Where houses are located, the size of the house one opts for, and the quality of the building materials are all things that go to make a wide range of possibilities for Australian house buyers. The $300 to $1,000 range takes account of that type of diversity in the types of houses that Australians choose. There is nothing here that the government needs to apologise for or correct: rather, the figures that we have given are bolstered by the work that has been done by Treasury in developing appropriate methodology for the calculation of the impact on ordinary Australians of these changes to the tax base.

There have been wild and somewhat dramatic allegations in trying to talk up the impact of this tax. Coming from an opposition that has no economic policy whatsoever it is not surprising that Senator Ian Macdonald would lend his name to this sort of thing. The impact of the GST, for example—a tax policy that those opposite were promoting before the last election and for which many of them have never surrendered the inspiration—would have imposed on the average or median size Australian house a tax of $4,000. But those opposite remain unapologetic for that type of approach.

The other point that needs to be made in this debate is the one concerning the absolute and unmitigated hypocrisy of the opposition. What we are talking about here is small changes to the tax base that affect housing prices. But what the opposition is talking about is blocking all of the revenue bills of the government in this session and, therefore, unmaking the federal budget: turning the budget from a budget which is in surplus with a national savings plan to a budget that comes anywhere else between surplus and whatever is the opposition's view. At the same time the opposition is crying crocodile tears at doorstep interviews around this building about the level of the current account deficit and the level of interest rates.

That is arrant hypocrisy. Those opposite cannot have it both ways. They cannot be removing the downward pressure that our budget puts on interest rates and then, if interest rates fail to fall, escape the odium that they as an opposition, by interfering with the budget, have in fact delivered higher costs to Australian house purchasers via interest rates than would ever have been the case with any of these tax changes. If, therefore, interest rates rise, or fail to fall, the cost of extra charges that home buyers in Australia will be paying will be brought to them courtesy of John Howard and Peter Costello and every home buyer in Australia will know that because we will tell them. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Minister, do you concede that Mr Gear's briefing note also said that in Perth, where the average new house costs $132,000, it will add about $260 to the price? What do you say about this actual working which shows that an extra $3,500 will be added to the price of a pretty standard sort of house constructed in Townsville? Australian home buyers trying to achieve the Australian dream are going to pay $3,500 more for a new house because of your tax. Your party has tried to fool the Australian public by telling Labor Party members to go out and say that the cost will be merely $260. How do you justify that?
—What about the grand vision, you hypocrite?
—Order! I ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw that comment about `hypocrite'.
—I withdraw.

—Simply by resorting to the facts is how I do it. We are not in the hypocritical position that the opposition is. The figures which I have talked about are for the median house-land package in Australia. The figures I have given are calculated on that. You bring to me an allegation which you wave across the chamber. As far as I know, you have not produced it to the tax office or the Treasurer for checking as to the veracity of it. You are claiming something else in a regional market, which may be different in some aspects to the median. You cannot say this is an apples to apples comparison. It may well be an apples to oranges comparison.

PARA.TAB: The HIA, the self-appointed spokesman on this issue, has not—I repeat, has not—been able to produce to the Treasury any figures to dispute what the Treasury calculations are. The fundamental proposition remains true. You cannot escape it. If you unmake the budget, you will be responsible for the increase in interest rates. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs. Does the government see its multicultural policy as static or dynamic? If dynamic, has any recent definition been given to how it might develop?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit I cannot understand the derision with which the opposition has greeted Senator Cooney's question. In making that comment, I thank Senator Cooney for his continued interest in this issue.

PARA.TAB: The report to which he referred, called Multicultural Australia, the next steps: towards and beyond 2000, is a two-volume report prepared by the National Multicultural Advisory Council, a body that the government established last July to advise on multicultural issues. It is chaired by a former immigration minister, Mick Young; with a deputy chair, former Democrats leader, Janet Powell. The government asked the council, as its first priority, to conduct a thorough review of our national agenda for multicultural Australia; to monitor progress and changes since the agenda was first set down in 1989 to see how it has been implemented; to identify what still needs to be done; and to set down some priorities for the future.

There is no doubt we have been making a success of multicultural Australia. That does not happen by accident. In essence, we have to have the right policies to ensure that the overall objectives are met and are relevant and up to date.

Those reading the report—and I know Senator Cooney, with your voracity for reading, you will—find out how much progress we have made in the last five years and how central our cultural diversity will be to our future development, whether it is economic, social, political or cultural. That is reflected in the breadth of issues examined in detail by the report, ranging from issues such as Australia's national identity, citizenship, racism, access and equity, language, employment and industrial relations, through to sports and the arts. The 47 recommendations made by the council also reflect the breadth of this area. The government will examine them. We look forward to responding to them and launching a new agenda later this year.

It is interesting in that context to highlight two issues that have appeared in the council's recommendations to government. One important development focused on by the council is that since 1989 there has been a new focus on a two-way relationship between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. It is important to multicultural Australia. The other development is a new understanding in the business community of productive diversity—how our multicultural resources and our multicultural work force can be used imaginatively to open doors throughout the world. In fact, in that context there is not one country with which we want to trade that we do not have an understanding within Australia of its culture, language and networks.

In terms of ongoing issues also, the council has identified areas where there is a lot of work still to be done and that, of course, is in areas such as racism and the reflection of cultural diversity in our public institutions. Senator Cooney, thank you for the question. It is a pertinent one. The council brought down its report today. I congratulate the 23 members for their work.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: is the minister aware that, of the government's budget estimate of $5.3 billion from asset sales in 1995-96, the maximum amount that will be raised from the Qantas sale is $1.5 billion, leaving $3.8 billion to be raised from all other asset sales? Would he concede that, even if two-thirds of the government's shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank were sold in 1995-96—and that would be an absolute maximum—the proceeds from this sale would not exceed $2.7 billion, leaving a gap of more than $1 billion to be filled by other asset sales, which the government itself acknowledges will realise only limited amounts? Will he come clean and admit that the government's asset sales program for 1995-96 has no chance of being met and that a huge hole of at least $1 billion will remain? Will he now tell the Australian people what effect this billion dollar hole will have on interest rates?

—Of course, Senator Short would know that the government displays in the budget the global expectation of income from asset sales. We do not disaggregate the figure by putting against each particular item what we expect to recover for selling that particular asset. We do not do it because, if we were to do so, we would undermine the national interest and we would undermine the interests of Australian taxpayers. If we said what we thought each thing might drag, we would be sure that that would be the maximum price we would get, and no more. Of course, the taxpayers' interest, the ordinary interest of the average Australian, is to see that, where we are disposing of public sector owned properties, we obtain the maximum income for them. So we do not disaggregate.

PARA.TAB: We have here, in this question, a foray by Senator Short to try to disaggregate the value of each of the component parts of the asset sales line in the budget this year. I will not confirm the accuracy of any of the comments Senator Short has made about that, but I will say that there has been talk about what the expected level of return for Qantas might be. That talk has been grossly inflated. The finance minister has remarked on that himself. The other factor here is that we expect that the budget bottom line will be met, with asset sales carrying the weight that we have given them in the budget settings. So we expect still to meet our budget bottom line.

We are not hypocritical. Those opposite are the hypocrites in this debate, because this question from Senator Short ends with a reference to interest rates. Of course, what is the one weapon that is fighting strongest against interest rates in Australia at the moment? That weapon is the fiscal tightening that this government has been able to bring about in the budget, and that puts downward pressure on interest rates. We have done work in finding savings, some of which you want to cut out and return so that the expenditure lines go up and the savings we have found in outlays, in fact, are returned. You also want to unmake the revenue side of this budget by opposing all of the tax changes in the budget. It is a simple calculation.

This budget has a tremendous power in the marketplace because it goes into surplus. It goes into surplus—something that the opposition never was able to achieve. It goes into a structural surplus in the next financial year and into a structural surplus of $7 billion plus in the following financial year.

You want to undermine that and take the downward pressure that this budget applies to interest rates off. If interest rates do not fall when they ought to because you have unmade the budget, and if interest rates rise when they ought to have stayed still because you have unmade the budget, then the odium for doing that will not rest with the government. We have put our budget down. It is clear. We expect to win the budget bottom line. We have heard expressions in public of various of the minor parties about what they might do about our revenue side bills on the budget but we are still there fighting to achieve the budget bottom line and the surplus figure shown in the budget.

If the opposition wants to escape the tag of gross hypocrisy, it will finally come clean and support that as responsible economic policy. You have no policy that you have proclaimed. We therefore look at your actions, and your actions are those of gross irresponsibility. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite obvious, and it is a matter of very great concern, I think, that the minister quite frankly does not understand questions that are put to him. The simple fact is that there are only two main asset sales planned by the government in this year's asset sales program. There are others, but they are small. One of them is Qantas. We know now that the Qantas float will raise a maximum of $1.5 billion. That leaves $3.8 billion still to be raised to get to your $5.3 billion target. It is just not possible for that to be raised through the Commonwealth Bank—nowhere near it. Therefore, you do have a hole of at least $1 billion on top of the phoney figures that you had in this phoney, fraudulent, fudged budget anyway. I ask you again: what impact does the government believe that a further $1 billion hole in its budget will have on interest rates? (Time expired)

—I am asked about this so-called hole by Senator Short. It is not there. We are fighting for the budget bottom line, Senator Short. Perhaps Senator Short might tell the chamber what the impact of opposing $1.5 billion in the revenue side of the budget will be on the bottom line. That is exactly what you are doing. Tell us the impact of your negligence. You will not do that, so let me do it for you.

PARA.TAB: If that unmakes the budget, it removes the downward pressure that this budget applies to interest rates. That is what it will do. The albatross will be around the neck of the opposition for Australian home buyers and everyone else in the community. You will not escape unidentified as the perpetrators of this economic crime. We will identify you in every electorate in Australia for what you have done and you will wear the responsibility of that around your neck like a stinking albatross. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Yesterday Senator Coulter asked me a question about pilchards. I said that I would provide some background information about the work being done in the CSIRO on that subject. Later he tabled a report which refers to this work, but since I gave my word to provide the information I have on the CSIRO, I table the CSIRO report, as I promised to do in my answer yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to the announced resumption of French nuclear testing in the South Pacific region.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen today is an exposure of Senator Gareth Evans's once much vaunted credentials in both human rights and disarmament issues about which he was so enthusiastic during the 1970s and 1980s. What we are now seeing is a classic example of pussy cat diplomacy. It is also worth noting that the coalition has a proud record of its own in this regard. I want to point out the extent to which this government has simply gone cold on the whole issue.

PARA.TAB: It is a great tragedy that Senator Evans does not have the intestinal fortitude to raise these matters in the UN. What we have basically heard is the running scared strategy: if anyone looks as though they might knock it off we are not prepared to take them on, to put in the hard yards or to talk the issue up; we simply throw in the towel from the outset. By contrast, back in 1985 Senator Evans would have been very hot to trot on these issues. I will read from an article that appeared in the Australian:

The United States and the USSR have made it plain that they are not yet prepared to make the concessions necessary to allow progress on Australia's initiative for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty.
The two superpowers are understood to have conveyed this hard-line message privately to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, in Geneva.

Mr Hayden would not comment, but yesterday there was little doubt that his speech to the review conference of the treaty on the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons was a tough message to the superpowers that Australia would not let the matter rest.
He strongly criticised both superpowers for failing to fulfil their obligations . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is a stark example of what you could do if you wanted to. If your heart is in it, if you are really serious about sending a message, if you want to make sure they understand your position, instead of practising pussy cat diplomacy you would be out there telling them. You would be out there urging our ambassador at the United Nations to do the rounds, to get up a form of words that would make it plain, that would stand them on their toes and make them take notice. A few months later there was another article in the Australian which I will read from:

PARA.TAB: Australia has "turned up the heat" in its call for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty with a tough resolution to the United Nations that has met strong opposition from the United States.
. . . so blunt that the US has threatened to vote against it.

Australia and New-Zealand co-sponsor a similar resolution each year, but this latest effort is perceived to be the stiffest to date. It expresses "profound regret" at the lack of action, and calls for an ad-hoc committee to begin negotiations in Geneva early next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking at the United Nations, Richard Butler—
admitted that "it is a little bit of a political razor's edge because some countries do not want to go as quickly as we have done".

PARA.TAB: In doing so, Australia has lost the support of certain Western countries, namely Canada, the Netherlands and Japan, which would normally have co-sponsored the resolution . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Did we run dead then? Did we throw in the towel? Did we say, `It's all too hard'? Did we not even embark on the exercise because we were afraid that somehow we might end up with egg on our face?

PARA.TAB: Something has fundamentally changed. That is why we want to know why Senator Evans has gone soft on nuclear issues. I have now given him three opportunities to rule himself out from running for the position of UN Secretary-General. There is a profound and obvious conflict of interest in his current situation. It is just not possible to curry favour with these nations and at the same time be out there heavily criticising them. Anyone in politics can tell you that. You simply do not give yourself a chance if you are going to knock them around the ears in the run-up to the ballot.

So you cannot have it both ways. If you want to keep going soft then you will get your reward. All I can say is that there is only one thing worse than being a disengaged moo-cow watching the passing traffic, and that is being a tame pussy cat wandering out onto the highway and allowing yourself to be run over by all and sundry.

I know you have had a particularly bad week, Senator Evans, particularly with Senator Robert Ray who of course was instrumental in assisting your ambitions for the lower house. When the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, last week wanted to delay the ballot for Deputy Prime Minister until you returned to the country, Senator Ray was the very one who brought the matter on immediately.

I can understand your fit of pique about domestic politics: you are not here very often so it does make it hard to curry favour. But the fact is that if you are going to stick to the international circuit you ought to realise that there are consequences domestically of that. You cannot go around the cocktail circuit being nice to people in the hope that they might support you and at the same time serve Australia's best interests. So why won't you swallow your pride? You love to wallow in the speculation that you could conceivably be under consideration for the Secretary-General's position but the fact is, as you well know, that that next Secretary-General will come from the Third World or the non-aligned nations. You haven't got a dog's chance, despite the fact—or perhaps because of the fact—that you are, as you described it, a monolinguistic dill, but at least you ought to be able to accept—

TALK.START.PARA: —Monolingual, actually.
—Monolingual, I am sorry. I apologise profoundly. Why won't you face up to the central issue and concede the game and at least put Australia's interests ahead of your own?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not respond to any of the rhetorical, undergraduate nonsense we have just heard from Senator Alston on matters political. What I will do is remind him, since he called in aid the opposition's fine record on these matters, exactly what the opposition has said and done over the years so far as nuclear matters are concerned.

PARA.TAB: I will begin with Robert Menzies, Mr Howard's favoured mentor, who in 1950 agreed, without cabinet or parliamentary consultation, to allow the United Kingdom to conduct atmospheric tests on nuclear weapons in Australia, distributing radioactive fall-out over a large part of this particular continent in circumstances which are now costing us tens of millions of dollars to clean up. It was the only time that any sovereign non-nuclear weapons state has ever allowed atmospheric or other testing to take place on its own soil, with the exception only of Algeria allowing another final run in France. That was the start of the contribution that the opposition made through the legacy of its particular mentor, founding father and revered figure—not least of Mr Howard—to nuclear policy in this country, letting other countries blast atmospheric tests and litter the Australian landscape with radioactive material. That was its first contribution.

Back in the 1970s the Whitlam government sought to take the matter of atmospheric testing off to the International Court of Justice. The grudging support that the opposition gave for that was manifested in a number of contributions on the public record by Ian Sinclair, among many others, complaining about the cost and the value of the exercise.

Then we came to the 1980s, when the Liberals opposed the establishment of the South Pacific nuclear-free weapons zone under the treaty of Rarotonga. They argued that it was offensive to the United States. Andrew Peacock referred to it as a `dangerously flawed proposal'. In the debate on the bill in 1986 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Prohibition of nuclear testing and nuclear waste dumping in the region ought to be removed from this Treaty . . .

I repeat: the opposition, through its spokesman, argued in the mid-1980s that the specific provisions prohibiting nuclear testing and nuclear waste dumping in the South Pacific should be removed from the treaty. Alexander Downer, now the shadow foreign minister, said:

I have two objections to the treaty. One is that it is basically an anti-French treaty and little else, and except for the platitudes that we all support, it embarrasses a number of our major allies. Secondly, I think it could be described also as the first stone that has fallen from the edifice which is the Western alliance in our region.

So we have the present opposition foreign minister, the bathtub boy who is posturing so loudly at the moment, saying that the treaty should be opposed because it was anti-French. This is the bloke who is on record in 1986 saying that this treaty is the best guarantee that we could have or ever would have that this region would be kept nuclear-free and it was opposed by the opposition specifically on the grounds that it was anti-French. The opposition was critical a little later on of our very firmly expressed opposition as a government to the Reagan Administration's Star Wars—the strategic defense initiative. That was another thing that we were deeply concerned to ensure did not happen because of its dangers of triggering a nuclear holocaust in a way that would be utterly destructive not only of our particular part of the world but of the planet as a whole.

PARA.TAB: As recently as the last election campaign, Robert Hill, the then foreign policy spokesman, suggested—

TALK.START.PARA: —Give him his title.

—Senator Robert Hill—I will give him his title as he does not have anything else to offer, certainly not in this debate—suggested as an economy measure that the position of ambassador for disarmament be abolished once we had the chemical weapons convention out of the way. There was no thought about the task that lay ahead on the comprehensive test ban treaty, no thought about the intense and immense process of negotiation and consultation and expert input that would go into the promulgation and negotiation to finality of that particular treaty. There was no thought about the job that lay ahead with the nuclear non-proliferation treaty when it came up for review, as it did in the early part of this year at the expiry of its original period of operation. There was no thought about who was going to make the case for indefinite extension.

PARA.TAB: The opposition wanted the position of ambassador for disarmament abolished because that is how little it regarded just a couple of years ago at the last election the anti-nuclear commitment that this government has consistently had for the whole of its history. It ensured that explosions went off on Australian soil in the 1950s, it gave barely grudging support to the effort in the international court in the 1970s and when it came to the real test in the mid-1980s of the very matter which is in issue at the moment, it lost it every inch of the way. Its record is disgusting. It is a bunch of cynical opportunistic hypocrites and it deserves to be painted as such. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy President, I ask that Senator Evans be required to withdraw the term `hypocrite' that he applied to all members of the opposition.
—Senator Evans, would you withdraw that.
—Is that unparliamentary—ruled as such?
—Yes.
—I withdraw.

—I was not planning to speak, but having listened to the ranting and raving of Senator Evans for the last five minutes, I felt there were a few comments worth making. The general comment is that it is true that in most of the great debates in the Cold War period the Labor Party went missing in action. Because of people like Senator Carr and Senator Faulkner, in those great debates, Senator Evans, you guys went missing in action.

PARA.TAB: But, Senator Evans, you have been greatly bruised—and it showed in your remarks—by your hopeless performance in the last two weeks over the French testing. I put it to you that not only is the left of your own party extremely critical of your performance, but most of the Australian community are; and that was, of course, shown in an opinion poll which was published on the front page of the Australian today.

The other issue which I think has emerged during this debate and which this chamber has addressed is that we have asked you on three occasions to rule out the regularly reported ambitions that you have to move from this parliament, from this country, to the UN in New York. On three separate occasions Senator Alston has asked you to rule that out. The reason that you have been asked is that there is a truly massive conflict of interest between your current role as the foreign minister for this great country and your plainly stated and naked ambition to move as fast as you can from this chamber to the UN. In all your international dealings with the French, with the Americans, with the Cubans and with all those other people that you like to constantly associate with, what we are seeing is a man who has a massive conflict of interest. You, Senator Evans, have to make up your mind whether you are the foreign minister of this country or whether you are having a prolonged job application for the UN and touting for votes for that job.
I have drawn attention in estimates hearings from time to time to some of the extraordinary aspects of the way you run your job, including the extraordinary nature of your visit to Castro in Cuba.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Hugh Morgan about that. What did he think of the visit?
—Your associating with tyrants like that is absolutely appalling. The reason you are grubbing around there is to see whether you can grub up another vote. That is the reason you are doing it.

PARA.TAB: Then, of course, there is this extraordinary capacity of your department to produce books on your behalf which you sign. Tens of thousands of dollars are wasted each year producing these books. I have made the point that if your department and you, as foreign minister, want to put out statements, you put them out on behalf of the government—not as a glossy, extended CV for you to apply for a new job. I do not think that ever in Australian politics have we seen a minister so keen to put out books dealing with issues such as—yes, you guessed it!—reform of the UN and to show what a great man you are; always careful not to cause too much offence to the people who are going to vote for you, but always, Senator Evans, at the taxpayers' expense.

I put it to you and to this chamber that Senator Evans has a massive conflict of interest here. Senator Evans has been asked three times to rule out that he plans to seek a job at the UN, and on each occasion he has failed the test. This issue, Senator Evans, as you have noted in the press, will simply not go away. Make up your mind that you are either the foreign minister of this country or you are touting for a job at the UN.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very interesting debate about Senator Evans. If it was a debate about the French testing at Mururoa, I am sure that other people on this side would get up, because we on this side of the chamber are very much against atomic testing in the Pacific.

PARA.TAB: But this debate is not—and never has been, it seems to me—about what the French are doing; it is about Senator Evans. If those opposite are so indignant about what the French are doing, why don't they say something about it? Why is this debate always about Senator Evans?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have.

—When the Hansard comes out of Senator Alston's and Senator Kemp's speeches, it will be very interesting to see how much of those two speeches condemned France and how much condemned Senator Evans. The last time I rose to talk about Senator Evans there was an accusation that he was going to the High Court. At that time, Senator Evans was involved in a conflict of interest and was doing all sorts of terrible things—according to those opposite—because he was going to the High Court. People opposite were saying, `Will you give me, us and the people of Australia a guarantee that you will not be a High Court judge?'

PARA.TAB: The next accusation was that Senator Evans was going to Holt because he wanted to be Prime Minister. Then the question was, `Will you give me, our side and our country a guarantee that you are not going to be Prime Minister?' Now the question is about his becoming Secretary-General, `Will you give me, us and the country a guarantee that you will not be Secretary-General?' Have people on the other side given any guarantees that if they ever come to office they will not be ministers or try to take a legitimate path through the political world to get to where they might want to go?'

In my view, there is no evidence that Senator Evans is going to be Secretary-General but, if he was Secretary-General, he would make an outstanding one. He would make a Secretary-General of which not only Australia could be proud but of which the world could be proud. You can show no evidence that he wants to be Secretary-General, but if he did want to, is it not something that Australia should be proud of?

TALK.START.PARA: —It would depend on how he got there.

—Of course it would. He would get there in a most honourable way. The fact is that Senator Evans's record as a foreign minister is outstanding. He did magnificent work in Cambodia. I am not too sure that we could look with much enthusiasm on what the opposition said about that at the time; he was criticised for doing it. It is the opposition's task to criticise—and that is what it is doing.I invite those opposite, if possible, to get some sort of substance to the argument they put against him. Senator Kemp and Senator Alston are both capable of giving intellectual content to the criticism they make of people.
—Steady on!

—They are capable. All I am inviting them to do is to give an intellectual basis to their argument. But, instead, they say he has no courage. They also say he is going to see Fidel Castro—and that that is outrageous. That is not the sort of thing that the United States would have been altogether excited about Senator Evans doing; so he is criticised for having too much courage on the one hand and criticised for not showing enough courage on the other hand. Let us start criticising the French rather than one of the greatest foreign ministers this country has had.

—This debate has been most interesting. I note that whilst Senator Cooney invited us all to talk about French nuclear testing, in his five minutes, he did not mention it in any shape or form but, like a lap-dog, ran to the defence of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. At least I am wearing a blue ribbon to indicate where I stand on the issue of French nuclear testing.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans started his remarks by commenting on what happened in the 1950s. That is about as relevant to me—I was born in 1958—as talking about what Moses or Adam did. It really has no relevance. Let us remember that it was in the 1950s that Senator Gareth Evans and the Australian Labor Party were still peddling the White Australia policy, a policy that the Liberal Party never embraced in any shape or form.

If you want to talk about the policy stances in the 1950s, Senator Evans, go and defend the White Australia policy. You will fail on every occasion if you want to go back to discussing the 1950s. Senator Evans, you invited us to go back to the 1970s. At that time, people of the ilk of Senator Carr were still embracing the human rights record of the Soviet Union. If you want to go back 20 years, do that by all means, but be prepared, Senator Evans and the Australian Labor Party, to acknowledge your great policy failures 40 years ago and 20 years ago.

What we are debating is not the policy stance of 40 or 20 years ago, but the policy stand today in relation to French nuclear testing in the Pacific Ocean. There is no doubt in the mind of any Australian today that the Leader of the Government in this place, as foreign minister, sold Australia's interests very short. There was no way that Senator Evans was prepared at the outset to condemn the French in a way the Australian people would have wanted him to. Senator Cooney, you will note that I am now addressing the question of nuclear testing by the French in the Pacific region.

What was the initial stance of Senator Evans? It was like a pussy cat; there was no substance and he was treading softly softly, not knowing which way to go, until he came back to Australia and some people gave him a bit of backbone. Undoubtedly they were not from the Left Wing, which has gone to water recently. It will be interesting to hear Senator Carr's contribution to this debate.

What Australia wants is a foreign minister who is committed only to the interests of the people of Australia and to world peace. We do not want a foreign affairs minister who has on top of his agenda the desire to become the UN Secretary-General. After having failed so dismally to get himself onto the High Court and after having missed out on becoming Deputy Prime Minister, because Kim Beazley has beaten him to that—he is no longer heir apparent—it will be third time lucky, he hopes. He will now try for the job of UN Secretary-General.

One day, Senator Evans may be a good Secretary-General. Quite frankly, I doubt it and I think the world would have a lot better people on offer to undertake that task. Having said that, our concern is that he is selling Australia short in his personal ambition to pursue the UN secretary-generalship. That is the important point in this debate. It is not whether Senator Evans has the qualifications and all the other things that Senator Cooney went on with. It is a question of whether in his pursuit of that job he has sold Australia's interests short in the world.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Forshaw

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 193, part (3) of which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator shall not use offensive words against either House of Parliament or of a House of a State or Territory Parliament, or any member of such House, or against a judicial officer, and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections . . . shall be considered highly disorderly.

I put it that the line being run by Senator Abetz and a number of others is clearly alleging improper motives to the foreign minister, the Leader of the Senate—and I ask you to rule it out of order. It is a disgraceful suggestion for them to put forward to this Senate that, in the course of carrying out his ministerial duties, the foreign minister has an improper motive. I ask you to rule those sorts of comments out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, I remind the Senate that, as Senator Forshaw's own leader called Senator Forshaw a bonehead and he never sought to get up on a personal explanation or ask that those comments be withdrawn, unless Senator Forshaw can point to a particular comment made by me that is against standing orders, I ought be allowed to continue. Senator Forshaw undoubtedly realised that I was scoring point after point and tried to stop the flow of points being scored. There is no substance to his point of order.

—On the point of order: imputations of improper motive are about the clearest and starkest breaches you can have because they are explicitly ruled out in the terms of the standing orders. Unless there be any doubt about my own reaction to what has been said, I do regard them as accusations of improper motive, which accusations I deny absolutely, as I have on numerable previous occasions. I think it would be appropriate for once in the history of this place for a bit of decency to prevail and for that particular line of assault and every sentence in support of it to be withdrawn.

—Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: this may be a matter that you would like to consider more calmly in the light of another time and report back to the Senate. I can see the claim being made by the other side about an inference or an imputation on a motive, but the necessary consequence of accepting that point of order is that this side of the chamber cannot raise the question of whether the minister is putting some other personal priority over and above his priorities as a minister. That is a very serious question. That is why we have been pursuing it. The minister has had the opportunity to rule out that he is interested in taking this job. He has declined to do that. While that state of affairs remains, it must be a question in the minds of the Australian community whether there is a conflict of interest. If that rule can be used to stop an opposition raising the question of a minister's conflict of interest, how on earth is the parliament meant to pursue whether a minister is putting some other personal issue over and above his or her ministerial duties? I cannot see how we could raise it any other way.

—On the point of order: Senator Vanstone may well be correct if there was some evidence to suggest that Senator Evans was traducing his duties to Australia in the interests of his own personal affairs. That allegation against the minister could not be more serious—indeed, it could not be more serious if it were put against any of us that, for our own personal ambitions, we were putting the people of Australia second. It is a most shocking allegation which would need a lot of evidence before it was made. The only bit of evidence suggested to support the allegation is that Senator Evans has been asked whether he will be secretary-general and he has not answered. It is then concluded from that proposition that he is guilty.
—No, it is not.

—Yes, it is. It is suggested that he is guilty of betraying his duty to the Australian people. That is a most terrible accusation to make, and one that is unsupported by evidence. It goes against every rule ever thought of in the interests of justice that silence, as Sir Thomas More says, does not indicate consent and never has. Yet that very traditional approach has been set aside by those opposite to make a terrible accusation on the basis of no evidence at all.

—On the point of order: I think Senator Cooney, for whom I have the greatest of respect, has missed the essential point. Regularly in parliament we look at issues involving conflicts of interest. Is there a serious conflict of interest involved here? In regard to the disclosure of financial arrangements of members and senators, there is an assumption of a conflict of interest. Equally, the point we are making in this debate is that there is an apparent conflict of interest between someone who is running a very important job on behalf of this country and who may be—we can judge only from the press reports and the speculation which regularly appears in the press—seeking a job at the UN. The logic which flows is that it is possible that the foreign minister may be in a serious position of a conflict of interest. That is the substance of the debate. Therefore, we are quite entitled to ask Senator Evans to rule himself out of that job so that he does not have that conflict of interest. I think the Australian public is entitled to expect that.

—On the point of order: I draw the historical analogy that Mr Malcolm Fraser was running for an international position right through his prime ministership. We did not raise the point of order that he had aspirations to be Secretary to the Commonwealth, did we? Nor should we. Those opposite should do exactly the same.

—I want to comment on a different aspect of Senator Forshaw's point of order. I say with regret to my colleague Senator Abetz that I do agree with Senator Forshaw. I think it was very offensive of Senator Abetz, rightly though it was, to accuse the Labor Party of supporting the White Australia policy. There is nothing more offensive that could be said about a political party than that it supported the White Australia policy.
—And created it.

—And created it, as Senator Kemp says. I think a Liberal government stopped that. It is very offensive of Senator Abetz to raise the issue of the Labor Party supporting and continuing the White Australia policy for so very long. True it is, but it is offensive.

—I think it is important that the standing order in question be observed, but I also think that it was a fairly robust debate on all sides. I did not form the view that Senator Abetz was particularly impugning the character or the integrity of the minister. He was highlighting certain issues, but that is not to understate the significance of the standing order itself. Senator Abetz, there are about 33 seconds left for you to complete your remarks.
—I can understand the Australian Labor Party's embarrassment and sensitivity at the comments that I was making, as shown by the fact that the minister has now left the chamber.
—Because he is not on chamber duty, and you know it. Don't make cheap shots.

—He is not on chamber duty when we are allegedly making these horrendous allegations against him. I would have thought he was so sensitive about this issue that he would have sought to defend himself. The issue is very simple: the people of Australia abhor the French action in testing nuclear devices in the Pacific Ocean, and the government has failed them.

—I am really sick and tired of the hypocrisy and the fraudulent nature of the Liberal Party's attacks on the issue of nuclear testing. We were asked what the coalition's policy was on this issue. We said that we only had to refer to ancient history. In the last federal election Senator Hill said that as an economy measure the ambassador's position at the conference on disarmament in Geneva should be abolished. As an economy measure! That was the Liberal Party's policy in 1993. Throughout the last 20 years, the Liberal Party has supported French nuclear testing. It has supported British nuclear testing in Australia. It has a long and consistent record on this very matter.

PARA.TAB: How does the Liberal Party respond? It resorts to personal abuse. That is really what it is about. It resorts to personal abuse to cover its fraudulent, disgraceful and totally hypocritical position on these matters. When it comes to the contribution that Senator Gareth Evans has made to Australian foreign policy, he leaves the lot of you for dead. What do those opposite do? They try to attack people on a personal basis. That is an appalling approach to take. They suggest that he could not be the Deputy Prime Minister as he is in the wrong house.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator Ray suggested that.

—They make the point that it was Senator Ray's suggestion. What a load of nonsense. If you knew anything about these matters, you would understand what nonsense it is. It shows absolute hypocrisy and absolute fraudulent behaviour on your behalf.

PARA.TAB: What we see is consistently the position of the Liberal Party on a range of matters. You now seek to try to outflank the Labor Party by absolutely fraudulently taking positions which you yourselves do not believe in. You now seek to attack the Labor Party on the basis of criticisms which would normally come from the Left. I can tell you this: there is no way that we will be associated with the sorts of fraudulent attitudes that you have taken. Senator Kemp talks about me in personal terms as well. That is fine. TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled.

The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia respectfully showeth that the tax on selected building products, proposed in the May 1995 Budget, will place an unwelcome burden on all Australians planning to build a new home, or carry out alterations and additions, or repairs/ maintenance to existing homes. Moreover, it is considered that the tax is iniquitous in that, when introduced, it will apply retrospectively to people currently building homes, who had entered in good faith into "fixed price" building contracts.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject the extension of proposed wholesale sales tax to building products.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens strongly urge the Government to accept the Democrats' proposal to drop the intended tax on essential building materials.

We believe the proposed tax—adding between $600 and $1,200 on the cost of a medium-sized home and up to $3,000 over the life of a mortgage—will make it more difficult for Australians to buy their own home, increase maintenance costs and rents on existing houses, and hinder growth in the building industry.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit our opposition to the announced imposition of Sales Tax of 12% on basic hardware and building products by the Federal Government from July 1 1995. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: 1. This new tax will directly affect ordinary Australians in the form of rising prices of building, maintaining and improving their home and by consequential job losses and company closures in an industry which has faced many economic pressures over recent years.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners request that the Senate should not pass this legislation when it is presented and/or work to prevent this taxation measure from being implemented by the current Federal Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Herron (from 428 citizens) and Senator O'Chee (from 254 citizens).

PARA.TAB: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
Forest Protection Petition for the permanent protection of remaining native old growth, wilderness and other high conservation value forest areas in Australia.
This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate Federal Government intervention, to comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in cooperation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp, cane etc.

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oil, and other nutritional and medicinal resources.
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the government to raise the pension age for women from 60 to 65.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate oppose this proposed change.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993 be amended with the application of common principles. To ensure that all parents with dependent children are treated equally, allowing maximum freedom of choice in child rearing.
These Acts need to be amended to take account of:

PETITION.PARA: 1.the fact that 60% of married women in the workforce who have children, would prefer to stay at home and mind their children, but for economic reasons can't afford to (Institute of Family Studies Survey).
2.the failure to provide for equitable choice for women and families in allowing parents the maximum right to choose the most appropriate form of care for their children.
3.that there be recognition of a parent at home as a formal occupation reflecting its economic value and worth to society.
4.the need for equal payment of any subsidies and allowances for the care of children, paid directly to the parent.
5.the recognition that a family with more than one child incurs extra expenses.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

PETITION.TITLE: Federal System of Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:
We, the undersigned citizens respectfully:

PARA.TAB: (a) express concern at the efforts of the Federal Government to undermine the role and responsibilities of the States, and the Prime Minister's unwillingness to meet with State Premiers;
(b) oppose any attempt to create regional governments in opposition to existing state and local governments; and
(c) reject the ultimate objective of the Labor Party which is to do away with the States and the Senate and to have ultimate and unquestioned power residing entirely in Canberra.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners will in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
