SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following delegated legislation be disallowed:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Casino Control (Amendment) Ordinance 1995, Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No.2 of 1995, made under the Christmas Island Act 1958
2.Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme Amendment No.95/03, made under s.4 of the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Act 1965
3.Civil Aviation Orders, Part 105 AD/B747/148, made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988
4.Determination of Technical Standard Notice TN2 of 1995, TS-024-1995 "Broadcaster Interface", made under s.246 of the Telecommunications Act 1991
5.Civil Aviation Orders, Part 105 AD/AB3/65 Amdt 1, made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988
6.Sales Tax Assessment Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1995 No.86, made under the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992
7.Sales Tax Procedure (Old Law) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1995 No.87, made under the Sales Tax Procedure Act 1934
I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include possible prejudicial retrospectivity, discretions with no indication of whether they are subject to review, and discrepancies requiring clarification. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee and the usual end of sitting statement about the work of the committee.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The summary and statement read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Casino Control (Amendment) Ordinance 1995 Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No.2 of 1995 made under the Christmas Island Act 1958

SPEECH.PARA: The Ordinance empowers the Minister to authorise exceptions to banking requirements presently set out in the Ordinance.

Prior to this amendment all casino banking transactions were required to be effected through the bank accounts maintained in the Territory. The Explanatory Statement states that the amendment will permit, in principle, off-shore foreign currency cheque clearance.

The amendment creates an exception which may be of considerable significance to the casino. There is no indication in the Explanatory Statement, however, whether the exercise of the discretion is subject to review.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice as to whether decisions made in exercise of the discretion are subject to independent review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme Amendment No.95/03 made under s.4 of the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Act 1965

SPEECH.PARA: The instrument amends the rate of subsidy in relation to a specified location in the State of Western Australia.
The instrument is dated 16 May 1995 and is stated to take effect on 18 May 1995. The date of gazettal, however, was 31 May 1995. Therefore, the instrument was effective a fortnight prior to gazettal.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking confirmation that the retrospective operation of the instrument did not prejudicially affect any individual other than the Commonwealth.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Civil Aviation Orders, Part 105 AD/B747/148 made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988

SPEECH.PARA: The instrument amends the Schedule of Airworthiness Directives relating to Fuselage Skin Stringer 12 Lap Joint.
Paragraph 2 of the compliance provision of this Directive states, "2. Modify in accordance with Requirement 2 before 20,000 flights or before 25 May 1999 whichever occurs later.".
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking confirmation that the date in the compliance provision is the date intended.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Determination of Technical Standard Notice TN2 of 1995, TS-024-1995 "Broadcaster Interface", made under s.246 of the Telecommunications Act 1991

SPEECH.PARA: The instrument determines standards relating to customer equipment or customer cabling that is connected to a telecommunications network.

From the instrument, it appears that the Determination was published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No.GN16, 26 April 1995. The Determination, however, which was signed on 29 March 1995, states that the technical standard is "effective from 5 April 1995".

The Committee is concerned that the apparent retrospectivity of the instrument brings it within the ambit of subsection 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. Under subsection 48(2), any provision operating retrospectively which would prejudicially affect the rights or liabilities of a person other than the Commonwealth would be invalid.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice concerning the apparent retrospectivity of the Determination.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Civil Aviation Orders, Part 105 AD/AB3/65 Amdt 1 made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988

SPEECH.PARA: The instrument amends the Schedule of Airworthiness Directives in relation to PPG Industrie Sliding Windows.
The Directive is stated to be effective from 3 May 1995. The compliance provision for this Directive states:
"Compliance: 1. Within seven days after 11 January 1995

TAB.TAB: 2. Prior to 01 August 1995.".

SPEECH.PARA: A possible explanation for the odd dates may be that there are two "Requirements" under the Requirements heading in the earlier instrument and the intention may be that there is a different date for each. If that is the intention, however, it is not clearly expressed in the instrument. Further, the date of 3 May 1995 creates the possibility of prejudicial retrospectivity in relation to the compliance date of "seven days after 11 January 1995".
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice in respect of the odd dates in the compliance provision and for comments regarding the apparent retrospectivity of the instrument.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sales Tax Assessment Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1995 No.86
Sales Tax Procedure (Old Law) Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1995 No.87

SPEECH.PARA: Among other things, these Regulations make amendments relating to the information to be included in evidentiary certificates where the Commissioner of Taxation is taking action against a person for the recovery of sales tax.
As the two sets of rules make an almost identical amendment to the respective principal regulations, the following comments apply equally to both instruments.

The Explanatory Statement for the Sales Tax Assessment Regulations (Amendment) states that the regulation in force prior to the making of the current amendment, regulation 18, "requires the Commissioner to certify [in the evidentiary certificate] that an assessment of sales tax payable by a person was made against the person in respect of the year set out in the certificate". This amending instrument, which removes the reference to a particular year from the Commissioner's certificate of assessment, is made retrospective to 16 June 1994.

The Committee has considered the explanation for the amendment in the Explanatory Statement, being that as the Act does not refer to a year, the amendment is removing an inconsistency from regulation 18. It is not unusual, however, for regulations to set out the details, manner and time frames within which fees, levies and charges or other imposts are to be collected or other matters complied with. That is, the delegated legislation sets out the details after the head legislation has set out the general principles.

In order to be satisfied that regulation 18 is not, in fact, valid law, the Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice as to the need to amend regulation 18 and as to whether any evidentiary certificates issued during 16 June 1994 to present were used in any actions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances Statement on work of Committee during Autumn and Winter Sittings 1995

SPEECH.PARA: During the present sittings, the Committee scrutinised the highest volume of delegated legislation ever recorded for a sitting period in the history of the Committee. The Committee scrutinises all disallowable legislative instruments tabled in the Senate, to ensure compliance with non-partisan principles of personal rights and parliamentary propriety. Of credit to the Committee, the Committee's secretariat and its legal adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan AM, the scrutiny process has maintained high standards notwithstanding the increased workload.

The high volume of legislation reflects a growth in the number of government programs, the broad policy of which is set out in principal Acts. The delegated legislation authorised by the Acts generally contains the administrative details of these programs. It is the Committee's task to scrutinise the subordinate legislation against certain criteria which have been summarised into four general principles set out in Senate Standing Order 23. These are:

PARA.TAB: (a)that it is in accordance with the statute;
(b)that it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;

(c)that it does not unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal and;
(d)that it does not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

SPEECH.PARA: In the event that the Committee finds that any of these principles may have been breached, the Committee's usual procedure is to forward a letter to the relevant Minister or law maker, requesting that the concerns raised by the Committee be examined. A response which satisfies the Committee may be an explanation which dispels the Committee's concerns, or confirmation that there exists a defect requiring remedial action, together with an assurance that such action will be taken. The Committee frequently receives an undertaking that appropriate amendments will be made to the offending legislation. If, however, a satisfactory response is not received and the Committee, in all the circumstances, is of the opinion that the situation warrants it, notice of motion of disallowance is given by the Chairman in respect of the subject instrument. A disallowance motion is the ultimate and last resort sanction of the Committee in respect of legislation which fails, or appears to fail the scrutiny process. The actual disallowance of legislation, however, is a rare occurrence. In fact, subordinate legislation has not been disallowed since 1988 due to action taken by the Committee.

The fact that such disallowance of legislation is a rare occurrence is testimony to the cooperation which the Committee receives from Ministers and Government Departments and Agencies. The action taken by the Committee and the response to that action by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer in relation to Income Tax Regulations, Statutory Rules 1994 No.461 detailed below under principle (c), exemplifies the cooperative effort between the Committee and relevant Government representatives.

The Committee is always appreciative of responsive and responsible action which serves to avoid the unnecessary disallowance of legislation. It is, of course, in the interests of all parties, that legislation is of the highest possible standard. The non partisan approach adopted by the Committee underpins the ability of the Committee to achieve that objective.

During the present sittings the Committee scrutinised 1,330 instruments. This represents an increase of 75.7 per cent on the last sittings. Of these 123 were statutory rules, the drafting of which is generally considered to be of a superior standard than that of other kinds of subordinate legislation. The remaining balance of instruments, being 1,207, were the usual heterogeneous collection of different series. Each of the 1,330 instruments was scrutinised by the Committee against the criteria summarised in the four principles mentioned above. There were 145 prima facie defects or matters worthy of comment in those instruments. The matters raised by the Committee with the relevant Ministers and law makers are described below under each of the four principles.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principle (a)
Is delegated legislation in accordance with the statute?

SPEECH.PARA: A disproportionately high number of concerns are raised by the Committee under this principle. This reflects the broad interpretation which the Committee places upon this principle. It covers not only technical invalidity, but also every other aspect of parliamentary propriety. There were one hundred and three matters raised under this principle.

Delegated legislation must be legally valid and must comply with its parent Act and with other Acts such as the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. Section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 limits the type of material "as in force from time to time" which may be incorporated in legislative instruments. One instrument defined an expression by reference to `the national classification of TAFE courses'. The question was raised whether the instrument referred to that classification system as it existed at a particular time, or whether it was intended to cover the classifications in the forms in which they may exist from time to time. The Minister advised that the classification system is the "national classification of TAFE courses" which is of a fixed nature. The Committee was satisfied that the incorporation did not impinge upon section 49A. Another instrument provided for the means of calculating the increase in the national employer benefit in any year by referring to Consumer Price Index (CPI) increases published by the Statistician. In that case the consensus of legal opinion was that the incorporation was valid, notwithstanding that it referred to more than one figure, because the figures do not link as an instrument or other writing as in force from time to time. On another occasion, however, the Committee detected a breach of section 49A which was confirmed by the relevant Minister. An Airworthiness Directive required compliance with a specific document and subsequent temporary revisions. This purported incorporation was in breach of section 49A.

The question regarding the validity of an incorporation of documents was also raised in respect of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Regulations which incorporated many documents by reference. In such a scientific field, the incorporation is probably desirable. Nonetheless, the Committee examined the incorporation to ensure that it is in accordance with the provisions of the relevant legislation. The Committee has also inquired as to whether the standards made by the Australian Accounting Standards Board are instruments of a kind which may be incorporated under s49A, as they exist from time to time.

On two occasions, the Committee's processes revealed that instruments which were the subject of an amending instrument, had not been tabled. This was due to the unorthodox tabling provisions which exist under the principal Act. The Minister had, however, previously undertaken to review these tabling provisions. Another instrument purported to revoke the former instrument in the same series. A search of available records indicated that the former instrument had not been received for scrutiny and that, although it was notified in the Gazette, it appeared not to have been tabled in either House of Parliament. The Committee has raised appropriate questions with respect to that instrument.

It is a clearly established principle that the drafting of delegated legislation should be of a standard equal to that of Acts. During the present sittings there were many errors in relation to numbering and citation. Two instruments had no numbering. Three instruments had no numbering and no other means of citation. One instrument had two different systems of numbering. The renumbering of another instrument contained errors. Other instruments contained errors in the numbering used throughout the document and in referring to provisions in other instruments. Where the renumbering of an instrument had occurred due to previous errors and renumbering is contained in a separate amending instrument, the Committee explored the possibility of the instrument being reprinted as it deals with the rights of the aged and infirm. Yet another instrument had an irrelevant attachment.

Some instruments were found to contain typographical errors of a minor nature and others contained imprecise or objectionable language. One instrument, for example, referred to "Parliamentary Council" when clearly "Parliamentary Counsel" was intended. Yet another incorrectly spelt the name of a disease. The Committee noted the extensive use of sexist language in a Treaty set out in a schedule to Regulations. Whilst recognising that removal of such language from the Treaty would be outside the practical capabilities of the Committee, it acknowledged the unacceptability of such language in either Commonwealth Acts or subordinate legislation. Several instruments contained imprecise definitions or lacked definitions where definitions were required. Some defined terms or phrases not even used in the instrument. Similarly some instruments defined expressions which were not even used, but which were similar to other expressions which were in the instrument. In addition some instruments contained vague or peculiar expressions. For example, AUSTUDY Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1994 No.409, provided that amongst the changes to a person's circumstances about which the department must be notified is if a person "gets a spouse".

Every instrument should be accompanied by full and detailed explanatory material. One instrument had no Explanatory Statement. Others had Explanatory Statements which did not contain sufficient explanatory material, or which contained ambiguous material. Several Explanatory Statements contained errors of a minor nature, such as typographical errors and incorrect dates. One Explanatory Statement was inconsistent with the instrument. The Explanatory Statement referred to three named institutions, whereas the instrument itself referred to two different institutions. A number of instruments fulfilled or partially fulfilled previous undertakings given to the Committee to amend errors which the Committee had identified. Many of these, however, were accompanied by Explanatory Statements which did not mention the role of the Committee in identifying the problem.

The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that delegated legislation which operates to prejudice a person retrospectively is void. Even where retrospectivity is valid, the Committee will raise a query, particularly where long periods of retrospectivity are involved. During the present sittings, the Committee raised concerns about retrospectivity on seventeen occasions. The issue of possible prejudicial retrospectivity was raised in relation to several instruments from a single authority. Retrospectivity was frequently raised in the context of compliance dates, where certain inspections were required to have taken place by dates which had already passed. The Committee's concern was that such compliance, if it had not already occurred, was now impossible. In other instruments in the same series, some compliance dates appeared remote when considered in the context of the danger the instrument sought to avert. On one occasion, the non-existent compliance date of 31 June 1995 was given.

Some instruments are intended to operate retrospectively but without prejudicially affecting any individual other than the Commonwealth. Where the Explanatory Statement does not give an appropriate assurance in relation to retrospectivity, the Committee has sought confirmation that this is so.

Some technical errors which appear to be minor at first glance may, in fact, have substantial ramifications. The Committee raised concerns about apparent discrepancies in two instruments which adjusted the Higher Education Contribution Scheme liabilities of institutions for certain years. Discrepancies were detected between the institutions named in the instrument and those institutions named in the Principle Act under which the payments are authorised. In several cases, the discrepancies were minor. Others, however, were more significant. The Committee is advised, in respect of one of those instruments, that an appropriate declaration was made changing the name of the institution. The Committee was satisfied with this response.

Concerns were raised on the grounds that some instruments may be technically invalid. Four instruments in a particular series appeared to have been made outside the period provided by the enabling provisions under which they were made. The Minister undertook to introduce amending legislation to ensure the validity of the instruments and any decisions made thereunder. In addition, one of those instruments was undated and extraneous material was provided to verify the date the instrument was signed. Two of these instruments also lacked gazettal dates.

In ensuring that subordinate legislation conforms with all aspects of parliamentary propriety, the Committee raised three other matters worthy of specific comment. One instrument provided the procedures to be followed to ensure that persons affected by reviewable decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are made aware of their rights to seek review of those decisions on the merits. The instrument, however, did not appear to stipulate how the "public notice" is to be given. The Committee was sufficiently concerned to make appropriate inquiries. Second, another instrument proposed to make an amendment which appeared to remove certain instruments from parliamentary scrutiny. The Committee always views such initiatives with concern and made appropriate inquiries to determine precisely which instruments, if any, would be affected by the proposed regulation. The Committee was satisfied by the response received.

Third, another instrument declared that insect repellent for use on human beings was to be regarded as "an agricultural chemical product". This provision raised the question of whether it went beyond the limits of the Act requiring such products to be subjected to all the testing and modification procedures required by the Agricultural Chemical Products code. The Committee's inquiries were satisfied.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principle (b)

SPEECH.PARA: Does delegated legislation trespass unduly on personal rights and liabilities?

The Committee interprets this principle broadly, to include every aspect of personal rights. The Committee views with concern legislation which contains unreasonable provisions or provisions which appear to impose harsh and unfair penalties. Furthermore, procedures provided for in subordinate legislation should be fair and accompanied by appropriate safeguards. In addition to those matters, the Committee will also query unusual or unexpected provisions. During the present sittings the Committee raised the following matters in relation to delegated legislation under this heading.

The Committee examined two instruments which it considered contained material appropriate for consideration by the Privacy Commissioner. The first instrument authorised the release of certain types of information and in the circumstances, the Committee felt it appropriate that the Privacy Commission should have been consulted in the process of development of the instrument. The second instrument involves the release of personal information. Although the Explanatory Statement noted that the disclosure of personal information is aligned with parts of Privacy Principle 11 in the Privacy Act 1991, the Committee considered that it was appropriate to ask whether the Privacy Commissioner had been consulted. These matters have been raised with the relevant Ministers.

Another instrument proposes to impose strict liability in circumstances in which it may be unreasonable to do so. The Committee has written to the relevant Minister drawing attention to those provisions and pointing out the possible unfair consequences for some defendants. The Committee has inquired as to whether the imposition of strict liability in circumstances which may have an unfair result may be avoided. In relation to other instruments, the Committee has sought confirmation that the rights of persons have not been disadvantaged.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principle (c)

SPEECH.PARA: Does delegated legislation make rights unduly dependent on administrative decisions which are not subject to independent review of their merits?

It is common for subordinate legislation to contain provisions which confer discretions on Ministers or other public officials. Some of the discretions conferred may be significant. The Committee supports the conferring of narrow discretions which are exercised against well defined and objective criteria. The Committee believes that decisions made in the exercise of such discretions should be subject to a review on the merits by an external and independent tribunal. This is normally satisfied by the provision for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Sometimes there are additional opportunities for review by other independent bodies and the Committee welcomes such opportunities.

During the present sittings the Committee raised concerns about the provision of review procedures on thirteen occasions. Concerns were raised in relation to, for example, the importation of certain firearms and part of firearms, and the allocation of capacity under the International Air Services Commission Regulations (Amendment). Such decisions may have considerable commercial implications for affected parties.

Another instrument involved the procedures to be followed at the Annual General Meetings of a particular organisation. The procedures enabled the organisation itself to determine the status of individuals which affected voting rights. Although decisions affecting status would be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Committee was concerned to inquire as to whether the review process would be completed prior to the Annual General Meeting. The Committee also questioned the status of resolutions passed at an Annual General Meeting from which potential voters had been wrongly excluded. The concerns of the Committee were allayed by the response which fully described the relevant procedures and related matters.

One instrument conferred a discretion on the Secretary of the relevant Department to enable the holder of a visa to be employed in Australia by any employer for a period in excess of three months. The response explained the discretion in the context of a previous amendment which had erroneously omitted the discretion. The Committees was satisfied with the explanation. Another instrument conferred a discretion on a Minister which would be exercised in respect of the operator of one enterprise only. The Committee has made relevant inquiries regarding the review procedures available in relation to the exercise of that discretion.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Income Tax Regulations, Statutory Rules No.461 of 1994

SPEECH.PARA: The following illustrates the application of the third principle to the Income Tax Regulations.These amending regulations, amongst other things, outline the method for calculating transitional lump sum reasonable benefit limits (RBLs) and transitional pension RBLs as proposed in section 140ZE of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Some of the regulations confer very wide discretions on the Commissioner, particularly those contained in regulations 51 and 53E. Regulation 51 provides that the Commissioner may determine RBLs at a higher rate than otherwise provided by the regulations "because of special circumstances". Under regulation 53E, the Commissioner may permit registration of a transitional RBL at a date later than the cut-off date of 31 December 1996.

The Committee wrote to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, inquiring as to whether decisions made by the Commissioner in exercise of the discretion were subject to independent review. To preserve the Committee's options, notice of motion of disallowance was given on 21 March 1995.

The response to the Committee's letter indicated that the only review available was that under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. The Committee considered this response against its third term of reference which requires the Committee to ensure that delegated legislation does not unduly make citizens rights dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal. Against this criteria the Committee concluded that it was unsatisfactory that the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 should be the only avenue for review. The Committee therefore wrote again in more specific terms.

As notice of motion of disallowance was due to expire an appropriate course of action had to be determined. It was clear that there were competing interests in this matter. On the one hand, the nature of the discretions in the regulations demanded an additional and independent opportunity for review on the merits. On the other hand, disallowance could result in the loss of the only flexibility available in the system for calculating RBLs. This could have meant a very negative result for taxpayers.

A draft response to the Committee's second letter was received. That letter confirmed the Committee's conclusions regarding the lack of opportunity for review of decisions on their merits. Hoping to avoid the invalidation of the regulations, and thereby preserve some flexibility in the system for the taxpayer, the Chair on behalf of the Committee, again wrote to the Parliamentary Secretary. The Chair indicated that an undertaking by the Parliamentary secretary to provide the requisite review mechanism would be an appropriate response.

The Parliamentary Secretary provided that undertaking on the same day. From the point of view of the Committee, this was a most satisfactory resolution. This case illustrates the co-operative effort of the Committee and relevant Government representatives to avoid the unnecessary disallowance of legislation whilst ensuring that subordinate legislation conforms with parliamentary propriety.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principle (d)

SPEECH.PARA: Does delegated legislation contain matter more appropriate for Parliamentary enactment?

Matters are not often raised under this principle. It is, nevertheless, an important principle. It is a breach of the fundamental requirement of responsible government if matters are contained in delegated legislation which should be subject to all the safeguards of the parliamentary passage of a Bill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Undertakings

SPEECH.PARA: During the present sittings, eleven instruments were considered by the Committee in the usual course of its scrutiny powers which fulfilled or partially fulfilled undertakings given to the Committee by the relevant Ministers. The majority of these instruments were accompanied by explanatory material which set out the history of the amendment, making particular mention of the Committee's role in identifying problems and errors. The Committee is appreciative of this recognition.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Condolences

DEBATE.TITLE: PROHIBITION OF EXPORTATION OF URANIUM TO FRANCE (CUSTOMS ACT AMENDMENT) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Coulter) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Customs Act 1901 to prohibit the exportation of uranium-bearing ore or uranium ore concentrates to France until the cessation of French nuclear weapons testing in the South Pacific Region.
Motion (by Senator Coulter) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: Imagine, if you can, a situation in which Australia, as a grower of opium poppies, was supplying poppy latex to another country for the manufacture of codeine in a legitimate pharmaceutical enterprise. Imagine further that we then learn that this country has begun making heroin for the illegal drug trade. The foreign country insists that it is not using our poppy juice to make its heroin and is prepared to enter into a bilateral agreement that none of our poppy juice will be so used. Would we continue to supply such a country?

PARA.TAB: How much more serious is it when it is not heroin and a few dead addicts but a threat to the security of the whole of human kind? For not only is there an immediate and local threat from the Mururoa tests but a much greater threat through the reversal of the trend toward a cessation of nuclear testing and thence to total nuclear disarmament. The hard work of very many people in this direction has been undermined by the arrogance of the French president. The cause of peace and cooperation has been placed once more in jeopardy.

Why would the French want to continue testing if they do not reserve the right to use these weapons in either an aggressive or defensive way. However they are used, nuclear weapons are destructive. Their use would damage the user as much as those against whom they are used. There is no place on our shrinking globe for the use of nuclear bombs. The Foreign Minister drew attention to that matter only a few moments ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The long-term consequences from certain types of atomic bomb explosions could be total sterilisation of vast areas of the earth for generations. No encouragement of any kind should be given to any nation that tests nuclear weapons and, by implication, entertains their possible use. On the contrary, every effort must be made to dissuade that nation from its dangerous course.

PARA.TAB: With the resumption of the French tests there is probably more unanimity of the Australian people behind a ban on uranium exports to France than any other matter at this time. The passing of this bill would be extremely popular. This bill gives effect to the wish of the majority of the Australian people. It gives legislative expression to the democratic voice of the people. This contrasts strongly with the French decision which appears to have been taken by the president alone.

The policy of the Labor Party is designed to restrict uranium exports to nations that are acting against the interests of nuclear non-proliferation. In 1984, when France was still testing, the Labor Party adopted a policy which said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Reserves the right . . . to withhold supplies of uranium permanently, indefinitely or for a specified period from any country which . . . adopts nuclear practices or policies inimical to further advance in the cause of nuclear non-proliferation.

Despite a weakening in nuclear policy in 1994, the Labor Party's policy still included the same clause but in the meantime France had ceased testing. A clause follows the 1984 clause which acknowledges the cessation and the moratorium which France had then placed on nuclear tests, but goes on:
However, Australia shall not permit further contracts of Australian uranium to France until France enters into a comprehensive test ban treaty.

In this the ALP seems to be giving a higher priority to maintaining existing contracts than to nuclear non-proliferation. However, it indicates a sensitivity on the part of the party with respect to France—a sensitivity which is more keenly felt by the Left and conscience of the party. It also indicates a very real concern for the danger of continued testing.

PARA.TAB: Unlike the Labor Party, the coalition has never opposed the export of uranium. It was the coalition, when in government, that approved the first exports of uranium for civil use. It was also a coalition government that exported uranium to Britain for the manufacture of the bombs that were exploded at Maralinga. This bill gives the coalition an opportunity to demonstrate to the Australian people that it now places a higher priority on long-term human welfare and nuclear non-proliferation followed by total nuclear disarmament than on getting its 30 pieces of grubby silver from a nation that ignores these paramount considerations.

The Australian people want their parliament to take strong action in the face of French defiance of international condemnation. This bill provides the opportunity for the whole parliament to unanimously support a measure which will place Australia in the forefront of peace seeking nations and earn the gratitude of every Australian citizen and every citizen of the many South Pacific nations that lie closer to the tests—not a few of whose citizens have suffered directly from cancers induced by the radiation from earlier bomb tests.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend this bill to every member of the Senate and seek their unequivocal support. I point out that when the government moves the adjournment, the Democrats will seek a division as an expression of the fact that the government and the opposition are simply not wishing to proceed with this important piece of legislation.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee on soccer, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not have a great deal of time this afternoon. It was with great difficulty that this Senate committee proceeded with its inquiry into soccer, not least because we followed an inquiry which had been carried out by former Mr Justice Stewart under considerable difficulties. Mr Stewart was asked to inquire into various aspects of soccer, particularly the transfer of Australian players to overseas clubs by the Australian Soccer Federation. In the course of that inquiry, he was not acting in a judicial capacity. Therefore, he did not have the ability to subpoena witnesses or offer witness protection.

PARA.TAB: When the Stewart report was eventually presented to the Australian Soccer Federation, it contained a number of recommendations. Many of those recommendations named particular people in highly adverse ways. The Australian Soccer Federation was placed in a situation whereby, with legal advice, had it published that report it may have been subject to legal action for publishing defamatory comments.

The committee understands that all but one member of the board of the federation received a copy of the report, and some parts of that report certainly were available to the media. Stories regarding what Mr Justice Stewart had said had begun to circulate. It was in that context that the Senate committee first took up this reference.

Given that circumstance, at the time of taking up the reference unanimously the committee felt that it was appropriate for the Stewart report to be published so that all those matters would be out in the open and under parliamentary privilege; that this would protect the Australian Soccer Federation; and that all those who were adversely named could come forward and provide evidence under parliamentary privilege to the committee. If they chose, they could provide contrary evidence. That is the context in which the committee conducted its inquiry.

The committee was able to look at a number of the matters which Mr Justice Stewart had inquired into. In the course of our inquiries we have come to conclusions, in many cases different from those of Mr Justice Stewart. In that regard we would emphasise most strongly that the Senate inquiry has played an extremely valuable role.

During the course of the committee's hearings, the Soccer Federation board itself underwent considerable reconstruction. A number of members of the board left and new members were appointed. The chairman of the board changed. Mr David Hill, former chairman of the ABC, came in as chairman of the board of the Australian Soccer Federation. A number of changes had already begun to be made while our committee was deliberating.

I wish to make some comment on the summary of the principal findings of the committee, because I think it is worth emphasising just what this committee did achieve. We confirmed the media reports which, for several years before the committee took this reference, had generated considerable public concerns about the very, very large sums of money being paid by overseas clubs for Australian players. Many of those sums of money were not fully accounted for.

There were stories of cash transactions and large amounts of money going missing. We were able to confirm that indeed large amounts of money had gone missing and, while we were not able to find exactly where the money had gone, nonetheless there were gross discrepancies, very serious discrepancies. We believe that highlighting those differences will help to support our other recommendations which go to the heart of improving the whole transfer process and making it a great deal more transparent. We identified that cash payments had been made, and, as I say, while we were not able to identify the ultimate beneficiaries of these vast differences, nonetheless there is a clear and very important need to clean up this whole process of transfer.

The impression that came most strongly to me was one of a rapid improvement and increasing number in the quality of Australian soccer players which resulted in an increase in demand for those players by overseas clubs, principally European clubs, and also a very substantial increase in the price being paid for those players. In that situation, it seems that soccer administration generally in Australia failed to put in place proper mechanisms to ensure that Australian soccer, the Australian clubs and the Australian players got the very best deal from those transactions and, in that process, exposed certain officials to the possibility of acting improperly and certainly exposed Australia to the possibility that these large sums of money which we identified went missing and went to sources at this stage unknown.

We did not find that the two principals at the centre of the coach transfer were in any way guilty of receiving any of this money. While we found it strange that they had not been asked to sign formal contracts and that at least the principal coach, Mr Eddie Thomson, had acted in a way which was improper, I certainly would accept that he was put in that position by the failure of the Australian Soccer Federation to put other mechanisms in place which would have substituted for the actions which he took in relation to player transfers.

Because the government members of this committee have sought to place on record a minority report, I would also like to reiterate that with the change in the government membership on the committee I believe the committee did become hampered by the attitude of some of those government members. I also believe the committee was exposed to ridicule on several occasions when government members chose to expose the differences in relation to whether the committee should have been taking certain evidence and what sort of evidence it should have been taking—indeed, even whether the committee should have existed in the first place. Those discussions which should, I believe, have been kept within the confines of the committee in private session were exposed to public view. I would certainly dissociate myself and the majority of the members of the committee from those actions. I think they were unnecessarily damaging.

In conclusion, I believe there has been a significant improvement in the administration of soccer. Part of that has been brought about because the committee was able to release the Stewart report and, of course, by the processes through which the committee went. The evidence which was brought forward to the committee itself accelerated and catalysed that process of change.

Soccer is an extremely good game. It should be a game in greater prominence in Australia. I believe it has been hampered in the past by these stories of corruption, mismanagement and lack of proper administration. I believe that the work of this committee has helped to put soccer on a much sounder footing with a better administration and that from here it will go forward to be the sort of game that it should be and to attract the sort of support that it should have been attracting in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this report on soccer and to perhaps explain my role in these matters. I came late to this committee; in fact I replaced Senator Devereux. As a consequence of becoming the chair of the legislative side of the committee I became the deputy chair of this reference of the committee.

PARA.TAB: One of the committee's references was this soccer inquiry. Like many people in this place, I had heard that this was not necessarily the most savoury of activities but I was prepared to approach the matter with an open mind and I read through the evidence that had been presented to my office. Upon reading that, it became very clear to me that there was a major problem in using the Senate for this type of work. I do not particularly want to engage in a polemic about the detail of it, but I want to place on record my very firm belief that the Senate should not be used to attack the civil liberties of Australian citizens as I think it is a fundamental principle of good government and the good legislative processes of this country. To me this inquiry quite clearly and demonstrably is an occasion when the civil liberties of Australian citizens have been fundamentally abused.

Let us get the context right. Last year there was a series of allegations about improprieties within the Soccer Federation. As a consequence, it obviously had some serious debates within its ranks. The ABC Four Corners program made a whole range of most serious allegations about the activities of a number of people involved in the Australian Soccer Federation, coaches, players, agents, clubs and officials. As I understand the situation, at that point a proposal was advanced by certain Liberal members of parliament that there be a Senate inquiry into these allegations. It was felt that the Soccer Federation should be able to sort these things out. It commissioned Mr Justice Stewart to produce a report, which cost something like $450,000. In that report a whole series of quite strong and quite serious allegations were made about the activities of certain citizens of this country. As a result of this inquiry by the committee which the Senate set up, the Senate has found that most of the matters of concern to the committee had been resolved by the Soccer Federation by the time the Senate report was actually handed down today.

In the process of the Stewart report being produced, very serious defamatory remarks were made. As a consequence, there had to be an outlet, under parliamentary privilege, to prevent defamation action being taken in the courts by citizens who were offended by these remarks. We have provided a vehicle by which defamatory remarks can be made and citizens' rights through the courts can be denied by using the Senate process to allow those remarks to become after-the-fact evidence before a committee of the Senate. People can be subpoenaed. As a consequence, there can be no protection at law for the people offended by those remarks.

Very serious allegations that went to corruption, conflict of interests, tax avoidance, improper financial transactions and a whole range of other matters were made. Criminal matters were alleged which have never been proved. Quite clearly, this report does not prove them but has left a slur on those persons' names throughout the process.

No matter what honourable senators opposite say and no matter what Mr Justice Stewart said in his report—he said his findings were opinions—no-one is able to convincingly demonstrate that most people believe the Stewart findings were nothing more than someone's opinion. That is the real problem in this matter. We have made a series of very serious allegations which have been given the cloak of legitimacy of the Senate. We say to people who are called—and subpoenaed in some cases—before this committee, `Aren't you glad you had the right to respond to these allegations that this Senate, through its committee, has given legitimacy to?' I put on the record that I am deeply offended by that process of the abuse by this chamber of civil liberties of citizens.

The evidence adduced to the committee at no point demonstrated that any of those allegations had any substance. The police inquiries were rightly undertaken, as they should be when allegations like these are made. What did the police come up with? No recourse to criminal prosecutions because the evidence does not warrant that. That is in writing. Does that help the people who have lost their livelihoods or whose lives have been destroyed or in any way dramatically affected by these allegations?

The Clerk of the Senate raised very serious concerns about the operations of these committees. He makes the point that actions before Senate inquiries and before the Senate cannot be used in courts of law. Therefore it would be possible for those who have committed offences to use that defence in a court of law. By the same token, those who are slurred or defamed cannot seek redress because it is all done under parliamentary privilege. You have a situation where the guilty are able to be protected and the innocent are slurred.

That is not a process that I want to be associated with. Senator Coulter makes the point that this committee may not have worked effectively because the Labor members did not fully cooperate with it. Nor should we! Nor should we be part of such an outrageous attack on civil liberties. I make it my business not to go along with that blatant abuse of the rights of the citizens of this country by this chamber. It is a gross waste of public money. It is a gross indecency, in terms of the political rights of citizens of this country, to be part of it.

If there were criminal activities, this is not the place to investigate them. We are not a court of law. I am not trained as a defence lawyer or a police prosecutor. Under our constitutional arrangements, I do not have the right to act as if I were a judge. You are deluding yourselves if you think that is an appropriate function for this Senate. All too often Senate inquiries have developed into witch-hunts and kangaroo courts. It is a totally inappropriate use of the time of this Senate. The minority report draws attention to this gross abuse of civil liberties.

This is the offence we have created: the minority will not go along with the majority. The committee system is run by the opposition. Be clear on this: the committee system is run by the opposition. The opposition seeks to fundamentally cause offence to those basic principles of democracy that we on this side hold very strongly.

In recent times we have seen a sea change in the soccer community. Since David Hill's appointment to the federation you can see a symbolisation and major changes in the soccer world. The Stewart report's major recommendations on policy issues as distinct from allegations of criminal activity have been addressed. That is appropriate. Major changes are occurring. Other matters are before various courts such as the arbitration courts.

It was not appropriate for this Senate to allow this activity that abuses civil liberties to go on. The Labor senators made clear throughout the work of this committee that we were seeking to have these matters brought to a conclusion much earlier than they were. Every attempt was made by the majority to resist it. While I am sure honourable senators opposite appreciate the great value of the game of soccer and have a deep personal interest in the game of soccer, I found extraordinary the personal efforts they made to secure evidence, which would not have come before the committee in the normal course of events, to bolster the claims they had been making and the attacks on civil liberties they had been making to try to drum up some basis for their claims. They have failed dismally. This report demonstrates their failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the latest instalment in a deliberate campaign by Senator Carr to seek to damage the whole Senate committee system. It is part of a campaign he has been assiduously following for some time.

PARA.TAB: I point out to the Senate that this was not a coalition stunt of any kind. This was a totally non-political inquiry until Senator Carr joined the committee. The chairman of this committee was not a member of the coalition. In fact, he was a Democrat.

TALK.START.PARA: —And an independent, too.

—And a very independent minded Democrat as well. There is no suggestion that this was a political stunt of any kind until Senator Carr pulled his political stunt. His objective, I believe, was not only to try to destroy the Senate committee system, which he has endeavoured to do on three other committees, but also to serve some other political objectives. One of them, I believe, was to protect a mate of one of his mates—Mr Labbozetta, a friend and appointee of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) on the Immigration Review Tribunal—despite the fact that Senator Carr failed to take any active role in this committee. We have avoided dealing in any depth at all with the question of Mr Labbozetta because he has an appeal pending before a liquor tribunal.

PARA.TAB: To clothe in political sanctimony the political objective that Senator Carr has is disgusting. To try to pretend this was a political witch-hunt and we were seeking desperately to find some wickedness to meet some kind of secret agenda is one of the most nonsensical things I have ever heard.

The fact is that soccer football in Australia receives $1 1/2 million a year in taxpayers' money. The people who are spending that money are people who had been subjected to that kind of very public criticism, not just in the Stewart inquiry but in other public arenas. For example, Mr Hill himself, who kept on complaining about the existence of the inquiry when it suited him, failed to mention that he was the head of the organisation, the ABC, that brought this problem to the forefront of public attention in its Four Corners program. We have given the people who were attacked in that program the opportunity to clear their names, and I believe their names have been cleared.

We were assiduous in trying to make certain that soccer had every opportunity to emerge from this with a clean sheet. I note that we were blamed and attacked by Senator Carr for having done what we could to make certain that all evidence that could come forward did come forward. In other words, by doing our job we obviously infuriated Senator Carr.

The facts are very simple. This matter could have been resolved a long time ago. In mid-1993 we discovered in evidence that the Chief Executive of the Australian Soccer Federation wrote to the English Football Association—this is more than two years ago—saying that it was going to have an inquiry into these problems it was having with agents. At that stage, the English Football Association had discovered a whole range of problems, particularly relating to transfers of Australian players to British clubs. There was a massive difference between the price being paid by the clubs and the price the Australian clubs were getting for their players. Here was the Australian taxpayer putting $1 1/2 million a year into soccer, while foreign agents were siphoning off—and that is just in the transfers we looked at—something like $1.2 million.
For heaven's sake! Senator Carr somehow finds it disgusting and immoral that we should express concern about that, that we should examine it. What kind of double standards does the senator have?

TALK.START.PARA: —He has no standards.

—He has no standards. The simple facts are that these huge differences were revealed in public. We have now confirmed them. We have established quite clearly the amounts in various transfers. We have not, unfortunately, been able to do as well as we might, because a lot of people made allegations behind the hand. There were a number of people, particularly players, who, as I understand it, talked to the media—that is, if the media people are telling the truth.

PARA.TAB: All of those claims and allegations simply were not made to this committee when people had the opportunity to do so—apart from one or two players who came and gave some very frank and, I might say, risky evidence in the sense that they may well have risked their playing future in this way. We commend them for doing so. But, on the whole, it does seem that many players had very strong reasons for not doing so.

I hope that the reason they failed to come forward was not because they were participating in some way in the tax free amounts of money that appear to have disappeared, if you like—maybe they were switched to who knows where under these arrangements. We saw a clear situation where there were receipts issued by an Australian soccer club for $515,000 for a transfer and, in fact, that club itself received only $240,000. Certainly, some of the gap was made up by specific cash paymentsand we have been able to see that. But we still do not know what happened to the great bulk—a difference of almost $200,000.

We have some pretty good ideas and we have been led in certain directions, but the simple fact is that this committee's inquiries could establish without doubt that Australian soccer has been milked for a particular purpose by some foreign clubs. There is no doubt in my mind that there is a slush fund, or maybe several slush funds, created overseas from money brought to Australia, purportedly for the purpose of a transfer but which, in fact, has been diverted for other purposes—presumably to create a tax free slush fund in another country, possibly Switzerland—so that tax free payments can be made to players or others for particular purposes in the future.

There is no doubt in my mind that the committee's inquiry has served the best interests of both soccer football—in providing an opportunity to clear the air of all of the allegations, the rumours and the speculation affecting the sport over a considerable period—as well as allowing those alleged to have been guilty of misbehaviour the opportunity to respond.

I know that one of my colleagues wishes to say a few words, but I do just want to say this. We have discovered quite a few additional matters that Senator Carr did not have the decency to acknowledge. We have found, as a result of the inquiries in Britain, that certain material which we have deliberately not brought before the committee, and which has been referred to authorities to pursue, may well be of a criminal nature. I want to stress this: at no stage did this committee transgress into the area of criminality; at no stage did we seek to act as judge or jury. We were looking at people's behaviour and the proprietary of it, not the illegality of it. That is why Senator Carr's attack on this committee is a disgrace. It is a political stunt. It reflects poorly on him because it is part of his evident campaign to try to destroy the power of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support the remarks that have been made by the chairman of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee, Senator Coulter, and also by my colleague Senator Baume. I also want to totally dissociate myself from the comments that have been made by Senator Carr in what I thought was an outrageous attack on a committee that has at all times tried to act with the utmost propriety. I will briefly read the comments of Senator Faulkner, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, when this reference was referred to the Senate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the government does not intend to stand in the way of that inquiry taking place. Obviously the government would work cooperatively with the inquiry as appropriate, and also with the Australian Soccer Federation in working these important issues through.

It is a pity he did not pass that message on to his factional colleague, Senator Carr, who, from the time of his entry to this committee, has sought to do nothing but destroy the workings of the committee by taking sensational stands. He has sought to publicise himself for political ends rather than for any ends that are in the interests of soccer.

PARA.TAB: Senator Carr says in his minority report—and I call it `his minority report' because I am quite sure that although Senator Wheelwright attended one hearing and Senator Reynolds attended a couple more, Senator Carr, who probably attended only four or five at the outside, and I may stand corrected—

TALK.START.PARA: —And not for long.
—And certainly not for long. He said:

PARA.TAB: The Opposition sought to sensationalise the inquiry in the media by encouraging witnesses to come forward and present unfounded allegations and malicious hearsay as evidence, resulting in further unnecessary public vilification of prominent Soccer people.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing could be further from the truth. At no stage did we encourage witnesses to come forward. They were invited by the committee to come forward only when they had put a submission in to this inquiry. So at no stage did we as individuals encourage people to come.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Carr had bothered to attend and keep an open mind, he might have been able to contribute something which would have been to the benefit of soccer. He sought only to sensationalise this inquiry. (Extension of time granted) If he had kept an open mind and if he had bothered to attend many of the meetings, perhaps we would have been able to talk some of these matters through. But Senator Carr did not even have the courtesy to attend any committee meetings when we were discussing the contents of the report. I would have thought, even if he disagreed with the report, certainly he could have come along and found some common areas of the report which he at least could have considered he agreed with. He refused to attend any meeting where we discussed the content of this report so that he could have any input into it.

That is not the way that Senate committees are meant to work. It seems to me that Senator Carr has a history of being on committees where he assumes the role of the wrecker, not the role of the supporter—a person who, at the end of the day, can come up with not only some concrete results which would help the final report but also, in this case, results that would be in the best interests of the people we were trying to help during this inquiry; that is, the Soccer Federation.

During the whole of that inquiry—although I missed a couple of hearings, I tried to attend as many as possible—I was generally pleased with the efforts that were put in by many people in the soccer fraternity to try to make sure that their game was improved and the administration of their game was improved and that, at the end of the day, everything that we did was in the best interests of soccer.

I have always been very keen on sport, although I have never been close to soccer, but my interest in this inquiry was to make sure that the thousands of Australians who play this sport can do so without fear or favour and in the knowledge that they have a sound administration and there is not a hint of corruption anywhere in that sport. I am not sure that I am properly convinced that that is the case, but I hope that this report will help the Soccer Federation in its efforts to try to ensure that soccer in Australia is in a far better state than it was prior to the commencement of the Stewart report. I thank the minister for allowing me that extra time to speak to the report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BANKING (QUEENSLAND INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The purpose of this Bill is to bring Queensland Industry Development Corporation (QIDC) under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: QIDC is a financial institution which is wholly owned by the Queensland Government and which undertakes commercial lending to primary, secondary and tertiary industry within the State of Queensland. While in recent years it has sought to adhere to Reserve Bank standards, QIDC has not been formally supervised by the Reserve Bank.

The Queensland Government has recently corporatised QIDC and as part of this exercise is seeking to enhance the accountability of QIDC by enabling it to be brought under Reserve Bank supervision. This Bill amends the Banking Act 1959 to bring QIDC under Reserve Bank prudential supervision. To this end, the Queensland Government has recently referred its banking powers, with respect to QIDC, to the Commonwealth. Specifically, this Bill includes QIDC within the definition of a bank in section 5 of the Banking Act 1959, thereby establishing a legislative basis for Reserve Bank supervision of QIDC. This will ensure that QIDC follows Reserve Bank requirements and is subject to the supervision of the Reserve Bank in relation to prudential matters.

The Commonwealth Government endorses Reserve Bank supervision of QIDC. As a substantial commercial lender, QIDC effectively operates as a business bank and its formal supervision by the Reserve Bank is entirely appropriate. Such supervision will help to ensure that QIDC remains financially sound and, accordingly, will help to underpin the security of the financial sector more generally.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains a more detailed explanation of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That—
(a)the Senate notes that the order tabled in the Senate on 11 May 1995, dated 2 May 1995, and made under subsection 6(1) of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974:

TAB.TAB: (i)entrenches the power of the action minister, who in most cases is not the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and who has neither the expert environmental advice available nor an unimpeded duty to protect the environment, and

(ii)increases very substantially the uncertainty of applicants because of the substantial increase in the discretionary power of the action minister, who will be a different minister in many cases and who suffers under the conditions outlined in paragraph (a)(i); and accordingly

PARA.TAB: (b)the order made under subsection 6(1) of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act tabled in the Senate on 11 May 1995 and dated 2 May 1995, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The new procedures which have been produced by this change are largely in response to the recent decision of the Federal Court in the Tasmanian Conservation Trust, substantially supported by my colleague Senator Bell, in the action against the Minister for Resources. In our view it was a gross over-reaction to the potential for further governmental liability in relation to woodchipping licences issued by that minister.

PARA.TAB: The new procedures, if adopted, will act to severely weaken the Commonwealth environmental impact assessment process. They will reduce—and I stress this—uniformity and certainty for both environmental groups and industry, reducing the overall effectiveness and integrity of Commonwealth environmental assessment to a lower standard than is found at present. The new procedures increase ministerial discretion, thereby allowing further discrimination within industry due to the triggering of the EIA process being potentially reliant on the political climate surrounding a proposed project.

Projects of a very similar nature may not be subject to the same costs and delays due to the high level of discretion involved. The new procedures decrease the integrity of the process for both industry and environmentalists by leaving many important decisions with ministers lacking expertise in this area—that is, lacking the expertise in the environmental area. The action minister can be just about any minister who has the initial responsibility for a particular proposal, and not the minister for the environment, who actually has the trained people who can make the assessments.

The changes are in conflict with the public review of the Commonwealth EIA process—CEPA, 1994—which was initiated in October 1993 and has sought extensive industry and environmental input. The new procedures do not take up the federal government's responsibilities towards national environmental protection or uniform encouragement of industry. New paragraph 1.2.1 states that the action minister must designate a proponent for an environmentally significant action or an action for which it is desirable to designate a proponent for other reasons, except as otherwise provided by these procedures. Part (b) of this paragraph increases the discretion of the action minister and, hence, certainty and accountability.

I stress most strongly to the opposition that this procedure which we are debating this afternoon, if allowed, increases the uncertainty and decreases the accountability and for that reason, we believe the opposition should be minded to support it. It does this by allowing him or her to introduce a development to the EIA process for purely political reasons. Similar projects may not be subject to similar environmental controls.

Paragraph 1.2.2 goes on to severely weaken paragraph 1.2.1 by stating that paragraph 1.2.1, except if initiated under 1.2.1 (b), will not operate if the action minister considers that any relevant environmental effect has been fully taken into account in giving effect to the procedures in relation to an earlier action, or a proponent has been designated in relation to another action in relation to which these procedures have been complied with, and the action minister considers that any relevant effect of the latter action, firstly, is an extension of the environmental effect of the latter action, secondly, is not of a nature significantly different from that of the effect of the earlier proposed action and, thirdly, does not significantly add to the effect of the earlier proposed action.

Later in this speech I will give examples of how grossly those provisions have been ignored in recent decisions. It also ensures that if any earlier proposed action had been permitted to be taken or commenced before the procedures are complied with, this fact will be fully taken into account in giving effect to these procedures. I will give examples of the gross misuse of that provision also.

If adopted, this section will operate to decrease the integrity of the process by reducing the professionalism and objectivity of decision making by leaving many important decisions with the minister responsible for the promotion of the development. The minister for resources has a responsibility to promote the use of resources; the minister for the environment has a responsibility to look after the environment. In this case we are talking about environmental protection legislation, which clearly should come under the minister for the environment, not the minister for resources. It puts the minister into a conflict of interest situation.

This section severely restricts what proposed actions may constitute an initiative for which a proponent may be designated and reduces the environmental expertise involved in decision making by leaving such decisions with the action minister. Again, I emphasise that the action minister is not the minister who has the staff, the equipment, the facilities, the knowledge and so on to make these important environmental decisions. The section also decreases the transparency as there is no requirement for the action minister to explain his or her reasoning in making a decision. This is particularly relevant in view of the Sackville decision, in which Sackville said, in specifically commenting upon that aspect, that such decisions about environmental significance are subjective.

This section increases uncertainty in industry about when the EIA process will be invoked and it decreases integrity by allowing developments which have already commenced to have that taken into account in decision making, thereby favouring such developments relative to actions which have not yet been started. In that case, one can have actions which are started when there has not been an EIS concluded; and these provisions allow those actions to continue, even though there has not been an EIS prepared.

Paragraph 1.2.3 defines `relevant environmental effect'. Depending on how this is interpreted, it may result in cumulative environmental effects being ignored, an area which the public review highlights as needing more attention, not less.

Paragraph 1.2.4 states that, where a proponent ought to have been designated, if the department of the action minister has failed to do so, it is to be taken to be the proponent who must notify the Environment Protection Agency of this. This paragraph has the potential to decrease the Environment Protection Agency's ability to access direct information about certain projects. It is clear that, taken together, the new procedures operate to severely undermine the objectives of the public review, that is, the review which has been going on since 1993.

The changes result in more decision making power lying with people of less environmental expertise, increased ministerial discretion, and less certainty of process. These changes are in conflict with the public review, which suggests the introduction of designated development lists. These lists would define proposals likely to raise environmentally significant issues of national or international importance by development type and/or receiving environment.

If a proposed development type were to occur on a designated development list, then it would automatically have to be referred to the environment minister. This system is used in New South Wales and has been seen to increase certainty, efficiency and transparency of process. I would interpolate here that that was introduced by a Liberal government in New South Wales, the Greiner government.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good government.

—Then follow suit, shadow minister, and support this disallowance. It is the preferred option of both industry and environment groups, and that comes out of the public review. The new procedures also avoid ensuring educated Commonwealth involvement in all matters of national or international environmental significance, suggested as desirable in the public review in accordance with the intergovernmental agreement on the environment.

PARA.TAB: These changes will be frustrating to environmentalists, but will also entrench inequality amongst industry due to outcomes potentially depending upon political motivations. The Commonwealth could better address concerns regarding which developments will be subject to the EIA process by giving threshold levels of change within designated development lists.

The changes to the definition of a proposed action are for clarification purposes following Mr Justice Sackville's discussion on this matter. The changes show that only Commonwealth actions may constitute proposed actions. However, the `environmentally significant action' definition shows that it is the environmental effects of a development which may occur as a result of a licence approval, et cetera, that are to be considered in making a decision. Such changes would be acceptable to the Democrats as they make the decision taken by the minister more transparent.

Under the new procedures, the minister for the environment may allow a proposed action to take place before assessment has occurred, even though he or she has determined that environmental assessment should take place. The introduction of the concept of assessment after the development has taken place makes a mockery of the EIA process. That comes from the Environmental Defender's Office in New South Wales.

This provision clearly reduces the integrity of Commonwealth EIA processes. This is especially so as, in making a decision, the environment minister must take into account any advice given by the action minister or relevant authority and may grant permission if it is in the public interest to do so. It makes the serious investigation of alternatives in a cost effective manner close to impossible. That the commencement of such a development must be taken into account in deciding whether further environmental assessment should occur further destroys the integrity and usefulness of the assessment system and increases inequality amongst developments which have started compared with those which have not.

New procedure 11.4 allows the action minister to request the environment minister to exempt a proposed Commonwealth action or a class of Commonwealth actions from all or any of the requirements of the procedures completely for a specified time or until the occurrence of a specified event. These changes are unacceptable as they further increase the opportunity for discrimination between proposed developments depending upon the political climate. Only motives which ensure accountability and certainty of process should be accepted.

Overall, it may be seen that these changes will result in a weakening of the Commonwealth EIA process. It is of particular concern that many more decisions are to be left with the action minister, who may be lacking in environmental expertise and/or will. As stated by the Environmental Defender's Office, the government's claim that this is being done to increase efficiency is not very strong, as it can hardly be considered onerous on the action minister to designate a proponent to the environment minister, who may then make the desired decisions from a position of know ledge.

The proposed changes do not support the ambitions of the public review in any way. The changes will result in increased discretion and uncertainty, decreased effectiveness of the Commonwealth EIA process, decreased integrity, decreased transparency, and decreased cost effectiveness, rather than the opposite.

The changes that will be proposed at the end of the public review process are those that should be supported, rather than these procedures, which represent a hurried attempt by the government to avoid problems with the improper renewal of woodchipping licences. These new procedures, if allowed, will lead to increased problems with the Commonwealth EIA process for both industry and environmentalists.
