The Commonwealth ought to be an expert on interpretations of the law which cannot be substantiated. For 20 years it has turned a blind eye to the obvious meaning of the words, adopting an interpretation which crippled the EIA at the Commonwealth level. The environment department has stood on the sidelines wringing its hands helplessly, saying, `We are powerless to intervene. The action minister has the responsibility for initiating the environmental assessment process.'

The Sackville decision delivered to the EPA the power to play a role. As soon as a new step was taken in relation to a proposal which could affect the environment to a significant extent, then the EPA was put in the driver's seat—where it should be. It did not matter that an EIS had been done in the past. It did not matter that the action minister did not consider a variation in the proposal to be significant. And it is not that minister's decision and that minister does not have the expertise to make the decision any way.

The point being made is that not all decisions will require referral. This is a big deal! While not all decisions will need to be referred because of the Sackville exception, most would. The ones which would not be referred would be because there has been an assessment process recently and the decision did not have the new quality of an initiative. The Sackville exception would cover the often-cited case of a coal export licence every month, which was used as an example to say that the administrative procedures were unworkable after Sackville. This is absolute nonsense.

Industry lobbied the government, saying that the sky was falling. Talk of an unsubstantiated interpretation of Sackville! The EPA went weak at the knees and has effectively handed the threshold determination of when a matter should be assessed back to the action minister. After 20 years—and I know this personally because I was a member of the ACF council back in 1974 when the then Labor government passed this legislation, and we worried even then about the fact that this legislation made the action minister not the minister for the environment—waiting for the ball on the wing, they passed the ball and did not like the pressure. They ran into touch. Why is the environment minister shying away from extending his own powers?

Sackville did leave the door open for exceptions. The scope of the exception is uncertain, but a reasonable analysis would conclude that, once a coal mine had been designated, for example, as a result of an export licence application, it would be some time before it needed to be designated again.

Annual referral is not excessive and there is a precedent for this arrangement. The Australian Heritage Commission Act requires that advice be sought each year in relation to many approvals. An annual referral to the EPA would enable the EPA to keep a matter under review and for the environment minister to decide, based on the matters listed in clause 3.1.2, if and when further assessment should be done. The burden on the action minister is negligible—one letter each year for matters affecting the environment to a significant extent.

The Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, has recently designated proponents in relation to 1995 and 1996 woodchip licences throughout the country. The EPA would need to update its information each year on these major projects. Some say this is an appropriate role for the EPA. The resources minister has already indicated the fashion in which such changes will be interpreted. In his reasons for not designating Harris Daishowa in relation to its woodchip licence application last year, he asserts that the additional logging—this is the example I referred to earlier—of 172,000 tonnes from Victoria, which has not been the subject of environment assessment, is not significant. What nonsense!This assertion may appear unreasonable to ordinary people, but it is quite a different matter to prove to a Federal Court judge that this conclusion was so unreasonable that it was not open to the minister to so conclude.

The decision as to whether the nature or extent of an environmental impact has changed lies with the action minister. This perpetuates the problem of the action minister not being the minister with the expertise to ascertain significance and not being the minister with an interest in ensuring that the action takes place. Woodchip licences around the country could be increased by 20 per cent each without designation. It would be a risky and expensive exercise for a conservation group to convince a court that the action minister was totally unreasonable in saying that a 20 per cent increase was not significant.

The giving of approval without the results of assessment has occurred on several occasions. For example, the Sawmillers Exports licence to export woodchips from the north coast of New South Wales was designated in 1990 and a final EIS was not produced until May 1994. During this period of four years, woodchips continued to be exported pursuant to annual licences.

Similarly, the Minister for Resources has designated Midway Forest Products in Victoria and, at the same time, granted a woodchip export licence. These ongoing projects are allowed to continue despite the action minister's earlier unlawful failure to designate until some intermediate assessment process takes place.

The proposed amendments have the effect of leaving the action minister with the power to make the crucial decision about when further environmental assessment may be appropriate. Post-Sackville, that power resided with the environment minister—where it should reside because there can be little argument about major projects affecting the environment resulting in a designation. The impact of an incremental change is harder to prove. If designation is required only when there has been a significant change in the project or the environmental impact, and that determination is made by the action minister, we are much worse off than post-Sackville. The amendments will have gone further than they need to have gone to address the alleged problems of proposals being designated too frequently, or there being uncertainty about when to designate.

The `ongoing project' exemption implicitly acknowledges that there are projects operating which ought to have been designated and which have not—in breach of the law. The ongoing project exemptions should be limited in time by a sunset clause. The EPA's threats that if these procedures are overturned, worse ones will be put in place by the government, make me wonder why we are participating in a Commonwealth EIA review.

What we have seen in relation to these proposed changes is blackmail by the government which is claiming that if we do not accept these changes the minister for the environment will have even worse changes imposed on him by his cabinet colleagues. That is blatant blackmail and is something which the Democrats will not accept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the motion moved by Senator Coulter relating to the disallowance of an order made under subsection 61 of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and which was tabled in the Senate on 11 May. I listened very carefully to Senator Coulter's speech. As usual, it was a thoughtful speech, certainly a long one but nonetheless thoughtful.
—Are you going to listen to mine, too?

—I cannot promise that. I listened carefully to the arguments that Senator Coulter put. There is great concern right across the spectrum. I have consulted with a number of groups and it seems to me that there is concern about what happened post-Gunns and how the issues that were raised in that case will be effectively addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I put the argument that this increases uncertainty. Senator Coulter is worried about the potential for increased politicisation of environmental decisions. I think that is a very real concern. He is concerned about the role of the action minister and that it decreases transparency. They were some of the arguments that Senator Coulter put.

PARA.TAB: There is a great need to restore certainty. There are often various routes for restoring certainty but, nonetheless, I think there is common ground in all parts of the chamber that it is important that all players in this arena know and understand the rules of the game as the rules can provide a basis for action which will lead to outcomes which are predictable. I agree with Senator Coulter on that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the big issues that we are facing in the environmental debate is the politicisation which has occurred across whole areas of the environment, areas in which the politicisation probably should not have gone so far. Of course people of goodwill will always differ. At the end of the day we must expect politics to play some role. But it has struck me as I have listened to the environmental debate and spoken to people that there is a very widespread concern about how often the politics of a decision overrides the science of a decision.

PARA.TAB: I think one example that Senator Coulter did not cite was the astonishing final decision made on export licences. An ALP senior member of parliament in Tasmania boasted that, because of his particular action, some of the coupes which may have been approved for licence were transferred out of that state into another state. Other people were concerned about the decisions which were made on the coupes in Western Australia.

I cannot think of anything which is more designed to weaken public confidence than the feeling that the government and ministers are playing politics with environmental decisions rather than making those decisions on the basis of scientific evidence. I thought that Senator Coulter raised a good point about that. It is a debate I think we should look at carefully to see how we can ensure that the processes by which the EISs are done provide a basis for confidence so that people can be assured that, when a decision is made, it is made on the basis of the best scientific environmental evidence available. That is important.

SPEECH.PARA: I think those views and the principles Senator Coulter outlined are shared by all people. The question is, as I have said, `How do we arrive at an appropriate determination?' Senator Faulkner, let us face it, had a very difficult decision to make; he had a difficult time over this issue. The proposal which is before us attempts to clarify the role of the action ministers in issuing export licences and makes it clear that an existing project does not require a new environmental impact study every time an export shipment is proposed. That is very important.

PARA.TAB: I think there was great uncertainty after the Gunns case. As I said, Senator Coulter expressed some concerns from his particular perspective. In many ways they are not dissimilar from the perspectives that are expressed on the other side of the spectrum from industry. There were concerns in that area that projects which had never been designated, in other words subject to an environmental impact assessment, may now require such an assessment and proposals which had previously been environmentally assessed could be held to require further assessment if they are of a significantly different nature.

I was interested that Senator Coulter felt that the role of Senator Faulkner as minister for the environment had been restricted. Other people have put the view to me that part of the problem is that his role has been expanded. There will be differing views on that, but it is interesting to speak to a variety of people.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the point, though, Senator. This is a minister who should have responsibility for the environment; that is the whole point.

—I take your point. I am just telling you the range of views which have come through to me. I have listened carefully to the debates. I have read carefully what Minister Faulkner has said. It is certainly our view that, having assessed all the arguments—we certainly do not believe this is the final debate on this matter; there are very real issues involved in how environmental impact statements will be progressed—there has been an effort essentially to restore the status quo; in others words, what was thought to have worked pre-Gunns.

PARA.TAB: To that extent it provides some certainty. I am aware of the arguments from both sides. The choice is never an easy one in these matters, but on the basis that it seems to me that the advice I have received is that there has been a deliberate effort to restore the certainty which existed prior to the Gunns case, we are not prepared to support your motion on this occasion, Senator Coulter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments to these administrative procedures made under section 6 of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 were tabled on 11 May. As a number of speakers have mentioned, these amendments were triggered by the decision of Mr Justice Sackville in the Federal Court in the Gunns case.

PARA.TAB: In that case the court examined aspects of the administrative procedures not previously subject to judicial scrutiny. Following the Gunns decision, the government received advice that the case had implications for all areas of government decision making. The court's decision meant that whenever the government considered granting, for example, an export licence for coal or for bauxite, the environmental consequences of that decision needed to be considered. This was the case regardless of whether the project had already undergone environmental impact assessment.

The Commonwealth government, of course, makes a very significant number of such decisions on a weekly basis. For example, some coalmines in effect require several export approvals in a single month. Under the previous procedures, as interpreted by the Federal Court, every export approval decision for those coalmines would need to be referred to the Environment Protection Agency for re-examination. Frankly, to allow such a situation to continue not only would create unnecessary delays, and certainly a significant level of uncertainty for industry, but also would, as a very important point, waste and distract resources away from the environmental assessment of new or changed projects.

In order to avoid this particular situation the government has amended the administrative procedures made under the Environment Protection Act. The amendments removed the need for operational activities to be referred to the Environment Protection Agency if there has already been an environmental assessment. Where projects requiring Commonwealth approvals have not previously been assessed, the government's responsibilities to assess that project remain. Where a project requiring Commonwealth approvals has been assessed but has undergone environmentally significant changes since that assessment, that project must be referred again to the Environment Protection Agency to ensure the altered environmental conditions are taken into account when the next Commonwealth approvals are given.

The amendments also provide me with the power to allow day-to-day decisions to be made for an existing project while that project undergoes assessment. I do note the concerns that Senator Coulter has outlined to the Senate during this debate and on previous occasions that, under the amendments, judgments on which projects should be referred to the Environment Protection Agency remain with industry or, if one likes, approvals ministers. Of course, they are termed `action ministers' in the procedures.

On this point I would draw the Senate's attention to the current review of the Environment Protection Act that is in fact being undertaken now by the EPA. Through that review the EPA has identified a range of issues which arise from the Commonwealth's current environmental impact assessment procedures. One such issue is the appropriate role of the environment minister in the determination of which projects should be environmentally assessed.

The review process has ensured that all stakeholders, including state governments, industry, community groups and environment groups, have had ample opportunity to put their own views on how the Commonwealth's assessment process can be approved. Given that this public review process is well under way, it would have been highly inappropriate for the government to have addressed the broader issues such as the role of the environment minister before the EPA reported on the consultations that have taken place with stakeholders.

The government, therefore, has elected to make these current amendments consistent with the current legislative framework. Let me state clearly that while these particular amendments are essential to allow important Australian industries to operate without delay or unwarranted uncertainty, and to ensure Commonwealth environmental assessment focuses on real environmental issues, nothing in these changes pre-empts the outcomes of the consultative review process that is currently under way.

It is through the review of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act that the issues raised by Senator Coulter should be pursued, not through the disallowance of these regulations. This issue really does represent a balanced government response which arises from what is frankly an unworkable situation that has resulted from the Gunns case.

These procedures are already enabling the Environment Protection Agency to work with state governments and industry to ensure the Commonwealth's environment responsibilities are being fully met, and being fully met with no unnecessary disruption to key Australian industries. I stress the words `unnecessary disruption' because that is what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what it is all about; avoiding disruption to industry.

—I thank Senator Chamarette for her support on this matter. Finally, it should be noted that the changes to the procedures will have no effect on decisions made by the government before the amendments came into effect on 5 May this year. It is for these reasons that I will be opposing the proposal before the Senate from Senator Coulter. I ask the Senate to support what I think is continued good management of these issues by the government and a very sensible approach to our environmental assessment procedures and processes in Australia.
—And the generous support of Senator Kemp.
—Before I sit down, I would like to acknowledge, as a result of Senator Cooney's interjection, that for once Senator Kemp has got it right.

—In supporting Senator Coulter in this debate, I would like to disagree with the very last thing that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) observed. He congratulated the shadow minister for getting it right. I cannot understand how that can possibly be a characterisation of the speech made by Senator Kemp in that he recognised the accuracy of that said by Senator Coulter and yet apparently turned his tail on it.

PARA.TAB: This order was provoked by the consequences of what is now known as the Gunns case, as determined by Justice Sackville. As Senator Coulter mentioned, I had some little part to play in that Gunns case—and happily so. It was made clear to me that the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) had not acted in accordance with the procedures that he was required to follow when granting an export licence to the company Gunns. History has shown that the community group, the Tasmanian Conservation Trust, was correct in its assessment that the minister had followed wrong procedures.

I believe it is crucial that community groups such as the Tasmanian Conservation Trust retain the opportunity to hold ministers to account and to challenge them in the courts of Australia. Because of this belief and because my colleague Senator Spindler adheres to that belief, we have established a woodchip licence fighting fund which has received very strong community support to enable community groups to continue to challenge ministerial actions where they have prima facie evidence that such actions were faulty. That fund is being used at the moment by three groups to challenge licences that have been granted.

Earlier we debated the need for the order that we have in front of us. I was assured that such an order would serve only to clarify the consequences of the EPIP Act so that all Australian exports would not be unintentionally frustrated. That sounded reasonable to me. If the order had just done that, it may have been supported. But that is not what it does. In fact, as Senator Coulter rightly pointed out, it has far greater consequences. It changes the environment impact assessment role in export licensing, and it reduces the capacity of the environment minister to discharge the duties required of the environment minister, which is to protect the environment.

If we accept this, we will be creating a situation which will provoke more controversy, more extreme reactions and more uncertainty for Australia's exporters. I think that is a matter which the minister for the environment asserted would not be the case. We will continue that uncertainty, which has provoked so much political polarisation in our past. The fact is that the government has baulked, it has panicked and it has introduced a proposal which will not resolve the controversies in Australia's forests.

I would like to raise other matters which deserve urgent attention and which are related to this issue. I remind the Senate that, for many years now, I have been pursuing the very poor level of compliance with forest management and timber harvesting practices. This is an area that I am greatly concerned about. I am greatly concerned that the minister for the environment seems to have little power to actively supervise licence conditions, and the Minister for Resources has little reason to supervise those conditions. As Senator Coulter has said, this order will change the balance even further. It will change the balance to favour more the action minister and will reduce even further the opportunity for the minister for the environment to pursue resource users who have not operated within the environmental requirements of licence conditions. It is that aspect of this change that concerns me almost as much as the constraint on the community's opportunity to initiate legal challenges to licences that have been granted.

I do not wish to pursue and take up the Senate's time any more rehearsing the arguments which have been so coherently and cogently presented by Senator Coulter, other than to express my own personal interest in this area. I cannot let pass the statement made by Senator Faulkner at the end of his contribution about the review process which is taking place. I really cannot understand why we have here today this very faulty piece of activity by the government which anticipates the outcome of the review process that the minister so carefully described.

I cannot see how he can stand there and say that this action does not pre-empt the outcome of the review. To say on the one hand that a review is taking place and on the other that this action should be endorsed before that review has been concluded is nonsense. How he can stand there and say that, I really cannot understand. The claim that this action does not pre-empt the outcome of the review cannot be supported, nor can we support the passing of this order. I support Senator Coulter's motion of disallowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) support the disallowance of the changes to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and the concerns outlined by Senator Coulter and Senator Bell regarding the Democrats' motion. These changes are a direct response to the protection of the environment being upheld in the Federal Court which found that the 1994 Gunns woodchip export licence had been approved illegally. According to the government, these changes are necessary to clear up uncertainty and to ensure that each and every shipment of coal and other minerals does not have to be assessed if the overall operation has already been assessed.

PARA.TAB: However, these changes do not provide certainty and go far beyond what is required to resolve these concerns. The role of the action minister is increased and that of the environment minister reduced. Overall, these changes work to the detriment of environmental protection and they pre-empt a review of the Commonwealth environment impact assessment which is currently under way.

It is clear that, although the government talks of coals and other minerals, the changes are clearly targeted at woodchip export licences. Having found that it has been acting unlawfully for 20 years, the government has resolved the issue by changing the law. This chamber has witnessed many repeated instances of this kind of action by the government. For example, when the application of migration law was found to be illegal by the courts, legislation was pushed through this parliament to make illegal conduct legal. It is a very objectionable procedure, and that is why it deserves the serious consideration that this debate gives. Regrettably, by the stance of the opposition and the intransigence of the government on this issue, it appears that these changes will go ahead.

The problems with the changes are multiple. The object of the EPIP Act is to ensure, to the greatest extent practicable, that `matters affecting the environment to a significant extent are fully examined and taken into account in and in relation to' a range of Commonwealth actions. It would appear that the changes will act to undermine that object in several ways.

Changes in section 4 of the amendments extend the powers of the action minister and weaken the assessment procedures by allowing new projects to be excluded from assessment. The term `fully examined' appears to be redefined to mean, in some instances, examination by a minister without the necessary expertise and with a primary interest in allowing the proposal to go ahead, to determine whether to refer an operation to the environment minister for assessment.

Under the previous regulations, the action minister decided whether a proposed project was likely to affect the environment to a significant extent. The minister for the environment then investigated the nature and extent of that impact and what action was required. Now the action minister is required to make specialised decisions on whether the impact on the environment is of a significantly different nature or significantly adds to the effect of the impact of a previously assessed operation. It is a bit like putting Dracula in charge of a blood bank.

There is now the potential for each incremental change not to be significant but for the overall effect to be as great as the initial action. The changes in this section would permit the Minister for Resources to do what he did in granting an export woodchip licence to Gunns. In this instance, the minister granted a woodchip licence to a new company for an additional amount of woodchips on the basis that this was covered by the 1985 Tasmanian woodchip environmental impact statement, even though the environmental impact of the required additional logging was not assessed in this EIS.

Changes in section 6 of the amendments legitimise a practice which has been occurring for some time—that is, allowing development to take place before environmental assessment. This is the case both for the extension of existing operations and for new proposals. The Sackville ruling was that the resources minister, as the action minister, failed to follow proper process when Gunns Ltd applied for a woodchip export licence. The resources minister did not consider, as required under the act, whether the proposed action affected or was likely to affect the environment to a significant extent; he decided that this impact had already been taken into account in an earlier environmental impact statement.

The effect of the Sackville decision is that, whenever a proposed action is likely to have a significant effect on the environment, it should be referred to the environment minister for assessment. It would seem to me that, if there is a significant environmental effect, the environment minister is the proper minister to assess this impact and determine what action should be taken. If the proposed action is part of an ongoing operation that has already been assessed, the environment minister is still the appropriate minister to monitor the effect of this subsequent action.

In the Gunns case, Justice Sackville found that the Gunns proposal for the production, transport and export of woodchips had not been previously proposed by Gunns or any other company. This means that the Gunns proposal was unrelated to earlier environmental assessments. The danger of these proposed amendments, which are being allowed, unfortunately, by the Senate's failure to disallow them, is that of an unqualified, less interested action minister not fully examining the environmental impact of proposals.

One of the major drawbacks to the current Commonwealth environment impact assessment is the lack of ongoing monitoring and evaluation of environmental impacts. Following the procedures as ruled by Justice Sackville would allow for this and for the primary assessment role to be taken by the appropriate minister—that is, the environment minister. However, this does not have to be an involved or complicated procedure. Not all referrals to the minister require the preparation of an environment impact statement or a public environment report. A letter to the environment minister is all that is required. The minister is then kept informed of operations affecting the environment. Should the impact be such that further assessment is required, then this should be done.

While Senator Faulkner was pointing out that it involved a much greater workload, the point we are making is that it will be a less risky process if the environment minister has it because he will have the best information to determine the level of assessment that is required. In a media release, Senator Faulkner stated that these amendments would not remove the need for a fresh assessment where there is an environmentally significant change in circumstances since the last assessment. He outlined the circumstances as possibly being an increase in the scale of operation, the introduction of new technology or a change in geographical location beyond what had previously been assessed. Another consideration is the length of time since the previous assessment.

However, these changes are not spelt out. If the action minister is to make the decision as to what is an environmentally significant change, then this needs to be clearly stated. The proposed new paragraph 1.2.2 should expressly outline the factors the action minister should consider. To ensure proper protection of the environment, section 6 of the amendments which allows permission to be given to perform ongoing operations before complying with the procedures needs to include a caveat to limit when this can occur. An operation should be allowed to continue only after it has been designated, if it has been properly assessed and the operations being carried out are limited solely to those approved under the assessment process.

In his media release announcing the changes, the environment minister said that the changes will not remove or weaken the opportunity for legal action in relation to previous environmental decisions. This is not the case. I know of at least one instance in which a case has not been proceeded with because of the changes, and probably there are and will be others. The one I know of is the Tasmanian Conservation Trust's challenge to the North Forest Products 1995 woodchip export licence.

It is a sad indictment on the federal environment minister that he has supported this whittling away of environment protection and what is clearly a move by his government to give primacy to development over protection of the environment. As Senator Faulkner pointed out—and he noticed my interjection—the major aim of allowing this regulation to go through is to avoid disruption to industry. It comes as no surprise to find that he finds himself in total agreement with the opposition and wants to congratulate Senator Kemp for supporting the government on this. It is worthy of condemnation that an environment minister should thus comply with a limiting and weakening of his own power, and, more than that, the actual responsibility that he holds within the community towards environmental protection.

In conclusion, these changes do not provide certainty. In giving the action minister even greater discretion in determining whether to assess, uncertainty is created—for industry, with the possibility of favoured treatment for political reasons; and for the community, which has a right to know that environmental protection is assured. The current environmental assessment procedures are far from perfect. However, these changes pre-empt a review that is currently being conducted and has been under way for some years now.

These changes should be disallowed, and the purported concerns they are said to resolve should be addressed as part of the review that is already in place. The Commonwealth environmental impact assessment is currently a sham. The government is to be condemned for its latest step backwards from its obligation to ensure the protection of the environment.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the impact of competition policy reform on a key area of concern to consumers, which is health and community services. There are very few savings to be made in most states in this area. Budgets have already been slashed, cut and trimmed year after year. Indeed, in most states, services have been pared back to the bone. They have endured cut after cut dressed up in various guises: efficiency premiums, productivity savings, enterprise agreements to reduce staff and—this is the latest one announced in this year's budget—changes to indexation arrangements.

PARA.TAB: This all means that less and less funding for services is available and that more and more stress is placed on fewer and fewer people who are employed to operate and provide these services. What fat there was has been well and truly cut away, exposing many people in need of services to long waits, or reduced or more expensive services. The message does not seem to be getting through to either the federal government or the state governments. They are all hell-bent on reducing expenditure so that they can go to the next election offering more tax cuts or promising that there will never be another tax increase. To them, selling apples and oranges or cars and lounge suites is similar to selling health services. I can assure them that it is not; it is very different.

As other countries have found out to their cost, markets or quasi-markets simply do not work in some areas. Unfortunately, we seem to be unable to learn from the mistakes of others. Even where competition does work to a limited extent, you end up sacrificing equity, quality or choice, or all three. You end up with access to services limited to the well-off or the very poor, and those officially described as such. Those who miss out particularly are the workers on low incomes—precisely those battlers about whom the government and the coalition profess to be so concerned.

The rules have to be different for these sorts of basic services. Governments these days are so dominated by their obsession with the bottom line that they will quite happily shift the provision of an essential service to whoever will take it on. They also think that they can get rid of the responsibility along with it. Someone else will be blamed when the wheels begin to fall off this brand new vision. All that matters now is price—service is cheap and gets cheaper. Forget about equity, standards and quality. I have to ask: where are the clauses in this bill that deal with any of these issues, that will guarantee that service quality will be maintained? They simply are not there.

I would like to look now at some specific examples of what is happening in Victoria. At the outset, everyone gives lip service to the idea of quality. Local councils—if we have any real local councils in Victoria these days—say that they are determined to maintain quality. When maternal and child health care services are put out to tender, we initially see a genuine effort to ensure that fully trained staff are still required; that those winning tenders are those offering a good service and are not for-profit bodies; that outreach programs, extra visits, preventative care, connecting services, and so on, continue to operate fully. But how long can they hold out?

If you talk to people working at ground level in these sorts of community services, they will tell you the same thing: with more and more government cuts, with government intervention insisting on cheaper and lower quality tenders, with the acceptance of these tenders, and with more financial pressure to cut costs even further, local councils will not be able to continue to deliver quality services. This is already happening. In Victoria, the state government funds only 40 to 50 per cent of services through the healthy futures program but one council reports that its staff spends 80 per cent of its time dealing with that very program. The pressure is now on to reduce that level of staff commitment to these services.

As services are being contracted out, skilled staff are being lost. It is cheaper to employ unskilled or partly skilled staff. Meanwhile, the incomes are being reduced for those employed in what are in many instances some of the lowest paid but most important jobs in the community. This is not about efficiency, productivity, choice or benefit to the consumers. This is about reducing the government's costs in the name of competition and to hell with the consequences.

On another front in Victoria, nurses' case loads are increasing substantially. The Victorian government rewards case loads of 180 birth notifications per nurse. One council area is just managing to make 140 birth notifications per nurse but the stresses are increasing enormously. That council's commissioners believe that 150 birth notifications per nurse is possible, but many other councils report that they are nowhere near those figures and that their nurses are already working to absolute maximum capacity and are showing early signs of burnout. How could that possibly be described as economically efficient? How will nurses possibly meet the targets that the government is setting? We have to recognise that the free market simply does not work. It certainly has not worked in other health and community services areas.

Another good example is pharmacy. Government and industry have combined to draw up an industry plan that restricts the location of businesses and reduces the number of outlets able to dispense medication. That came about because everyone was forced to acknowledge that letting the market operate unrestricted had resulted in increasing pressure on prices as costs increased because many businesses and operators were struggling to survive. There was an agreement to rationalise the number and distribution of pharmacies.

The agreement struck between the government and the industry has seen a 10 per cent reduction in the total number of pharmacies throughout Australia. In areas where too many pharmacies were operating—there were so many that most, if not all, were unprofitable—pharmacists have been paid to move out of the industry. Meanwhile, special support is available for rural and remote areas to ensure that services are maintained.

We are facing the same lesson in the area of child care. As we rely on market forces there is a clear maldistribution of centres, and this has occurred particularly following the extension of public subsidies to private centres. In many coastal Queensland cities and on the north coast of New South Wales there is a huge oversupply of child care places. There are centres half full and centres that have already gone bankrupt. Meanwhile, in Melbourne, when a parent has a job it is impossible in some areas to get access—even priority one access—to any child-care centre whatsoever. Indeed, people are being forced to leave the work force or not take up work options. That is how the free market in child care is operating. There may be some competition but it is hardly efficient and, in many areas, it is certainly not of any great benefit to consumers.

Here is a classic case of the need for government intervention—for government to sit down with industry, as it did with the pharmacies, and look at the best way to ensure that competition actually benefits consumers. If that means, as it did for the pharmacies, that some centres have to close down so that others can open, surely that is better than the current situation. There are many areas where competition should not be the overriding feature for the delivery of services. These are the areas where we, as a community, decide we have priorities over competition. We decide that we are putting access or equity considerations first. This goes across a range of areas—education, health, community support services.

We say that competition does not matter or is a secondary consideration because our first concern is to see that low income earners or people with disabilities, for example, get priority access to a particular service or that a particular service is shared out equally amongst all of us. That is what communities do. That is why we have governments. We have priorities beyond competition—priorities which we look to the government to uphold. If competition becomes the be-all and end-all, not only do consumers lose out but we also abrogate those community priorities and responsibilities. That is what is wrong with this bill. That is what is wrong with this ideology-driven approach to competition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, competition is generally a good thing but the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995 is not just about competition. It could end up being about creating another bureaucratic empire which will be unaccountable to the people and outside the control of the parliament. It could end up saddling businesses and family consumers with high utility charges.

PARA.TAB: For decades, especially since 1932, this Senate has scrutinised delegated legislation. We should never tolerate the elimination of parliamentary scrutiny through the creation of new bureaucratic structures. Only last Friday, at the National Conference on Microeconomic Reform and Federalism, the chairman of the Western Australian parliament's standing committee rightly attacked the creation of authorities and commissions, the edicts of which are beyond parliamentary scrutiny. This bill has no provisions for parliamentary scrutiny of access, pricing or dividend policies of semi-government bodies in control of billions of dollars worth of taxpayer funded infrastructure.

Professor Ted Kolsen of the University of Queensland has described the new competition policy as naive. He has criticised its failure to take account of what is called in the jargon `second best realities'. He has pointed out that open access regimes can lead to inefficiency and the imposition of user charges in excess of economically efficient and marginal cost pricing.

Huge changes are being proposed to the financing and charging of public utilities; yet the impact on rural and regional Australia—such as my own state of Tasmania—has not been studied. The bill does not lay down any guidelines regarding pricing principles for access to public utilities. Professor Kolsen and the Business Council of Australia have questioned the extent to which the interpretation of the access provisions will deter investment in facilities open to others on uncertain terms and conditions.

The government's own Economic Planning Advisory Commission on almost the last page of its interim report on infrastructure has acknowledged that there is a conflict between private property rights and the requirement that a private owner can be forced to make his infrastructure available to users. Its response has been that `only time will tell' whether the Competition Commission gets it right. This is simply not a satisfactory basis for any law, let alone this one.

The Commonwealth has increasingly raided public authorities for revenue: for example, forced dividends from selling off the Reserve Bank's foreign exchange reserves. It has reaped in hundreds of millions of dollars from Telecom in this budget. Users of infrastructure need protection against exploitation of natural monopolies by greedy treasurers. The bill should, at the very least, be amended so that in regard to Commonwealth statutory authorities and business enterprises parliament can disallow any dividend to the Commonwealth and thus ensure that parliament retains control of the purse. I will have potluck in that attempt, might I say, because both major parties will deny that.

The competition bill implies the pursuit of full cost recovery from the users of public utilities. The Prices Surveillance Authority in its submission to the review of national competition policy did not question full cost recovery from users; yet the PSA pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: prices charged by state authorities have increased much more rapidly than CPI. In the two years ending December 1992 selected state and local government charges (including water, gas and electricity charges) increased by 10 per cent—over eight times the increase of the CPI of 1.2%, excluding those charges.'

The PSA even suggested that `public authority prices are often too low rather than too high'. Now there is a warning of price increases to come! Yet infrastructure by its very nature often confers external benefits on non-users such as landholders and governments which gain increased value or taxes from the economic activities which infrastructure supports. The correct economic principle is that of `beneficiary pays', not `user pays'. Neither EPAC nor the Industry Commission have satisfactorily explained how these external benefits can be properly taken into account in determining when and where infrastructure should be created and at what cost it should be made available to users. For example, the Industry Commission argues for imposing user charges for water supply instead of land rates, but then it admitted:
Of course, commercial land prices would tend to rise if this tax on business users were eliminated.

In other words, the actual production of goods and services, as opposed to landholding, would gain nothing. Business and consumers would not gain: they would be subjected to new user charges and no reduction in rents. People in Sydney have already noticed the windfall enjoyed by owners of harbourside properties as municipal rates have been cut in half and replaced by a `user pays' garbage levy. They have noticed the slug to family costs.

PARA.TAB: Much has been made of the extra national income that can be gained from increased productivity and the shaking up of inefficient public utilities, but the $64 question is who is getting the gains. The Australian Automobile Association in January 1995 pointed out the massive increase in indirect taxation that is taking place in Australia under the guise of user charges. The association stated:

SPEECH.PARA: the commercialisation and privatisation of Government business enterprises such as communications, electricity, water and sewerage have been accompanied by State and Federal Treasuries transferring existing funded public assets to GBEs at replacement value and imposing spurious `dividend' requirements on Government business enterprises which in turn must be recovered by `user charges'.

The result has been a recent meteoric rise in indirect taxation in Australia disguised as user charges. This form of tax has increased by 650 per cent since 1987-88 from $400 million to $3 billion. Nor is it likely to decrease. South Australia has just doubled the value it puts on its electricity and water assets and announced that it is looking for a six per cent return on the doubled asset base.

PARA.TAB: The editorial in today's Australian Financial Review has questioned Victoria's electricity reform and points out that increased competition in the electricity industry may lead to rises in prices as public investment is wound back. Not only have businesses and families had to pay for spuriously valued assets—assets that they owned in the first place—but they have also been denied the lion's share of efficiency gains. In a media release of 26 July 1994 EPAC admitted that labour shedding has been important in increasing the productivity of government business enterprises. EPAC also admitted that many of the benefits of increased productivity have been passed on to governments in the form of increased dividends. In plain English, the Commonwealth has cut the states' share of income tax so that it can use the money on its spending programs to buy votes.

The states have retaliated by sacking workers from public utilities and dumping them on the dole queues, and the Commonwealth government then turns up to claim the credit for its so-called Working Nation initiatives in shuffling these people in and out of dole queues. Meanwhile, businesses and families pay twice over. Their utility bills are much the same as they were before, but they now have to pay more tax to support the unemployed. Meanwhile, the public utilities show spurious productivity gains by deferring necessary maintenance. It is a scheme of `off-balance-sheet' financing to arouse the admiration of the most sophisticated corporate financial adviser. It allows the government to claim credit while picking people's pockets on the sly.

I am all in favour of free and fair competition. I am all in favour of efficiency and productivity. But I am not so naive as to believe that this is all that is behind this bill. From the point of view of revenue greedy treasuries this bill is as much about setting the stage for `off-budget' revenue raising. Governments want to spend money buying votes so they turn every water and electricity bill into a tax. They sell off every asset they can find, from airports, to the Commonwealth Bank, to foreign exchange reserves, and now our airline, Qantas. When governments find out that they have no infrastructure left, or they need to invest more, they implement a compulsory superannuation levy to force workers to pump money into superannuation funds which will build or buy the airports, the electricity and the water infrastructure and what have you. The funds will be guaranteed full cost recovery and a guaranteed profit on their investment.

It all looks so good: productivity is up, efficiency is gained and infrastructure is being built without anybody seeing taxes up. The only problem is that like the more spectacular entrepreneurial plays of the 1980s it will all come unstuck. Workers will see superannuation levies as taxes. Workers will see that they are getting no benefits from productivity gains or, even worse, as in England, their water bills are rising. They will, of course, demand wage rises.

Businesses will see that their infrastructure costs are not falling as much as they should and that they are being charged more than marginal costs for their use of network infrastructure. They will look overseas and see countries which do not waste their tax money on mickey mouse spending schemes but which use it to provide cheap roads, power, water and communications. Businesses will invest and create jobs offshore.

I am also concerned about the lack of due process in considering this legislation. I point out that the report of the Committee of Inquiry into National Competition Policy has not even been ordered to be printed as a parliamentary paper. I point out the superficiality of the answers given to my questions on notice at Senate committees on these issues by the Treasury and the Department of Housing and Regional Development.

The Treasury has admitted that there are no criteria set out in this bill to establish pricing guidelines for access to declared essential infrastructure. The Treasury has admitted that there is no guarantee that business and consumers will get the benefit of economically-efficient, marginal cost pricing principles. Indeed, the Treasury has stated that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the intention is to achieve an outcome consistent with normal commercial practices which seek a return on fixed assets.

No wonder states are rushing to revalue their utility assets! The Treasury has glossed over the problem of natural monopoly and the fact that pricing above marginal cost is simply another form of indirect taxation. The Treasury has admitted that it has not undertaken an examination of the income redistribution effects of changes in charges for public utility services resulting from these reforms, and that is where I come in. I am concerned that they will adversely affect low-income workers and regional Australia, including my state of Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: The Treasury has not even denied that user charges in excess of marginal costs could not be rebated without breaching the GATT subsidy code. In other words, exporters would be better off with overt indirect taxation which could be rebated, instead of disguised indirect taxation through user charges which cannot be rebated. When all our competitors rebate their indirect taxes through VAT refund arrangements, it is more than a little silly for Australia to pursue infrastructure pricing policies which will hamstring exporters.

The Treasury has failed to answer questions on the impact of full cost recovery on rural and regional Australia and the implied bias towards excessive metropolitan urbanisation. That is very important. I asked this question, I think, of the Bureau of Immigration Research. I asked whether the bureau had done any study about the effect this would have on the increased urbanisation of Australia. But no; it had not even thought of it. The Treasury has not done it. What effect will that have on my state and on the outlying states of Australia? The Treasury does not explain how external benefits can be taken into account in funding infrastructure.

Finally, the whole scheme of access is designed to end up in the High Court if infrastructure suppliers are compelled to make infrastructure available at loss-generating marginal cost. The imposition of third party access on private owners of infrastructure could amount to a taking of property without just compensation, in which case the taxpayer will have to bear the cost. In other words, the taxpayer may end up having to pay for infrastructure which he or she does not even own. Before the parliament legislates to impose such a contingent liability on taxpayers, taxpayers are entitled to have some idea as to what the potential liability will be. If the taxpayer has to bear the cost of providing infrastructure, it is reasonable that the infrastructure be publicly owned and available to all.

Similarly, the Department of Housing and Regional Development has admitted that it has undertaken no research into the impact of taxes and user charges on regional Australia, urbanisation and international competitiveness. Nor has the department analysed the conceptual basis for measuring so-called cross-subsidies where non-users of infrastructure, such as land-holders, also benefit. To talk of removing cross-subsidies or community service obligations before one has even defined the measure of the cross-subsidy is quite premature.

I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard copies of my questions on notice to Treasury at the Economics Legislation Committee and its extraordinary responses. By that I mean extraordinarily vapid responses. I also seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard my questions on notice at the estimates hearings into the Department of Housing and Regional Development and the answers. They are contained in the volumes of those two committee Hansards, but I believe they should be incorporated in the Senate Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: ECONOMICS LEGISLATION COMMITTEE
COMPETITION POLICY REFORM BILL 1995

SPEECH.PARA: Questions to be put to Treasury (Senator Harradine)

PARA.EMPHASIS: 1.What, if any, criteria are set out in the Bill to establish pricing guidelines for access to declared essential infrastructure where a determination is made (see s44R)?

SPEECH.PARA: Part IIIA, Division 3 of the Trade Practices Act, as established by the Competition Policy Reform Bill, contains provisions relating to access to declared services. Section 44R provides that determinations on access made by the Commission may deal with any matter relating to access by the third party to the service. Accordingly, a declaration may specify the terms and conditions of the third party's access to the service. Section 44S deals with restrictions on access determinations, while section 44T lists matters the Committee must take into account when making determinations including the legitimate business interests of service providers, the costs of providing access, the public interest and the interests of all persons who have rights to use the service. The Commission may also take into account any other matters that it thinks are relevant.

Division 3 does not set out specific pricing guidelines for the Commission to follow when making determinations on access. This approach reflects the fact that there is no single economic pricing model which is applicable to any infrastructure facility in all circumstances. Accordingly, a negotiated outcome agreed between the provider and the third party is seen as being desirable—such that determinations can only be made if negotiations have failed. When making a determination the Commission will take the matters specified in section 44T into account on a case by case basis being guided by the appropriate pricing model in the circumstances. An appeal against Commission determinations will be to the Australian Competition Tribunal to guard against demonstrably inappropriate pricing decisions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2.Is it intended that access to essential infrastructure will be guided by marginal cost pricing principles or by full cost recovery through user charges?

SPEECH.PARA: See answer to question 1.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.If it is intended that access to essential infrastructure be governed by full cost recovery through user charges how does that improve the efficiency of the economy given that the Industry Commission has conceded at p180 of its 1992-93 Annual Report that public utility monopoly pricing above marginal cost "is simply another form of indirect taxation"?

SPEECH.PARA: See answer to question 1.

The access regime contained in Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act is relevant to certain services provided by both public and private facilities. The regime establishes two mechanisms for the provision of third party access:

.a process for declaration of services which provides a basis for negotiation of access on a commercial basis. This is backed up by provisions providing for compulsory arbitration if agreement cannot be reached by negotiation; and
.a procedure whereby service providers can offer undertakings which set out terms on which a provider will grant access to third parties.

In both circumstances, the intention is to achieve an outcome consistent with normal commercial practices, which seeks a return on fixed assets. The access regime will promote economic efficiency by encouraging competition in markets upstream or downstream from infrastructure facilities. Efficiency will also be encouraged through increased utilisation of infrastructure. Furthermore, these outcomes are not necessarily dependent upon short run marginal cost pricing of infrastructure. The quote from the Industry Commission 1992-93 Annual Report relates specifically to Government Business Enterprises operating in uncompetitive markets. In such markets there are limited pressures to operate efficiently and in some cases capital investments have not always been undertaken on a commercial basis.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 4.Given the view expressed by the Industry Commission at p185 of its 1992-93 Annual Report that public utility dividend payments to government are too low, is the Competition Commission under any statutory duty to consider the impact of higher charges for water and other necessities of life on households?

SPEECH.PARA: See answer to question 1 and 3.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will administer the Prices Surveillance Act. The Prices Surveillance Act (as amended by the Competition Policy Reform Bill) provides that the Commission, in exercising its powers and performing its functions under the Prices Surveillance Act, shall have particular regard to the need to discourage a person who is in a position substantially to influence a market for goods or services from taking advantage of that power in setting prices.

The Competition Principles Agreement provides that prices oversight of State and Territory Government business enterprises is primarily the responsibility of the State or Territory that owns the enterprise. In accordance with the principles, States and Territories will consider establishing independent sources of prices oversight advice where these do not exist. The principles, among other things, provide that the prime objective of independent prices oversight advice should be one of efficient resource allocation but with regard to any explicitly identified and defined community service obligations imposed on a business enterprise by the Government or legislature of the jurisdiction that owns the enterprise.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 5.What examination has Treasury undertaken of the income redistribution effects of higher charges for public utility services, for example the impact on families?

SPEECH.PARA: Analysis undertaken by the Industry Commission and other bodies suggests that, with the possible exception of water, utility prices will fall as a result of these reforms. These falls are unlikely to be uniform, however, across time, jurisdictions or users because of the local factors. Treasury has not undertaken an examination of the income redistribution effects of changes in charges for public utility services resulting from these reforms.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 6.If as the Industry Commission has acknowledged user charges in excess of marginal costs are taxes can these taxes be rebated for Australia's export industries such as mining and agriculture without breaching the GATT subsidy code? If they cannot be so rebated on a selective basis to exporters how does imposing such taxes improve Australia's current account deficit? Will the Competition Commission be charged with the duty of preventing such indirect taxation? If not why not?

SPEECH.PARA: See answers to questions 1, 3 and 4.

The authority for the Commission and the State Governments to raise revenue through taxation is provided under a number of sections of the Australian Constitution. As a matter of law, the definition of whether revenue raised by governments in Australia is, or is not taxation is therefore a matter for interpretation by the High Court. The High Court has previously defined taxation as, `. . . a compulsory exaction of money by a public authority for public purposes . . . and is not a payment for services rendered.' (Matthews v Chicory Marketing Board (Vic) (1938) 60 CLR 263, 176 and 190). Section 53 of the Constitution also distinguishes between taxation and `. . . imposition of fines or other pecuniary penalties or fees for services'. Because access charges will be set by reference to the service provided, it seems unlikely that they could be construed as a tax.

The ACCC will not have a role in oversighting indirect taxation. However, prices charged by certain public utilities may be subject to declaration under the Prices Surveillance Act, as is currently the case with Australia Post.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 7.If infrastructure is charged to users on a full cost recovery basis does that not amount to selectively heavier taxation of rural and regional Australia? Will the Competition Commission be charged with the duty of preventing such indirect taxation? If not why not? Is it rational to impose higher costs on living and producing in rural and regional areas of Australia at a time when concerns are being expressed about excessive metropolitan urbanisation?

SPEECH.PARA: See answer to questions 1, 4 and 6.

The issue of the identification and best means of funding community service obligations, including where these subsidise the cost of delivery of services in rural areas, is logically separate from access charging issues. Governments are seeking to achieve efficient delivery of both utility services and social policies expressed through community service obligations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 8.What economic theory supports a process of full cost recovery of infrastructure from users when there are external benefits for non-users, such as land holders, from infrastructure investment?

SPEECH.PARA: Economic theory suggests that, from a societal perspective, investment decisions can be distorted when external costs and benefits are not considered in an investment appraisal process. As such, the need for full cost recovery from infrastructure facilities needs to be considered on a case by case basis. External benefits, if any, can be taken account of by the Commission in making an access determination.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 9.What advice has been received in regard to the Constitutional validity of the imposition of an open access regime on private or State owners of infrastructure (see Clause 44ZZJ)? If infrastructure is required to be made available at economically efficient marginal costs, are losses imposed on infrastructure owners which may entitle them to seek compensation from the Commonwealth? If on the other hand, the need for compensation is avoided by allowing access to infrastructure only on a full cost recovery basis, is not economic efficiency damaged by charging more than marginal cost?

SPEECH.PARA: The access regime in the Competition Policy Reform Bill has been developed and drafted in accordance with legal advice provided by the Attorney-General's Department, and the Government is satisfied that it is valid under the Australian Constitution.

Subsection 51(xxxi) of the Constitution provides that where the Commonwealth Parliament makes laws with respect to acquisition, it must provide for `just terms' compensation. Accordingly, new section 44ZZJ was included in order to deal with any finding that an access determination results in an acquisition of property. It ensures that access legislation is valid by creating a liability to pay compensation. Provisions similar to section 44ZZJ appear in a number of Commonwealth Acts, and they are sufficient to fulfil the requirements of `just terms' in subsection 51(xxxi) of the Constitution (see Minister for Primary Industries and Energy v Davey (1994) 119 ALR 108).

Where the Commonwealth is found to have the primary liability for any compensation, the access determination can provide for the third party to reimburse the Commonwealth: this is required by new subsection 44S(4) in particular circumstances.
On efficiency issue see answers to prior questions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT
RURAL AND REGIONAL AFFAIRS AND TRANSPORT LEGISLATION COMMITTEE
HEARINGS OF ESTIMATES—QUESTIONS ON NOTICE
HOUSING AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT PORTFOLIO
SUBPROGRAM 2.1—REGIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine asked on 2 June 1995:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 1)What research has been undertaken within the portfolio to ascertain the spatial effects of indirect taxes such as fuel excise and sales tax which have a greater impact on producers and customers located away from metropolitan centres?

SPEECH.PARA: Response:
No research on this topic has been undertaken, but please refer to supplementary note.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2)What research has been undertaken within the portfolio to ascertain the spatial effects of income taxes upon producers and consumers in regional and rural Australia, bearing in mind that zone rebates do not compensate for disabilities of location such as potentially higher education costs for children?

SPEECH.PARA: Response:
No research on this topic has been undertaken, but please refer to supplementary note.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3)Given the thrust of Industry Commission recommendations, competition policy reform and Government budgetary demands is towards reduction or elimination of community service obligations in favour of full cost recovery by public utilities, what research has been undertaken on the impact of full cost recovery for public utilities and infrastructure on rural and regional Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: Response:
No research on this topic has been undertaken, but please refer to supplementary note.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 4)If, as the Industry Commission has admitted at page 180 of its 1992-93 Annual Report, public utility monopoly pricing above marginal cost "is simply another form of indirect taxation" how does a move to full cost recovery improve regional Australia's international competitiveness, especially since this form of taxation cannot be rebated for exporters without breaching the GATT subsidy code?

SPEECH.PARA: Response:
No research on this topic has been undertaken, but please refer to supplementary note.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 5)Has any research been done within the portfolio on the conceptual analysis of so-called cross subsidies in public utility pricing where external benefits to non-users, such as landholders, are present? To what extent is metropolitan Australia subsidised by the export performance of regional Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: Response:
No research on this topic has been undertaken, but please refer to supplementary note.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Supplementary comment on questions 1-5:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the short answer to all five questions is that to this point in time no research on these specific questions has been carried out, the Department is currently developing the capacity to handle such research. In the first instance, the data for answering such questions is not yet completely available. Although we have personal income and business income details, these are not sufficient and they are on a taxable income basis not gross, nor is information available on the prevailing tax incentives for attracting businesses to regional locations. Moreover, when the data does become available it has to be reconfigured into a usable format at the regional level. This is currently taking place within the Data Section of the Department. The Department is also commissioning ABS to review the regional expenditure of the Commonwealth which should improve the capacity to examine public expenditure flows.

To answer these questions satisfactorily also requires the development of a modelling capacity to use the data. The development of an in-house capacity to model such questions is currently taking place within the Economic Analysis Section. For example, a Regional Economic Modellers Reference Group has been convened to advise on which models should be used. It is expected they will give their recommendation in a few months time.

It is perhaps also worth noting that regions as defined by the program cover both urban and non-urban. Moreover, many factors combine to effect regional competitiveness and the program attempts to look at the question more broadly than simply what the cost structure of non-urban enterprises might be. Leadership, skills, market awareness, opportunities for value-adding, infrastructure, specific funding for projects and so on, comprise the package of measures and approaches advocated by the program. For example, through the provision of infrastructure funding this seeks to improve the cost structure of enterprises in regions.

Some may argue that the move to cost recovery will impact adversely on the cost structure of some enterprises within many non-urban regions, but on the other hand the removal of resource allocation distortions will improve the business environment and cost structure of others. This would occur as a result of microeconomic reform and outcomes would also depend upon the level of competition generated within a region. The net result will vary from region to region.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I invite honourable senators and interested persons to clearly read those documents. They will see that what I said is based on facts. Until senators and the community know the facts and are aware of them, we are being premature in debating this matter here and now.

PARA.TAB: To summarise what I have said: I simply wish to point out that the competition bill could end up saddling businesses and family consumers with higher utility charges. The competition bill has no provision for parliamentary scrutiny of access pricing or dividend policies of semi-government bodies in control of billions of dollars of taxpayer funded infrastructure. Huge changes are being proposed for the financing and charging of public utilities. My concern is that this is being done without any major studies being undertaken of the impact on rural or regional Australia, such as in my home state of Tasmania. Nor has the impact on families of the user pays principle been examined. The competition bill implies full cost recovery from users of public utilities.

I pointed out what the Prices Surveillance Authority has said about the pricing and who gets national income gain as a result of this reform. Let me point out, as I did earlier, that there has been an explosion in hidden taxation in Australia disguised as user charges. They have risen from $400 million in 1987-88 to $3 billion now.

Unless senators and the community have a chance to consider these questions and answers and the non-answers that I have been given by the relevant departments, this bill, I believe, cannot be successfully debated let alone passed into law. The first rule of competition policy should be caveat emptor—let the buyer beware. I suggest we get this shiny new car checked out before we part with our money. Sadly, the major parties have not checked for oil leaks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees and Senator Harradine, who spoke before me, sounded warnings about where this legislation can take us. It is proper to take account of the issues they have raised. As far as I can see, it has not been suggested that competition in its proper context is a bad thing. In other words, everybody seems to agree that competition, if confined to its proper place, is a good thing.

PARA.TAB: The other thing that should be stated in the context of Senator Harradine's statement that this matter has not been debated with full knowledge of what has and has not gone on beforehand is that his suggestion has some merit. One of the reasons why that is the case is that we are in a federal system, and this legislation evolves from an agreement made between the various governments in Australia. It is a problem that we are going to face again and again.
