TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, the point I was making earlier was that the federal system is a system that requires agreements between governments. The fact that you have to get agreements between governments makes the role played by parliament less than it would be if this legislation had to go through this parliament only and was concerned with this jurisdiction only.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, there has been debate on this issue, as has been proved by those who have gone before me and who will come after me. It is also clear that legislation like this, which is going to become more and more frequent, is largely determined by what state, territory and federal governments do. I do not have a great deal of difficulty with that as long as people keep in mind the ultimate purpose of government.

The ultimate purpose of government is to have a community which enables all its members to live in peace, freedom and security; properly fed, clothed and housed; well educated and provided with good facilities for the recreation of their mind and body; and with decent health care available to them. Government must ensure the integrity of society and its capacity to accommodate all within it fairly, having proper car for their well-being and dedicated to their happy future both short- and long-term. Government must employ all legitimate means, including social, cultural, economic, legal and environmental, to achieve its ultimate purpose. It should not allow the use of one or more of them to usurp the right role of others.

Competition does much for the good of the community. That has been stated again and again in the debate. In so far as it does, government must nurture it. It is most beneficial where it operates in its proper place among other forces. It seems to me that we have to bear in mind that competition is only one of a number of instruments that are available to governments and the community to produce a good society. If competition gets out of its proper place and starts to do the things that Senator Lees, Senator Harradine and others have suggested, then it ought to be brought back and put in its proper place.

Senator Lees and others have talked about community service obligations and certainly, at times, the force of that community service obligation should predominate over the force of competition where it is appropriate in terms of the sort of society we want and which I have described. If such things as water and electricity and gas, those essential provisions for a decent life, are not available, and competition is not making them available, other forces should come into play. Government should see to it that people are properly provided with those things. If government does not do that, government is not living up to its duty. That is not an argument against competition; that is an argument in favour of society and in favour of using a range of tools to get to the result that we want.

This legislation that we are dealing with at the moment—it has been criticised by Senator Harradine, and he repeated the criticism of others—must be read with all of this in mind. This legislation will work well if the competition it promotes is kept within the context of the range of tools that are needed to develop the sort of society Australia wants. Clearly, there are cases where competition must be put down and must be subjugated to other forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —You put horses down.

—Yes, that expression does remind me of horses, Senator Calvert. It is probably an apt phrase to use because there is no doubt that competition can get out of control, can gallop away, if the proper restraint is not applied to it. That is what we must be careful of.

PARA.TAB: I came across an example in this very building today, where competition forces and often its twin, market forces, have to be restrained. I do not want to go too deeply into this, because I have to get the full details. I do not know whether you know, Senator Calvert, but the nurses at the station in Parliament House are now in some difficulty. If you accept what they say—and I have at this stage an inclination to do so, although I am always subject to correction—in the interests of the money that is available to management, and no doubt in the light of the general thrust of what we are talking about today, they will have their wages reduced from 1 July without proper consultation. There was, as I understand it, an enterprise agreement, which may not be persisted with—not as a result of what they want, but as a result of what management wants.

Of course, that is a consideration that should be taken into account in the sorts of things we are talking about. People who are working should not be subject to a particular force that is let loose blindly, but there are other matters that should be taken into account, such as the need for people to have a proper wage, for people to be consulted on what they are going to be paid and for a true enterprise agreement to be broken only by consultation, and so on. These are the sorts of things that, if kept in mind and taken along with competition forces and with market forces, will make this legislation good legislation.

If it is not applied with the proper attitude, with the proper community interests kept in mind and with the proper tools used in addition to this particular tool, there can be trouble. But if it can bring good, together with these other things that I have spoken about, we will get somewhere. Competition, like all good things, may be loved too much, to paraphrase a famous judge, and may be embraced too closely. Good things must be taken in moderation, and I am sure that if we do that in this case this legislation will do much for the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is easy to forget the significance to the Commonwealth public sector of the legislative changes that the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995 proposes, particularly their significance to government business enterprises. The Industry Commission in its report estimated that about $4 billion of the $23 billion estimated savings would come from Commonwealth level GBE reforms, particularly to Telstra and, to a certain extent, to Australia Post and the airports.

PARA.TAB: An Associate Professor of Economics at James Cook University, Dr John Quiggin, points out that the commission has significantly overestimated the benefits which flow from Commonwealth GBEs under the new competition policy. He showed that the Industry Commission had mistakenly double counted the efficiency reforms already under way in Telstra, in Australia Post and in the airports. He writes that the Industry Commission makes very dubious assertions about potential benefits such as claiming that Australia can reach the productivity levels of Sweden, ignoring basic factors such as our very different geography and our different population densities.

The Industry Commission also assumes that the abolition of the existing duopoly in the larger telephony market will result in substantial price falls, when evidence from within Australia, from the United States of America, and from elsewhere overseas suggests that the impact on Telstra's dominance of the market—in the medium term at least—is unlikely to deliver the massive gains claimed by the Industry Commission.

On the subject of airports, the Industry Commission's analysis becomes even more difficult to accept when it assumes that all Australian airports can reach the capital productivity of Sydney airport. It is unfortunately very obvious to anyone monitoring the attitudes of both the government and the opposition to the leasing of Australia's major airports that no airport is likely ever to have anything near the same throughput as Sydney. The only one which may come anywhere near close in the medium to long term is Sydney West, if and when it is built and fully operational.

Despite all that, this Industry Commission report has been trumpeted as conclusive evidence of the benefits of competition policy and as the final word on whether these reforms are necessary at all. That is a great pity because the reform package has very significant ramifications at the federal level.

Trade Practices Commission Chairman, Mr Alan Fels, has described the new rules for access to essential communications facilities as `the most important amendment to the Trade Practices Act' in this bill, but the debate about this has been quite minimal. Shared use and interworking both fall within the scope of this legislation we are talking about today. Those two categories encompass, amongst other things, the situations where two or more pay TV services use the same infrastructure and the problems arising from the use of a publicly-switched network service.

The access to infrastructure services provisions in the bill provides for conciliation and arbitration of access disputes. That sounds fine in theory, and it is, but in practice it could prove very difficult to administer. For a start, the processes in the bill are not at all transparent. The users and consumers of a service are given minimal opportunity to influence decisions on whether a new operator should be allowed to access the service and on what conditions.

This could become a very serious problem where the would-be competitor wants access only to the profitable part of the service, leaving the existing operator to run the non-profitable bits. In more general terms, competition in a market does not necessarily translate to greater benefits for consumers or meet public interest concerns. It does not automatically meet non-economic objectives and community service obligations.

Access to facilities in the telecommunications field is vital for the provision of a diverse range of services and should promote diversity of ownership and control. The bill does not recognise diversity as a key objective; rather, the objective of the bill, the measurement of the benefit of competition, is primarily, of course, an economic one. Unless measures are put in place to ensure that access to distribution systems is not controlled by the few or that there are guaranteed rights of access for all, there will, in all probability, be no real diversity.

The bill will not achieve this end. By its very nature, and as Professor Fels concedes, it encourages agreements on access outside its provisions. This could mean that there is no scrutiny of whether the public interest is met in such arrangements. For these reasons, there is an urgent need for public comment and consultation before services are declared. The Democrats will be moving amendments to achieve that.

For the communications industry, the generic regulation provided by the Trade Practices Act will probably prove inadequate in dealing with the policy challenges thrown up by convergence, or the satisfaction of social policy objectives that are currently enshrined in the regulation of the communications industry.

The Communications Law Centre, in its submission to the Senate inquiry on this bill, argues that because of the special status of the communications industry, there is a need for some industry specific regulation within the competition policy framework. But the entire policy push implicit in this bill and the COAG agreements is towards less regulation rather than more. The centre is convinced that competition will not deliver on content and diversity matters in the converged telecommunications industry, particularly with the emergence of strategic alliances between existing players. Encouraging of diversity could mean mandating anti-competitive behaviour such as the United States practice of requiring cable television operators to allocate one-third of air time to local broadcasting stations to maintain their audience penetration and, therefore, their viability.

The Democrats believe that this package does not provide an adequate scheme for a transparent public interest driven access to an infrastructure services to services regime. We foresee serious problems in the future that the new ACCC will have insufficient power to police. We are concerned that the competition policy reform could lead to a lack of interest in the equally important need to regulate aspects of specific industries to achieve social policy objectives, particularly where such regulation could be perceived to be anti-competitive. In the vitally important communications industry, the Democrats need to be assured that the inadequate framework established by this bill will not be the beginning and the end of the policy push to provide a comprehensive, competitive, diverse and culturally constructive communications industry base which will be available to all on an equitable basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to various aspects of this debate on the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995. Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter, and just more recently Senator Harradine, have stressed the momentous nature of this piece of legislation. Senator Bourne has just reminded us that there are serious problems in particular areas. She spoke of the telecommunications industry and the inadequate framework that this legislation delivers in that area. Even though those serious problems have been mentioned and even though speakers such as Senator Harradine have stressed with great sincerity the importance of this legislation, I am certain, from listening to other contributions, that none of those contributions have been taken seriously because attached to this legislation is a great deal of dogma and a great deal of party political commitment without a lot of thought.

PARA.TAB: If those who have allowed their parties to be committed had actually taken any trouble to listen to those who would be most affected by this legislation, we might have heard a little more concern, such as has been expressed in some areas by the National Party. I have certainly heard Senator Boswell express concern about the implications that this might have for rural Australia. That concern may have been translated into a little more than the rhetoric that we hear coming from so many of the other contributions.

This bill is based on a wing and a prayer. It is a dogmatic belief that the positive aspects of the Competition Policy Reform Bill can be delivered without any downside. This is how it has been sold to the Australian people. I recall a figure of $1,364—not $1,365, not $1,000 or $1,500, but $1,364—mentioned as the dollar benefit that Australian citizens would enjoy per person as a result of the passage of this legislation. Anybody who can confidently introduce such a precise benefit as a result of such a complicated and comprehensive piece of legislation such as this is really shooting into the wind because that so-called benefit cannot be demonstrated. I defy anybody to come in here and quantify it with such accuracy and then stand by it.

The benefits of the bill are vague and I do not think they can stand the scrutiny of comparison with the downsides which definitely do exist. The same argument has been used to justify free trade and lower tariffs to the Australian people in terms of allegedly lower prices from higher competition. In the end, the big retailers have got most of the benefit in higher profit margins while we see the unintended consequences far too often. Hundred of thousands of workers in the textile, clothing and footwear, and car industries have lost their jobs.

I predict that competition policy will work out in a similar way. Consumers may get some benefit in terms of some lower prices but the big winners will be big businesses and the treasuries of state and federal governments, perhaps. The losers will be displaced public sector workers. We will lose quality of the delivery of many of our public services such as education. Residents of regional Australia will be losers in this area. The local government sector, to which has been paid far too little regard, will be another loser in the wash-up of what we have before us.

I want to look at the education sector. In his second reading speech the minister sought to claim that it was not the intention of the government that competition policy should relate to the core business of education. What is the core business of education? How far do you take that core business? Should schools be forced to contract out their resource needs? Should schools be required to lease their premises on a competitive basis? Should schools be forced to compete in the provision of extracurricular activities or non-core subjects? What are they—computer literacy or music? How far should schools be forced to go on sponsorship and user pays charges? None of these questions are properly addressed by this legislation and these are the questions that the people of Australia deserve to have answered before we allow this fait accompli to take effect.

One private sector submission to the current Industry Commission inquiry on contracting out argues that the core business should be limited to policy and service design and that all government services can be delivered by contractors even if the services are of a social nature and involve activities that are hard to specify in empirical terms. That is a possible interpretation of what is up for grabs under this bill. Imagine what radical reform of education such an approach can potentially open up, especially when you tie in the other elements of the Hilmer package, including requiring repeal of anti-competition regulations, even if they serve a social purpose and a requirement for competitive neutrality for non-core government business.

The push towards corporatisation and privatisation is an inevitable part of competition policy. Several states are already seeking to move the TAFE system towards a corporatised model, with full fees and full commercial considerations. Education quality, access to free education and community involvement become inferior to the pursuit of the dollar under such corporatised models. Then we have to ask ourselves: what is education all about? Is it about making a dollar or a service to the community and an obligation of government? We find those words very hard to find in proposals such as this.

In the process of corporatisation, jobs in the public sector will be lost. The Democrats are not opposed to the achievement of genuine efficiency in government, but this must not be at the cost of lower quality, fewer services, less universal access to a quality service and less accountability by the service provider to the public. None of this is guaranteed in this legislation.

This Labor government has ridden roughshod right over its own constituency by riding this competition policy. The Australian Education Union, the Community and Public Sector Union and the ACTU have all expressed extreme concern about the impact of this bill on their members. The job security of their members and the continuation of the services provided by their members are also matters that concern the unions I have mentioned. The government has ignored the concerns of those unions and the welfare lobby, the parents lobby, the consumer lobby, the local government sector and the environment movement. It has continued. That is why I mentioned this idea of dogma right at the beginning. I see government members who have a twinkle of concern but they are overwhelmed by this dogma and this inexorable push, ploughing on with reforms of dubious benefits and definite cost.

The regulation review process in particular has the potential to bring into question the maintenance of education standards. For many years in many states various groups have been trying to get around rules in the education area on teacher registration or examinations or curriculum or facilities, or whatever—trying to go for the lowest common denominator. Potentially, thanks to competition policy, such regulations, which have been the one protection of a child's right to education irrespective of the beliefs of the parents, should be struck down as anti-competitive.

The Democrats will be moving amendments later in the debate to make it quite clear that the delivery of education services is regarded not as a business activity but as an obligation of government and a right of Australians; and we will make sure that the education sector is, therefore, excluded from the operation of this bill.

The other sector I want to address is local government. The local government sector has been downgraded by this reform. The sector has not been adequately consulted, and the government should be ashamed of that fact. It is a fact that the local government sector has not been adequately consulted on the implementation of the competition reform agenda, as evidenced by the fact that the original bill did not even exclude the core services of local government from being divided up and forced on to a competitive neutrality basis.

The government has since partly corrected this oversight but has not gone anywhere near far enough. The current provisions in the act will leave local government open to possible litigation under the competitive conduct provisions while state governments performing identical tasks will not be open to such litigation. Local government is clearly seen as the poor third cousin. This could leave it open for an unscrupulous business to try to use the Trade Practices Act to argue that local government fees were excessive or anti-competitive. It could severely restrict the ability of local government to use its full range of powers to protect the considered interests of local communities.

Later, in the committee stage, I will be moving amendments to the bill, as requested by the Australian Local Government Association, to ensure that local government is treated exactly the same as state and federal agencies under this bill. It is an important part of our political system. It is about time we acknowledged that and acknowledged the effect of such propositions on it.

To allow the potential for local government services to be challenged, to be split up and to be opened up for competition would be to mandate the export of the incredibly anti-democratic Kennett local government reforms to all the Australian states. In Victoria we are now seeing the contracting out of local government taken to an extreme extent, with community services like the running of libraries and health and recreation services being put out to tender. Quality and the concept of community service are being sacrificed in the pursuit of the holy dollar.

Local government stands to pay a large part of the cost of implementing the Hilmer reforms, yet it has not been to date included in the sharing arrangements of the speculated dividend—I repeat: the `speculated' dividend—from the reforms. Competition policy could also involve higher costs for local government.

The water industry, for example, is one expected to be a major target of Hilmer-style reforms. This has the Australian Conservation Foundation very worried and concerned that it could lead to utilities trying to make money by selling as much water as possible while any conservation and education programs and regulations drop off as anti-competitive. Also, we are particularly concerned that the stopping of the supply of water, seen as a social need, could well proceed and people could have their water deliveries—

TALK.START.PARA: —They could have their water cut off.

—Senator Calvert, who has experience in local government, would understand the problems that can be caused by cutting off water from communities. Buy-local programs by local government could be regarded as anti-competitive.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.59 to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner suspension I mentioned that local government in Australia will continue to have problems with the proposals that are before us for a competition policy. In particular, I was making the point that the obligation to deliver water to communities throughout Australia has been previously met by local government bodies. That could well end up being a significant problem.

PARA.TAB: We have already seen some of the ramifications of privatising the water supply in the United Kingdom. Those in this chamber and others interested in the area who have been previously involved in local government would be horrified to learn that on some occasions the supply of water has been denied to people who cannot afford to pay for that water.

One of the obligations that local governments have met in Australia over many decades has been to take care of the health of their residents. A significant part of the health of the nation is ensured by a reliable supply of fresh, clean water. It would be one of the potential crimes of this Hilmer concept if that supply is denied because the user cannot pay.

Local governments, as many senators would be aware, for many years have been able, through many courses, to meet their obligations to supply water. One is that when the cash is not there to pay for the water rates, or even local government rates, there has been the capacity to make a charge against the property. They have continued to deliver the water, collect the rubbish and clear the sewage—and that charge is recouped when the property is sold. Those are the sorts of community service obligations which local governments have been able to deliver, by taking payment by methods that can be very difficult to come by when we look at the user pays and privatisation concepts.

Buy-local programs by local governments could be regarded as anti-competitive as could arrangements for preferred suppliers to councils or councils being preferred builders for state main roads departments. Such arrangements ensure the integrity of some local communities and make sure they can maintain a strategic capacity to build or repair, or meet many of the needs that a local community needs to retain to call itself a community.

I am sure senators from remote areas of Australia appreciate that when the threshold size of the community declines, those sorts of things are most important. Local government is waking up to what Hilmer means to this sector. We need to ensure that the negative impacts are minimised. I hope that in the committee stage, the government and the coalition will join with us to provide a fairer deal for local government by supporting the amendments we will move.

I want to foreshadow those amendments in a way. Senator Kernot received a letter from Mayor David Plumridge, the President of the Australian Local Government Association. He enclosed a copy of the letter that he addressed to Mr Costello, the shadow Treasurer for the coalition. With regard to the amendments that the Democrats intend to move, in the letter to the shadow Treasurer, Mr Plumridge wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: ALGA sought these amendments during the deliberations of the COAG Micro-Economic Working Group, of which we were a member, and at that time obtained the agreement of the States to negotiate both with the Commonwealth.
In the event, and without adequately explaining its reasons, the Commonwealth agreed to a partial exemption of licensing activities, but no protection at all from prosecution and pecuniary penalties.
Further in his letter Mayor Plumridge wrote:

We are . . . deeply concerned that those responsible for this legislation have confused Local Government, which is just that—government, with the trading authorities of the States. The correct comparison is with the central departments of the States. This is made clear in the definition of "local government body" in proposed section 2(D)(2) of the Act.
That is a very important clarification. It justifies the amendments that are being sought by the ALGA.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to quote from a letter that Senator Lees received from Ray Groom, the Premier of Tasmania. Mr Groom states:

SPEECH.PARA: All reforms under the NCP proposal will be required to go through a public interest test before being implemented. Furthermore the NCP will have sufficient flexibility to enable States and Territories to determine their own reform agenda. Any Tasmanian agenda will take into account community service obligations and other safeguards.
I intend to see that Premier Groom is reminded of that constantly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has almost concluded a long debate in the second reading stage on the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995. As the minister representing the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), it is for me to close the debate on behalf of the government so that the Senate can move to a consideration of this bill clause by clause. This has been a long debate, a number of senators have spoken in it, and it has taken considerable time for consideration of its general principles within the Senate.

PARA.TAB: This bill is quite significant. It is a major plank in the government's agenda for micro-economic reform. This bill is aimed at creating greater efficiency in the operation of the Australian economy, saving taxpayers money, creating new jobs and improving household savings. While there is contention as to the measures of savings, the numbers of jobs and the improvement in household savings, and whilst there might be some argument at the margins about how much, none of the serious commentators question that those savings will be significant and that they will be a major spurt in improving the efficiency of this economy. They will make it more globally competitive and, as a consequence, create a much better platform for Australian business to succeed in the world. They will become more competitive and thus be more effective at winning contracts, growing their Australian businesses, increasing more employment for Australians and contributing to the greater economic strength of this country.

I am one who has long held the view that the greatest and most complex difficulty in Australian politics is not the adversarial parliamentary system that we have, in which Labor and the coalition face one another for honours as to who will run the country as government, but rather the management of the Commonwealth-state relationship. We have governments with legitimate constitutional responsibilities at a state level, a Commonwealth government with its legitimate constitutional responsibilities and conflict between Commonwealth and state as to cooperation and a national view of things.

So strong is the basic premise for this legislation that the most vexed problem in Australian politics—the management of the Commonwealth-state relationship—is in good repair. We have a situation in which the Commonwealth and the states agree about the need for this legislation, and not only agree about it in principle but have gone a huge way down the road to putting the flesh around the bones of that agreement to make competition policy a real biting economic tool for improving the efficiency of the nation. That in itself says that the principles we are seeking to enshrine here have huge power right across the political spectrum—certainly, Labor-Liberal and National Party-Labor.

There have been criticisms of this legislation in this debate by the Australian Democrats and by the Greens, who have raised serious doubts that they hold as to whether this legislation in any form should go ahead. With any major social change of the sort that we are now talking about, there are of course critics. But the level of criticism that comes forward is criticism at the margin of the principles that we are involved with here.

The Industry Commission, in assessing the impact of this legislation—these reforms arising from the Hilmer report—estimates that, as a consequence of this legislation, national savings would be improved by $5.5 billion; 30,000 jobs would be created; it would lead to greater prosperity in the nation, pushing wages up by three per cent; and disposable income per household could rise by $1,500 per annum. They are the estimates of the Industry Commission. People criticise those estimates. No-one has been able to come forward with a better model of what they would be. But even if they are wrong and only half right, they are still, as I have said, significant changes.

If anyone wishes to try to oppose this bill and knock it off the agenda paper, they are saying to Australian industry—and their voices are quite clear—`We do not want a competitive economy and you will have to fight in Asia for your markets with one hand tied behind your back.'

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the waterfront? Have you got reform there?

—I am surprised that I am interjected upon. Let me complete the point. The interjection is really about the degree of reform, not the need for it. There are different views between the major parties about what constitutes the degree of reform and how best to manage reform. With the greatest of respect to you, Senator Panizza, there is no difference between the major parties about the need for it. We just do it better than you do and the community recognises that in the ballot box, and you resent that idea. Nonetheless, there is a congruence of perspective about end outcomes.

PARA.TAB: Let it just for this moment be recorded that, if you are opposing this bill, neutering this bill or trying to reject this bill, then you are saying clearly to Australian industry, `In the world competitive market, you have to fight with one arm tied behind your back.' I do not think any Australian wants to see that occur.

Opposition senators have recognised the fundamental importance of this bill—the substantial gains in prospect for the economy as a whole and the substantial gains in prospect for ordinary Australians. As I have said, that goes to more jobs, higher wages, lower inflation and an improved fiscal position for the governments in the states as well as for the Commonwealth. This bill has been subject to one of the most exhaustive public consultation processes ever. No-one can say that what lies before the Senate chamber tonight has not been through the mill at all levels of consultation in Australia.

A public inquiry that was conducted by the distinguished Professor Fred Hilmer—the report bears his name—lasted for over a year. There was the release for comment of the exposure draft of the bill and the intergovernmental agreements last September, which attracted over 70 submissions in all. There have been numerous individual approaches by interested parties to Commonwealth and state ministers. This issue has now been centre stage for comment and debate within the Australian polity for well over a year.

It is fair to say that the package now has widened community support because of the consultation. Every state and territory government, consumer groups and the business community broadly endorse and support the package.

Those who have opposed the bill have not been able to sustain their criticisms. That is an important point. There is an obligation of rigour. Certainly criticisms are welcomed, but criticisms are tested to see whether they can be sustained. In this case, they have not been, and they have failed the test of rigour. Basically, this reflects a lack of understanding about what the bill itself does do.

It also reflects baseless fears about what the bill might do. It does not attack, as has been suggested in this debate, our humanity, for example, or community service obligations, as has also been inferred and suggested. That is a matter that governments will decide individually, as they do now. So this bill does not seek to change those arrangements. It was for each of the state governments as well as this government to decide what the right balance of community service obligations might be and for the democratic process to inform their decision making.

Flowing from all this are those who would want the bill to do what it was never intended to do and what it is not appropriate that it do. That is an important consideration leading into the committee stage here. We cannot hang off this bill other pieces of legislation that are not appropriate to its purpose and to try to reconfigure this bill to make it do things that it was never intended to do. I suggest with the greatest respect to honourable senators who intend to move them that some of the amendments are of that character.

The bill cannot be used as a vehicle to promote, for example, environmental objectives above other objectives of the bill. The bill is not the appropriate vehicle for separate proposals that will be set in a broader policy context. The bill is not a vehicle in itself to promote the interests of, for example, small business. The bill is to ensure that there is genuine competition which creates an efficiency from which small business can benefit. It is not a small business policy piece of legislation in itself.

In short, this bill represents the result of wide consultation, unprecedented agreement between the Commonwealth and state governments and the prospect of delivering significant reforms to benefit customers, businesses and the Australian economy as a whole. With those words, I commend this bill to the Senate and wish it a speedy passage.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a second time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

These are basically technical amendments. Perhaps I could give a few words of explanation. At the meeting of Council of Australian Governments on 11 April 1995 the Australian governments agreed to implement a package of national competition reforms, consisting of the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995 and three inter-governmental agreements—the conduct code agreement, the competition principles agreement and the agreement to implement the national competition policy and related reforms—with a number of amendments to the bill.

PARA.TAB: These amendments were as follows: firstly, to insert a process in the national access regime for recognising effective state and territory access regimes; secondly, to clarify the operation of new sub-section 51(1) of the Trade Practices Act 1974 in relation to licences issued under legislation; thirdly, to withdraw part of the coverage of part IV of the principal act in the Australia Capital Territory and the Northern Territory in recognition of the participation of those territories in the cooperative scheme for applying the competitive conduct rules to all businesses within Australia; fourthly, to clarify the operation of new sub-section 155(7A) of the principal act which excludes state and territory cabinet material from the ambit of the compulsory information gathering powers in section 155 of the act; fifthly, to clarify the provisions of the principal act which exclude non-business activities of the crown from the coverage of the act; sixthly, to provide an exemption from the competitive conduct rules for local government licensing decisions and internal transactions; seventhly, to clarify the operations of new section 51AAA of the principal act; and eighthly, to make consequential amendments to the bill. Further, the amendments will also enable the Australian Competition Tribunal to appoint legal practitioners and enable the tribunal registrar to engage consultants to assist the tribunal with its review role under parts IIIA and IX of the principal act.
I appreciate that that is a somewhat technical explanation for the amendments I have moved. They are technical amendments. I do not know whether there is any opposition to them.

—I would be interested to know how these amendments came about. Did the government reconsider its legislation? What motivated the government to amend the legislation in this fashion? TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for that question. The question is: how did the amendments arise; who are the authors of them; and what was the process? That is how I understand the question. The answer is, essentially, that they arose in consultations leading up to the last COAG meeting that adopted the competition policy reforms. They were considered by the governments of the territories, the states and the Commonwealth at that meeting and were adopted by all those governments at that meeting. Therefore, they arise as amendments to this bill in order to give force to the agreement reached between the Commonwealth, states and territories; and, for the Commonwealth's part, to honour the agreement.

—What am I to understand from that? What implication is there in that statement by the minister? You are not saying, are you, that the Commonwealth parliament should not amend this legislation unless it gets the agreement of COAG? Is that what you are saying or not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess you are trying to define what I am saying by asking me to exclude what I am not saying. The agreement between the Commonwealth, the states and the territories is subject to the legislative procedures in each of the parliaments of the Commonwealth, states and territories. What is being put to the chamber, frankly and openly, is that it is a significant agreement that has been achieved. It is a rare thing for the Commonwealth, states and territories to agree in such explicit terms on a major item such as this, but they have. That, in the government's view and, I believe, in the view of other senators, carries with it a huge amount of force.

PARA.TAB: From our point of view, since we are a participating government in reaching that agreement with the states and territories, our obligation, squarely and honestly, is to present that for endorsement by the legislative chambers—the Senate and the House—enact it into law and to do so earnestly and conscientiously as party to an agreement. That is our obligation.

We believe these amendments, in their character and nature, are best described as broadly technical. They facilitate the operation of the bill. I hope that answers Senator Harradine's question. No, we are not saying that the Senate is pre-empted. Of course it is not. What is before the chamber has tremendous persuasive power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you may be advised of that, but I am advised by those who would be affected by this—that is, the Australian Local Government Association—that your amendments are just a little too sharp in that they do not include taxes, levies or fees for licences. They include the licences but not the taxes, levies or fees. I am advised of this in the full knowledge that the Local Government Association has attempted to point this out to the government and has had its requests ignored and is not convinced by the amendments that have been promoted by the government.

PARA.TAB: I have received correspondence from the Australian Local Government Association. I do not apologise for reading to the committee the content of the argument, because I think that if I do that at least it will make it plain and clear what it is that local government expects from this bill and how it has been disadvantaged, at least to the association's knowledge. In relation to clause 76 of the bill, the Australian Local Government Association refers to the proposed addition of the words `imposing or collecting taxes, levies or fees for licences' to the definition of activities exempt from part IV. The minister will note that that is precisely what is before us under Senator Kernot's name. The Local Government Association tells us:

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will place Local Government on the same footing as the States/Territories.

The amendments to Part IV of the TPA will open up all Local Government activities which could be construed as "business" to possible litigation under the competitive conduct provisions. However, the Act contains no definition of business.

The States/Territories considered it necessary to make it clear that activities associated with imposing taxes and levies and licensing are not to be considered "business" and the Commonwealth agreed. Hence the provisions of 2C(1)(a) and (b).
The advice from the Local Government Association to us reads further:

Local Government is in exactly the same position as States/Territories. Councils issue a wide range of licences (shops, advertising, use of public places, building and planning approvals etc) for which fees are charged.
Local Government also imposes and collects taxes or levies in its own right.

Past experience and ALGA's legal advice points strongly to the potential for aggrieved applicants for licences to use the new TPA to argue that the Council's behaviour was anti-competitive in that excessive costs or conditions were imposed or a licence was refused. Similar arguments might be applied to the imposition of local rates or levies (eg development contributions for open space).

I will add my own example to that—one which Senator Gibson may appreciate. It concerns a levy for the Hobart Central Heart Association. It fits into precisely that sort of definition. I continue with the advice I have received from the Australian Local Government Association, which reads:
Such litigation could be extremely costly, lead to unwarranted delays and frustrate proper government. No doubt the States were motivated by similar concerns.

If the current wording remains, it would appear to a potential litigant that the Parliament intended the granting etc of a licence by Local Government to be exempt, but not the charging of a fee for that licence. This is plainly untenable.

I think those words are quite clear, and I will continue with similarly clear objection with regard to the proposed protection of local government against prosecution and pecuniary penalties. The document reads:

Local Government is currently effectively exempt from the provisions of Part IV by virtue of the `Rockdale' case, which indicated that general-purpose Councils would rarely if ever be classed as financial or trading corporations. Hence Councils would not at present be liable to prosecution and pecuniary penalties under the TPA.
This protection is comparable to the shield of the Crown and reflects the fact that Councils are government entities, not business enterprises.
Councils are not equivalent to State authorities established primarily to undertake business activities. They are equivalent to central government departments.

The Australian Local Government Association therefore argued that the primarily governmental activities of councils should continue to be protected against prosecution and pecuniary penalties in the same way as the crown in right of a state or territory. We should note that the protection being granted to the crown does not include some business activities. The proposed amendment would not extend to identifiable local government business enterprises, as they are excluded from the definition of `local government body' in proposed section 2D(2). This is again directly comparable to the position in respect of states and territories. The advice concludes:

Councils should not be exposed to the potentially large costs involved in defending prosecutions and payment of fines. These would simply amount to a further tax on local communities and an unwarranted intergovernment payment. Other sanctions are available to ensure that Councils meet their obligations under the new legislation, including direct intervention by the State/Territory Governments. Local Government's competitive conduct will be ensured by rules adopted by the State/Territory Governments pursuant to the Competition Principles Agreement.

That concludes the advice. I find that perfectly plain and clear. I cannot see why what you are proposing should not include the definition at least of part (a) of the proposed amendment under Senator Kernot's name, because that was, of course, provoked directly by the advice that we received from the association.

PARA.TAB: Time and time again, senators from all sides of this chamber have appealed for closer democracy to be the norm—they have appealed, if you like, for democracy in Australia to be the order of the day. I think the principle of subsidiarity is very important—that is, power should reside with the smallest group capable of performing the functions for which the power is required. That would mean that those over whom the power is exercised would have greater and closer control over those who exercise the power. That is the principle of subsidiarity. I would have thought it was a logical principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great truth actually.

—Exactly. Senator Woodley said that it is a great truth so far as democracy and good governance is concerned. The further away the decision makers are from the people, the less likely they are to take any notice of the people. This is precisely the situation that will arise out of this legislation. As I indicated in my speech during the second reading debate, this parliament—let alone any of the state parliaments—has got no control over the issues of access, pricing and the like. In this bill, you are giving away this control to some sort of commission.

PARA.TAB: It is very interesting to know how these things are going to take off. I wish to refer the committee to an address made by Terry Slater, the Acting Chairperson of the National Food Authority, to the Federalism Research Centre National Conference on Micro-Economic Reform and Federalism on 22 June 1995, last Thursday. Page 4 of his address states:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Food Standards Council, (ie State, Territory and Commonwealth Health Ministers) was formalised within the new regulatory framework through a 1991 Commonwealth, State and Territory agreement, signed by heads of government.
That is a bit like this. It continues:

The primary functions of the Council are to consider, and if appropriate adopt, food standards recommended by the National Food Authority, and to provide general oversight of the food regulatory systems in Australia.
Council decisions are made on a majority basis with provision for out-of-session decisions which facilitates timely decision making.
That is a bit like what we are setting up here.

Quite detailed protocols have been developed for these out-of-session decisions which have allowed even quite contentious matters to be debated and resolved without the need for a Ministerial meeting.
It continues:

The two key points are that food standards are adopted by reference, that is without the usual parliamentary consideration, and without amendment, so that such standards are uniform across Australia. This, I think, is quite unique in Australia and is a model for producing uniform legislation within the framework of a truly national system.
It is unique because:
it sets up a system outside the usual parliamentary process for the development of national food laws

That is precisely what you are doing here. I digress a little from the amendment moved by Senator Bell, but what he and local government are saying is: `Before you hand all of these things over and we get into the situation where our right to manage on behalf of those who elected us is hived off under the TPA or under this legislation, at least listen to what we are saying.'

PARA.TAB: I support what Senator Bell and what the local government association have said. I also support—and I believe all in this parliament should support—the concept of the principle of subsidiarity, so that the fundamental decisions that are going to affect the economic livelihood and non-economic livelihood of people are not made by a group of individuals far beyond the reach of those going to be directly affected by those decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to back up the comments that have been made by both Senator Bell and Senator Harradine, but also to say that, if this kind of decision can be made by state and federal governments and imposed on local government, it is mostly because at this stage local government does not even crack a mention in our federal constitution. It seems to me that that is one of the best possible arguments that it is time that we looked at our constitution and looked at the relative powers of state, federal and local government, and let the people decide whether or not this current situation is tolerable. The more people learn about this kind of little grubby deal, the more you will get an uprising from the community saying, `No, it is time that was changed and we re-looked at the whole state, federal and local government power situation in Australia.'

—I want to also underline the principle which Senator Harradine has outlined for us because I believe it is a critical one. I do not know if this parliament knows, but in one of the perhaps most rarefied governances in the world, the European Union, the principle of subsidiarity, nevertheless, is enshrined in the constitution for that body because it recognises that, the more you move government away from people into the supranational bodies, the more important it is to enshrine and ensure that the people have some device or assurance that their wishes, their opinions and their concerns will be taken into account.

PARA.TAB: To underline that, I want to bring to the Senate the concerns of the community services sector represented to me only yesterday by the national body of the Uniting Church, which raised tremendous concerns about this and which said that not only is it local government that is being excluded but the whole community sector. A community sector, which I might add, has annual budgets in the billions of dollars if we take into account the churches and other community players in that sector.

We are removing further and further not only from local government, but also from local or community governance, the opportunity to be involved in decision making. The principle of subsidiarity is absolutely critical. I wish this parliament could understand what Senator Harradine has been saying, because it is not simply about legislation; it is really about the kind of humanity we want to have in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we commit this amendment under Senator Kernot's name to obscurity—
—History.
—Hansard, for posterity's sake.

—History. In the face of no perceived or heard objection from the major parties, I think that obscurity is perhaps where they would like it to go. I want to insist that the implications are recognised. The minister introduced this section of the debate by telling us that there was a weight that must be recognised behind the agreement that had been reached by the state governments and the federal government; and that this was being brought into this place for endorsement.

PARA.TAB: I am getting a little tired of executive government's actions, of COAGulation's actions and of some ministerial councils' actions being brought before us for endorsement—not for challenge, consideration, debate or amendment. I would like to ensure that the Australian people are aware of how far into the realms of sophistry the real debates have been taken. If we had debates in the 1950s and 1960s about faceless men governing Australia, surely we ought to look now at how far away from real debate we have gone.

The National Food Authority was mentioned by Senator Harradine. I recoil from my memories of that because that authority brought about the lowest common denominator in the levels of food authorities in Australia. I also recoil when I remember what happened during a debate, in which the minister in the chamber participated to some extent, about the National Registration Authority. The federal government had reached agreement with state governments about chemical residues and how things ought to be monitored. It was about agricultural and veterinary chemicals. It was all hunky-dory and we had to pass the legislation without amendment because, if we did not, it would all fall in a heap, state governments would demand that it all be taken back again—and this neat little deal could not possibly be challenged by this parliament.

I was sucked in; I believed that. Although there were some protestations from the Democrats, that legislation went through. Two years later we had to amend it because none of the state governments had come to the party. They had all worked out that it was a little suspect and that it did not need to be followed through. I am never convinced by these arguments that there is a weight behind the agreements reached by the Commonwealth government and state governments. Far too often we see examples of where the cosy deals suit the administration of government, but not the people of the states of Australia; and certainly not the other bodies that are affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stitched up by bureaucrats.

—You are right, Senator Harradine. Far too often, even ministers and elected members who are supposed to be putting the point of view of the people have been hoodwinked by deals which have been stitched up by the bureaucrats. I am reminded of a particularly famous example in Tasmania involving the Tasmanian Government Insurance Office, one of the few qangos that paid any sort of dividend to the Tasmanian people. Year after year, a couple of million dollars came back to the Tasmanian people. It was sold for peanuts to some foreign body and the Tasmanian population now pays through the nose for its insurance. Only last week we heard that teachers are not covered by workers compensation insurance or by any other insurance when travelling on school excursions.

PARA.TAB: What is the result? Do the people of Tasmania benefit? Do the kids of Tasmania benefit? Does the community of Tasmania benefit? No. Eventually there will be no school excursions or interschool competitions because the staff will not be able to take the personal risk of being involved in accidents. Where in those economic rationalist driven figures are those community activities recorded? Nowhere. The events do not happen. The community is the poorer, but it cannot be calculated. No-one ever wrote that one down. It just means that life is not so rich anymore. How do we measure that? We cannot. The economic rationalists have not invented an index for that one yet. I do not think they ever will because they do not have the nous to see what it is to be alive. It is just a question of graphs and numbers.

These issues may seem slightly irrelevant, but I see this as one final opportunity to put in an envelope and present to the minister exactly what is upsetting people about this cosy deal that has been arranged by some of the representatives of the Australian people but not all. Those who are concerned about this are starting to realise what qualities of life will be compromised by these theories. That is all they are; they are theories. The minister cannot demonstrate to me how the figure of $1,500 that he quoted to me as the benefit to each individual in Australia will arrive in my pocket. I am a person in Australia, and I will believe it when I see it. I make a bet with the minister: I think we will both be long dead before we get any of that money. I think it is a case of a figure being plucked out of the air, a figure which cannot be delivered and a promise which will be haunting those who endorsed this program for a long time to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support these amendments. We support the principal that Senator Harradine raised, as supported by Senator Woodley, of subsidiarity. I remind the Senate that tonight we are talking about the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the Trade Practices Act, which currently applies to 80 per cent of the economy, applying to the government sector. The agreements that have been entered into by each of the states and territories with the Commonwealth are that that should apply. While we are sympathetic to the points being raised by local government representatives, the facts are that local governments belong to the state governments, not to legislation from out of this parliament.
—What?

—They are established under legislation under state parliaments. If they want changes, they have to raise them with their state parliaments. It is not our role to push that. The coalition supports the agreements that have been reached between the state governments and the Commonwealth government about removing the shield of the crown through each layer of government. Therefore, we do not support the Democrat amendments in this case.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller
PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to explain why I did not proceed with my amendment No. 19 when the government was successful with its batch of amendments. In this case, its amendment No. 14 to clause 54 on page 27 omitted the proposed subsection 44H(5). I should read out that government amendment in order to explain what my amendment would do to it:

PARA.TAB: "(5) In deciding whether an access regime established by a State or Territory that is a party to the Competition Principles Agreement is an effective access regime, the Minister:

TAB.TAB: (a)must apply the relevant principles set out in that agreement; and
(b)must not consider any other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: My amendment No. 19 was seeking to add to the original government version the words `or in any other relevant intergovernmental agreement'. It could still apply here that the minister must apply the relevant principles set out in that agreement and in any other relevant intergovernmental agreement.

PARA.TAB: I know that this anticipates some debate that will involve some of the Greens (WA) amendments, but I want to make the point that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has repeatedly said that competition policy affects almost every action of government. It cuts across a wide range of other policy areas and conflicting policy agendas. That is why I think including the words `any other relevant intergovernmental agreement' is really important.

Take the example of water. Conservation movements raised with many of us the conflict that could arise in that competition principles might be used to override the COAG policy on water resources. On the one hand, there would be the imperative to unleash market power, which might override the equally important need to conserve and promote more efficient resource use. This amendment that I would have moved places the competition principles agreement on the same footing as all the other COAG agreements. I think they need to be reconciled and not unilaterally overridden by this agreement. That is an important principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —From what Senator Kernot has just said, one of our options has been knocked out. But we will give the government another chance a little later on to reconsider its approach to allowing a range of issues upon which decisions might be taken. That is extremely important and very dangerous to limit. In support of Senator Kernot, and knowing that this amendment is not now to be put, later on we will be giving both the government and the opposition another chance to look at how dangerous it might be to limit the options.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.After clause 13, page 6, insert the following clause:
Economic duress
"13A. Section 51AA of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (2) and inserting the following subsections:
`(2) A corporation must not, in trade or commerce, engage in conduct that is economic duress within the meaning of the unwritten law, from time to time, of the States and Territories.
`(3) Subsection (1) does not apply to conduct that is prohibited by section 51AB.'
`Note:The title to section 51AA is amended to be:

PARA.EMPHASIS: `Unconscionable conduct and economic duress within the meaning of the unwritten law of the States and Territories'.".

SPEECH.PARA: 2.After clause 13, page 6, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Actions for damages

SPEECH.PARA: "13B. Section 82 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `Part IV or V' and substituting `Part IV or IVA or V'.".
3.After clause 13, page 6, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Other orders

SPEECH.PARA: "13C. Section 87 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `Part IVA or V' from Subsection (1B) and substituting `Part IV or IVA or V'.".

These amendments do not directly affect the matters that are the subject of this particular bill but they certainly concern competition policy. They relate to unconscionable conduct, and I am seeking to move these amendments to those sections in the bill which deal with the Trade Practices Commission amendments. By and large, small business has not been able to access unconscionable conduct as a remedy because of the way in which the unconscionable conduct provisions are drafted in the Trade Practices Act. That has been a matter of contention for some considerable time.

PARA.TAB: We have heard the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, in this very chamber during the last 24 hours, say that he attended a conference where this matter was discussed and that he gave an undertaking to small business that the government would attend to this matter by amending the conditions of unconscionable conduct so that, at long last, small business could get a fair deal. After Senator Schacht provided that information, I challenged him, saying, `On that basis, Minister, you would be supporting my amendments.' He seemed rather reluctant to commit himself to that, saying that a lot more work needed to be done before he could agree. I would have thought that the issue is fairly clear: either small business has access to this remedy or it does not.

The first amendment I am moving adds a new subsection to Part IVA of the Trade Practices Act to provide that a corporation must not, in trade or commerce, engage in any conduct that amounts to economic duress within the meaning of the unwritten law of the states and territories. I am advised that that would do what the minister has suggested should be done. It is rather odd that the minister does not wish to take this opportunity to provide small business with that particular remedy.

The second amendment relates to clause 13B and it seeks to provide an action for damages under section 51AA. It is an amendment to rectify what appears to have been a legislative oversight when amendments were made to the Trade Practices Act in 1992. It amends section 82 so that a person who suffers loss or damage by virtue of Part IVA—unconscionable conduct—may also take action to recover the amount of loss or damage caused by the contravention of the act.

Presently, section 82 of the Trade Practices Act provides that if conduct contravening Part IV causes loss or damage, those persons affected may recover the amount of that loss or damage by taking action against the person or persons involved in the contravention if it is with reference to restrictive trade practices or consumer protection. I believe it should also be available for damage suffered as a result of unconscionable conduct and I would call on the government and the opposition to support that particular amendment.

The final amendment deals with Part IV and it seeks to insert into section 87(1B) a provision that allows representative actions to be taken on the basis that contraventions of Part IVA or Part V—that is consumer protection—have occurred and that damages would need to be obtained under that section. There would be many cases where individual consumers simply cannot afford to run actions on their own behalf. However, where many consumers are affected by unconscionable conduct or by contraventions of consumer protection legislation a representative action would provide justice for a lot of people. I believe that the government and the opposition—which has had my amendments now for quite a number of days—should support these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Greens will be supporting Senator Spindler's amendments 1 and 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting Senator Spindler's amendments. When I closed the debate on the second reading I said that there were a number of things that were foreshadowed as coming forward in the committee stage which, while virtuous in themselves, were not appropriate to add on to this bill. I have to say to Senator Spindler that his amendment, in the government's eyes, has great virtue but this is not the appropriate place for it.

PARA.TAB: I have a note here from my department which very briefly explains why I hold that view. First of all, it notes that the concept of economic duress enshrined in Senator Spindler's amendment is a favoured approach that the department holds in addressing small business concerns about the efficacy of the unconscionable conditions of the Trade Practices Act. This arises from a report prepared by a working party of the Small Business Forum.
I make it clear that, while ministers will respond to departmental advice, I see a great deal of merit in what they say in the advice offered to me now. It goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We have briefly examined the Democrat's proposal and, noting that there is no existing concept of economic duress within Australian common law, we believe it will not work. The provision as drafted is also technically flawed and potentially opens up legitimate business and business contracts to scrutiny of the courts.

With the greatest respect, the advice that I have before me is that, while the idea is correct, the drafting of the idea in the amendment before us opens more problems than it solves. The note goes on:

While the Democrat proposal is unlikely to be effective, there are sound legal and economic policy reasons for the government to utilise the concept of economic duress to address small business concerns about business to business conduct. However, because the regulation of business conduct can impact on the competitive pressures of a market, an imprecise provision prohibiting certain activity can have significant adverse economic impact. The department is working closely with a range of business groups representing both large and small business to ensure that any response to the small business working party report both addresses small business concerns and does not provide significant distortions to the competitive operation of the market.

I read that into the Hansard to show that there is a strong body of advice coming to us in government to go down this track, but to do it with greater precision and accuracy. Therefore, for those reasons I do not support your amendment.

PARA.TAB: I should also say that the report of the Small Business Forum that has focused on this issue is the subject of a working party and is being progressed. The government, in the context of responding to the working party report, is considering potential applicability of economic duress.

The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) said the other day that his strong determination is to press ahead in this area and bring in the proper amendments; that the government is currently consulting with a range of business groups on this issue; and that we should offer to consult with the Australian Democrats about that as we continue down this course and get their response to the working party outcomes so that there can be, if you like, an effective remedy in this area. What I am saying in short is not that we oppose the concept; rather, we are actively involved with the small business community in trying to find the best way of implementing the principle.

On a clear reading of what is before us now, firstly, it is not the appropriate way to amend the bill, in our view; and, secondly, the amendment as drafted does open up problems which we think ought not be opened up. With respect, it is not the most precise way of fixing this issue. It is for those reasons that we oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition, while sympathetic to the matters raised by Senator Spindler on behalf of the Australian Democrats, basically supports the position taken by the government with regard to the current situation. Therefore, we oppose the amendments.

—I thank the minister for his offer to consult on the amendments that the government will be preparing. It is rather a pity that the government, with obviously much more effective resources at its disposal, could not have brought back an improved amendment in answer to the wording that we had, seeing that the minister was at such great pains to suggest that the government is, in principle, supportive of what I am trying to do.

PARA.TAB: May I also comment on one other aspect of the answer that the minister provided, and that is the suggestion by the department that it may be an anti-competitive provision because it may restrict competitive behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never said that, Senator.

—If you translate that, what it means is that we must allow the big boys to bludgeon the little ones; we must not interfere; and we must not try to regulate the market to protect those people that do not have the capacity to protect themselves against unconscionable conduct.

PARA.TAB: Let the free market reign. Let the strong ones beat up the weak ones because, if we do not, that is anti-competitive behaviour. Let us have free competition reign for as long as it takes the government to give some thought to an amendment which currently fits on one page—it is about 20 lines—because the government cannot provide better wording than the Democrats can, with our meagre resources. That is a very good excuse, Minister, but it just does not wash. It means you are prepared to expose little people—small business people—to the vagaries of the market and to those that can strongarm them. You are not prepared to take any action when the opportunity is offered you.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the minister and Senator Gibson have said, there is certainly an emerging consensus in Australia, particularly among small business, that this is an area that needs policy action. All of us know, from sitting through question time, that Senator Schacht, who is the minister currently responsible for small business, has made it quite clear that the government is committed to achieving progress in this area.

PARA.TAB: I have had a look at this matter, as Senator Spindler knows, only briefly. That is not to say that these matters have not crossed my mind. I have had a long, enduring interest in small business, from the day I left school and entered small business to the day I came into this place. I know from personal experience that there is a significant problem area in Australia between the perceived benefits of big businesses and, particularly, small business who see that in many circumstances they do suffer some duress.

To be fair to the minister and the government—and it is not very often that we seek to defend them or even be fair to them—I think it would be fascinating to create either a quasi-judicial tribunal, such as the Trade Practices Commission or another body, or some other judicial body such as a court, to determine exactly what unconscionable conduct might be in relation to someone who has suffered loss or damage as a result of some form of price fixing, for example. The minister has informed us that the term `economic duress' is not an area where there is any body of either statutory law, as you would call it, or common law.

I am sure that if we were to appoint you, Senator Spindler, when you retired from this place, and a couple of other people to some body that was to determine what economic duress was in relation to a number of business transactions, and you, as a commissioner, tried to determine what economic duress was case by case in relation to small businesses, the lawyers who would appear before you would all do very well, but the small businesses concerned, and possibly the consumers concerned, may not be the winners. So I, having just looked at this matter, and based on my own experience in small business, would say that the answer the minister has provided, supported on behalf of the coalition by Senator Gibson, is a sensible one.

There is a multipartisan commitment in this chamber to addressing this area of policy, even though Senator Schacht keeps saying that we have no small business policy. I know this is an area of policy that our shadow minister and other ministers in finance related areas are looking at. It is an area that we think should be the subject of reform. It is a very genuine concern of the small business community and something that we take very seriously. But as the minister said, it is not the appropriate place or the appropriate time—and that sounds like Sir Humphrey talking. To almost omnibus this into the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995 here tonight is not the best way to handle policy in this area.

All I can say, on behalf of the coalition as the spokesman on small business in the Senate, is that we are committed to looking closely at how you address this. It has enormous ramifications in terms of existing state legislation for things like trading regulations, trading hours and a whole range of other business law areas that cannot simply be waved away with the magic Democrat wand with a page and a half of amendments tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am simply not convinced by the arguments. I believe this is an amendment that should be supported by both major parties. I welcome the commitment in principle, and I guess we will have to wait until the government is ready to move on this and bring its superior resources to bear on it.
—Whichever government it is.

—Whichever government, yes. Both parties claim to be extremely supportive of small business but, when it comes to effective measures to support small business, we find them wanting. I commend my amendments to the committee.

—I would like to support these amendments. I do not know how long ago it was, but I remember when I was on the ACTU executive and we were talking about restrictive trade practices legislation and the need for that sort of legislation to protect small business. In fact, certain governments took this up, and eventually the legislation came through. Looking back over those 20 years, I just wonder. I look around and see small businesses being ground into the dust. What has all this legislation done for small business? That is what I would like to know. Heaps of lawyers have made packets out of it. What has it all done?
—It is a good reason to oppose this amendment.
—No, it is not a good reason for opposing that amendment. That thought flashed through my mind immediately I had said that—
—The lawyers' fees.

—About the lawyers' fees—it is true. But in my view you have to have some provision which would efficiently and effectively deal with the strongarm tactics of the big fellows.
