They have enormous power with state governments and, indeed, with the Commonwealth government, obviously more so than small business does. In the states they appear to have enormous power when it comes to setting other frameworks for operation—for example, in the area of shop trading. It is the big fellows who have been pushing for 24-hour trading, seven days a week. How can the small family business compete in that sort of situation?

PARA.TAB: We are dealing with one part of the equation here. Even if we are dealing with one part of the equation, at least what Senator Spindler has proposed ought to be supported. I, too—as it looks at though this will bite the dust—will be very interested to hear what Senator Schacht is proposing. I have listened to his responses in question time in respect of small businesses. I hope small businesses can make more out of it than I can.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller
PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 2, proposed section 2, line 19, omit "consumer protection", substitute "protection of the consumer and the community".
13A.Government amendment No. 13, omit proposed paragraph 44G(3)(b), substitute the following paragraph:
"(b)must consider any other relevant agreement, for example, the Water Resources Policy of the Council of Australian Governments.".
13B.Government amendment No. 14, omit proposed paragraph 44H(5)(b), substitute the following paragraph:
"(b)must consider any other relevant agreement, for example, the Water Resources Policy of the Council of Australian Governments.".
13C.Government amendment No. 15, omit proposed paragraph 44MA(2)(b), substitute the following paragraph:
"(b)must consider any other relevant agreement, for example, the Water Resources Policy of the Council of Australian Governments.".
14.Clause 54, page 32, proposed subsection 44T(1), at the end add the following paragraph:
"(h)the value to customers of having a range or combination of goods and services offered at least cost.".

This group of amendments should be uncontentious. I cannot understand why any senator here would not support them. The amendments seek to include public and community protection as an object of the act. They seek to have existing agreements between federal and state governments acknowledged and considered. They seek to explicitly include the issue that some ways of providing services have significant contingent benefits.

PARA.TAB: As I noted in my speech on the second reading, this bill is actually an empty vehicle, a vehicle of considerable power to change the face of Australian society. Senator Harradine has mentioned the concerns about the level of control that has been donated by us to perhaps faceless bureaucrats in this manner. It changes relations between levels of government, but is empty of content just the same.

The act will have an objective. Clause 3 of this bill will insert the objective as section 2 of the principal act, the Trade Practices Act. It is this objective we are seeking to change with our amendment No. 1. The Trade Practices Act does not currently have an explicit objective. It is an act about trade practices. It is not a social agenda. We are turning it into a social agenda with an objective. We are creating a powerful and relatively autonomous body with a social reform objective and an unspecified agenda. It is crucial that in such a case we get the objective as near right as possible.

I note that the Democrats have also proposed to amend this with their amendment No. 4. I note that our two amendments are compatible and move the objective in a similar direction. The objective of this act proposed in this bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Act is to enhance the welfare of Australians through the promotion of competition and fair trading and provision for consumer protection.

This is an assumption that promotion of competition will enhance the welfare of Australians. Is this so? It was not the case in the United Kingdom. Worse than that assumption is the directive that the object of the act is to enhance welfare `through' competition and fair trading. Any other method of enhancing welfare—cooperation, regulation and so on—will not be considered. In fact, a major objective of this act is to deregulate, to take away all those provisions made by society, mainly for its protection.

PARA.TAB: Another major objective is to privatise, to get rid of those public endeavours to enhance public welfare to create pressure for efficiency through competition. Our amendment here is minor. It has to be since we are given nothing but an almost empty shell. We seek to change the definition of the object of the act. We seek to extend the object beyond competition by changing it to:

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Act is to enhance the welfare of Australians through the promotion of competition and fair trading and provision for protection of the consumer and the community.
It is ironic that often the consumer is used to promote such changes, a la free market. If you ask those people involved with consumer protection, you will find that they are the most concerned.

PARA.TAB: What we are proposing is not a big change, but it would give a bit of a different direction to the commission. The consumer protection part proposed by government seemed minimal, but it is the slight concession to community interests government seems willing to make. It is not enough. The consumer is only one of the parties that needs protection and consumer protection is liable to be interpreted as ensuring the lowest cost through dubious measures of economic efficiency.

In a specific economic sense, the consumer is also part of the market transaction. It is assumed that by allowing consumers choice they are protected and they will make free and unencumbered choice based on enlightened self-interest. Economics also notes what are called externalities. This is where the results of a market transaction affect parties outside the transaction and where the effects are negative. There will be no reason for those in the transaction to consider them.

An example of this is a bartender selling drinks to a customer. The bartender may decide that the customer is not drunk enough to cause a problem in the pub, so she or he sells the customer another drink. The customer is happy, but on the way home the customer runs over a child. The death is related to the sale of the drink, but is external to the transaction. It is an externality. In the same way, when a British coal fired power plant sells power to a town, the acid rain that kills rivers and lakes in Norway is an externality. It never enters into the transaction in Britain and people go on buying and selling as if Norway did not exist.

Consumer protection can also be seen in a narrow way in the health example. If the hospital is understaffed and has huge waiting times even though there are empty beds, the establishment of a private hospital protects the consumer. It is assumed that if people do not like waiting they can go to the private hospital. If they do not, they have made the free choice to wait. In all this economic language, the interest of the public—the fact that people may not have that much money and the fact that there may be community ethic—gets lost.

The community ethic may say that we should have decent health available to all without excessive waiting times. That will be lost in competition policy. The interest of the non-consumers who feel the impact of consumption—the externalities—will also be lost. The interests that would be otherwise lost under the proposed definition need to be considered. Our amendment says that the commission must consider and protect the community not just the consumer. This is the least we should include in an objective for this legislation.

Amendment No. 13 seeks to ensure that all the hard work—work done in the public sector in developing flexible, responsible and responsive community service provision—is not simply thrown away. It will protect and have the commission recognise agreements made expressly in the interests of the public between federal, state and local government. It recognises agreements made over many years with a wealth of experience.

Competition is not only the objective of this act but it also becomes the underlying objective of society with all other agreements assessed in the light of their potential competition impact. All other values become subject to the supreme value of competition. This is not acceptable. Agreements like the water resources policy were made for explicit goals outside the formal economic framework and outside considerations of competition.

But there are strong reasons for such an agreement and that is why the federal and state governments all agreed to the establishment of the Council of Australian Governments. There are other similar agreements. Competition policy should not simply be allowed to plough over these agreements as if they were nothing, of secondary nature or of little consequence with no need for consideration.

The government put up amendments to extend the claim that competition policy is the only issue. In its own amendments—Nos 13, 14 and 15—the government sought to establish that the only criteria by which any party, minister, commission or council can make an agreement is by a competition principles agreement. None of them is allowed to consider wider impacts unless those concerns are included here or in the agreement. The pertinent section of the government amendments reads:
In deciding whether an access regime established by a State or Territory that is party to the Competition Principles Agreement is an effective access regime, the Council:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)must apply the relevant principles set out in that agreement; and
(b)must not consider any other matters.

These are indefensible amendments designed to exclude social and environmental considerations of existing agreements that might be in conflict with so-called pure competition. The very least that should occur is that they be changed to explicitly acknowledge and consider other inter-governmental agreements which may be made on a different basis.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook mentioned that we do not wish to have other agreements overriding competition. We have actually entrenched in legislation that if we do not make any changes to this the ability of competition policy to override those other areas that we believe are so important in society will be diminished.

The alternative amendment No. 13 standing in my name would actually pursue some other objectives by deleting the `must not consider' clause and replacing it with a directive to consider other agreements—at least consider them. This is not open slather for the community to claim; it is simple preservation of agreements existing by governments. It does not force people to make any decisions. It simply says that it is open for you to take other agreements into consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a sensible idea.

—Certainly. Amendment No. 14 standing in my name carries this process on. It extends the need to consider some very basic factors. It proposes to change subsection 44T in the services provision to say that in making a determination the commissioner must take into account the value to customers of having a range or combination of goods and services available at least cost. This will take into account simple things such as a post office where rural people can pay some of their bills and do banking. It is not a huge issue and should be able to be addressed. I would hope the Nationals would be particularly thoughtful on this since it will especially reflect concerns and issues in relation to rural people.
—They have not even voted.

—I have noticed that the Nationals have stayed out of the chamber. Perhaps that is a statement in itself. It would take in more complex issues, especially in conjunction with some of our definitions, such as the value of having watershed management addressed in integrated ways by water providers who would look at social needs instead of just bottom line figures and provide efficiency and conservation services as well as selling water. It would include the sorts of issues raised by the Institution of Engineers—that is, maintaining the body of cumulative information and expertise. These are the sorts of issues I hope our amendments could address.

PARA.TAB: I noticed that, in the Economics Legislation Committee report on this set of amendments, there was an acknowledgment that a lot of these issues needed to be addressed. But I have not seen any government amendments that actually do that. We have been told that these are serious and we ought to consider them, yet the government is still asking us to pass the bill without any real indication that it has done such a thing.

I do not think we are suggesting outrageous extensions that seriously violate the essence of the bill. They simply assure some basic issues—that all senators should recognise as important—that are included in the very sketchy directions we give to the bodies we are establishing. The institutions we are creating here today—the commission, council and tribunal—will be immensely powerful. Our amendments and those of the Democrats are attempts to ensure that it will be a force to benefit all members of Australian society, and not just line the pockets of a few fortunate people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will support Greens' amendments 13A to 13C, because they have the same effect as Democrat amendment 19 which I articulated before. We also think it is important that a range of other agreements be considered. That is just the simple principle.

PARA.TAB: In relation to amendment No. 1, I need to ask Senator Margetts exactly what she had in mind by including `community' in the way that she has. Did I miss something when I was out of the chamber? We will support amendment No. 14. We just need a bit of clarification on the addition of `community' to `consumer'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for her question. The reason for adding `consumer' to make it `protection of the consumer and the community' is that we are very concerned with the direction that this bill is going in—that is, it is looking only at price consumerism. I guess what we are trying to make explicit is that a consumer is a member of the community as well. People make consumer decisions for a whole range of reasons, not just bottom line price. `The protection of the consumer and the community' explicitly includes consumer and community. It cannot simply narrowly be construed as the protection of price mechanisms for the consumer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I see what you mean. But you are talking about protection of the community, and that sounds a bit like a law and order issue. I agree with what you are trying to achieve, but I wonder whether this is the most obvious way of doing it without making it complicated. The Democrats have a number of quite specific amendments which deal with ensuring that community issues, as distinct from the community, are addressed.

—I listened to what Senator Margetts said. She made some extremely valid and relevant points, which should be taken into consideration in respect of this whole area. I also agree with the example that was given in her amendment No. 13 about the water resources policy of the Council of Australian Governments. For example, will the privatised water utilities be required to observe those agreements if that agreement gets in the way of the application of the competition policies outlined in the legislation? Clearly, there is a conflict where presumably COAG in that particular instance is attempting to take account of community concerns rather than just simply the narrow area of consumer concerns.

PARA.TAB: I would have liked to have gone into some of the actual verbiage. I apologise that I have not focused on that. I have not focused on it, I must confess, because of the clear indication that the government and the opposition are at one in this matter and would knock it off in any event. But that is no excuse for my not having looked at it, and I apologise to Senator Margetts for not having done so. I have looked at it in only specific terms, but I know I agree with what she has said in general terms. One thing does occur to me, however: how suitable will the competition commission be in assisting these particular issues? Therein lies the problem we all have with this piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to give a piece of further information to Senator Kernot. In relation to consumer protection as opposed to protection of the consumer and the community, because it specifically relates to the Trade Practices Act I think Senator Kernot should have less difficulty in seeing it as being a law and order issue. Because the Trade Practices Act has been often interpreted or been used to interpret against community values, if at any stage the narrow definition of the act is being used to batter some community group over the head, I guess this qualification enables some ability for our finding, which is not specifically about trade practice and bottom line price.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 4, page 2, definition of "Competition Principles Agreement", at the end add the following words:
"and, for the purposes of this Act, subject to the following modifications:

PARA.TAB: "(a)clause 1, the following definitions are inserted:

SPEECH.PARA: `"efficient resource allocation" means the allocation of goods and services to their highest value end-use in ways which are consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable develop
ment, and in ways which do not cause a decline over time in the availability of, or utility derived from, those goods and services;
`"least cost" means the least total cost or loss, and includes:
(a)pecuniary costs including monetary payment, or loss or reduction of other actual or potential commercial options;

PARA.TAB: (b)other relevant resource costs;
(c)relevant non-pecuniary costs which, on reasonable grounds, are accepted as important in terms of the public interest;

(d)non-pecuniary costs or social costs such as loss of amenity, loss of the right to share in the existence of or benefits from the resources (including intergenerational rights and expectations), loss of social adhesion, or reduction of sustainability;
(e)loss of intangibles which, on reasonable grounds, are valued by the community; and

(f)loss of the ability of the community to establish, protect or pursue tangible and intangible values through cooperative or collective non-governmental means, or through local, State or Territory Governments;

SPEECH.PARA: `"public interest" or "public benefit" means the public right to expect the full range of relevant goods and services to be provided at least cost and in ways which are efficient, ecologically sustainable, equitable and consistent with community wants and needs;';

PARA.TAB: "(b)clause 2, subclause (3), after `In accordance with these principals', the following words are inserted:

SPEECH.PARA: `and the principles contained in other relevant agreements, for example the Water Resources Policy of the Council of Australian Governments,';

PARA.TAB: "(c)clause 2, paragraph (4)(b), after `efficient resource allocation' the following words are inserted `, the public benefit and ecological sustainability,';
"(d)clause 3, subclause (8), at the end the following words are added:

SPEECH.PARA: `Policy statements of competitive neutrality should not be inconsistent with other relevant agreements, for example the Water Resources Policy of the Council of Australian Governments.';

PARA.TAB: "(e)clause 4, subclause (3), omit `a review', substitute `a rigorous, public and independent review';
"(f)clause 4, paragraph (3)(a), after `commercial', insert `, social and environmental';
"(g)clause 4, paragraph (3)(b) is omitted and the following paragraph substituted:
`(b)the costs and benefits of separating potentially competitive elements of the public monopoly, and of all related structural issues;';
"(h)clause 4, subclause (3), at the end the following paragraphs are added:

SPEECH.PARA: "and(i)the regulatory system most appropriate for protecting the public interest and for ensuring ecological sustainability; and

TAB.TAB: (j)the continuing need for some goods and services of a public nature to be provided via a rate or levy, rather than via a pay-for-use system.".

PARA.TAB: "(i)clause 5, paragraph (1)(a) is omitted and the following paragraph substituted:

SPEECH.PARA: `(a)the advantages of the restriction to the community as a whole outweigh the disadvantages; and';

PARA.TAB: "(j)clause 5, paragraph (9)(b) is omitted and the following paragraph substituted:

SPEECH.PARA: `(b)identify the nature of the restriction on competition, including accounting, reporting and pricing practices;'.".
11.Clause 54, page 23, proposed subsection 44B(1), insert the following definitions:
` "least cost" means the least total cost or loss, and includes:

PARA.TAB: (a)pecuniary costs including monetary payment, or loss or reduction of other actual or potential commercial options;
(b)other relevant resource costs;
(c)relevant non-pecuniary costs which, on reasonable grounds, are accepted as important in terms of the public interest;

(d)non-pecuniary costs or social costs such as loss of amenity, loss of the right to share in the existence of or benefits from the resources (including intergenerational rights and expectations), loss of social adhesion, or reduction of sustainability;
(e)loss of intangibles which, on reasonable grounds, are valued by the community; and

(f)loss of the ability of the community to establish, protect or pursue tangible and intangible values through cooperative or collective non-governmental means, or through local, State or Territory Governments;

SPEECH.PARA: " `public interest' or `public benefit' means the public right to expect the full range of relevant goods and services to be provided at least cost and in ways which are efficient, ecologically sustainable, equitable and consistent with community wants and needs;".
12.Clause 54, page 23, proposed subsection 44B(1), definition of "service", after paragraph (c) insert the following paragraph:
"(d)services directed at improved efficiency of resource utilisation and disposal;".

I will be speaking to the more extensive amendments in amendment No. 2. They are definitions and some effective changes to be included mainly in the intergovernmental agreements. Amendment No. 11 puts some similar definitions in the principal act where it was necessary for other amendments. Amendment No. 12 makes a very short addition to the definition of `service' in this bill.

PARA.TAB: The competition policy, with its intergovernmental agreements, forms a basis for action unprecedented in Australian history. As we noted in relation to our last group of amendments, the commission, council and minister are being asked, not legislatively ordered, in compelling terms to consider in their deliberations the agreements in only the competition principles agreement. It is therefore these measures which give initial direction to the bodies which we are now establishing. The Greens (WA) believe that it is imperative we send some message embodying some indication that a narrow economic focus is not the basis we want for all future decisions to be made upon. We have attempted to embody some other consideration in the definitions included in the draft agreements.

Amendment No. 2 includes a definition of `efficient resource allocation'. In economic jargon, this often means that resources are available at the cheapest price or that they are available in the market, with the assumption that Adam Smith's famous invisible hand will automatically allocate resources efficiently as long as people can trade freely. This ignores the fact that choice is not the only factor at play. There are also necessity and market dominance. The analogy of a 17th century market where most people are effectively self-sufficient and trade in surplus goods is not a good analogy for today's economic sphere. Companies with more profit than many nations have gross domestic products can use their power to maximise return. People who must buy have choice available only at the prices offered.

There are alternative definitions. Some believe that efficient resource allocation means the most socially beneficial and most sustainable allocation of physically scarce resources. This judges efficiency in terms of outcome, in terms of net social benefit weighed against net social cost, including environmental costs.

The definition of this term is of particular concern in relation to plans to privatise utilities. We seek basic protection for the growing recognition that conservation and technical efficiency are often better methods of providing power, water and other necessities at least cost and with the least negative impact on the environment and society. It seeks to embody the fact that while private utilities can go broke, sell up and move away—and end up increasing charges due to poor management—the interests of the community are served best by providing a service that takes a long range perspective and recognises that it is society that pays the cost of mismanagement and loss of efficiency.

Utilities do not mind this kind of inefficiency, at least in the medium term, because they are in the business of selling power and water. It does not matter to them how much those things are used and inefficiency may increase sales. This is no longer an adequate approach and society has regulated to prevent exactly this kind of short-term, profit-centred gain to a few individuals in the unbridled competition that this is likely to lead to.

That is why competition was bridled in the first place. It is a horse, a vehicle to get us somewhere; but there must be controls to ensure we can direct it—and there must be some kind of direction provided by an agent other than a horse. If we want a sustainable, just community which provides for all of its members, there have to be clear goals and controls. Otherwise, how do we know when we have reached them?

The second definition that we have included is that of least cost. This might seem simple to some people but, obviously, it is lost on a lot of people, especially those in government. The definition is crucial, because one based purely on bottom-line figures will never take in the wider range of values and goals we have for society. We are creating a vehicle that will largely dictate the society we will have. It is a partisan organisation pursuing goals and objectives. We need to ensure that those objectives are those of the community and of ordinary people.

Those objectives are not always framed in dry, technical terms. They are often not capable of being framed in such terms but are able to be expressed and described; and we should be able to pursue them. The sense of least cost that we are defining explicitly considers long range costs and opportunity costs. Those costs which result from using resources one way instead of another are also considered. The cost to one industry of the actions of another is also considered. These are not normal market transactions but could be calculated on a balance sheet as costs to the community and to society; as costs to one sector of the economy due to actions of another.

Our definition of cost goes beyond economic costs and includes such costs as the depletion or degradation of resources. This is important. It includes non-pecuniary costs such as the loss of amenity, the loss of access to services, the loss of quality of life—and I mean quality rather than the level of consumption—and the cost to future generations. It means costs such as despair, emptiness and the feeling that life is getting worse and not better. It includes the cost to our children, the cost to our sense of the community and the cost of restrictions in the ability to pursue values, including through legislative or regulatory means.

The existence of regulations in law is not evidence of the meddling of politicians; it is evidence that people want to pursue their values. We are not suggesting that no decision should ever be made. We are suggesting that, if a body is set up to reduce and take apart regulations, to inhibit regulations, to inhibit the ability of the community and to pursue its interests—be they one price for all on electricity or whatever—it must consider all costs. We are saying that, if this body will review laws and regulations in the interests of society, it must take the interests of society into account. When the cost is considered, it must go beyond simple bottom-line figures and even more complex economic calculations and address the broad range of interests. All costs must be considered and judgments made on the basis of the best result in relation to these costs.

Finally, we define public interest or public benefit. This follows through with the other definitions and says that it is not up to the Industry Commission to say that the public will benefit from increased gross domestic product, even if the increase is gained by higher charges, reduced access, social upheaval or dislocation. It is ultimately up to the community to determine what it needs and wants. Amendments 2(b) and 2(d) extend into the agreement itself to embody the recognition of relevant agreements already made between governments, usually with a lot more public consultation than this measure. Agreements like the water resources policy reflect the wants and needs of the community and the public interest and should be recognised.

Amendment 2(c) seeks to provide explicit consideration of public and environmental effects of prices and changes to prices. It is important to extend this, since it is easy for economists to consider punitive benefits to the economy and attribute benefits to the community without considering the actual mechanisms or impacts of a change in price. For example, a reduction in business costs in power with a small increase for domestic consumers may be seen as negating the impact of large increases on rural users. There may be many social and environmental ramifications of such a decision.

Amendment 2(e) seeks to assure that the public has strong input into the process of breaking down public monopolies. Many have social functions well beyond the apparent economic ones, and the nature and importance of these must be identified. Amendment 2(f) seeks to extend the very limited perspective to include a far broader range of considerations. This is essential in many public monopolies that have functions which include environmental management. Amendment 2(g) replaces a subclause which demands that only the merits of privatisation and fragmentation of utilities be considered. We believe it is more appropriate to consider both benefits and costs.

Amendment 2(h) is an insertion of the two sections into requirements for a review of proposals to reform public monopolies. It seeks specifically to ensure consideration of sustainability and to assure that there will at least be consideration of the option of a flat charge rate or levy which means that all people have access to a service at the same cost. Amendment 2(i) tries to make explicit some of the issues consumers have about practices which they feel result in higher prices for them. All in all, it seeks that people know and understand what they mean by these considerations. When we talk about such things as least cost, we seek to make sure that people understand that least cost can mean real least cost, not just least cost for some.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting the Greens (WA) amendments Nos 11 and 12. I need to ask the minister a question about amendment No. 2. Can we really be so anarchical as to rewrite these agreements? Is that up to us? Can we rewrite the agreements that have already been written?
—Are you referring to the COAG agreements?
—Yes. How tied is this parliament's hands because of their existence?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot may not have been here earlier when I had a similar question from Senator Harradine. His question was couched differently, but essentially the point was the same. I said in answer to his question that we have an agreement reached between all of the states and territories in Australia and the Commonwealth government, with the participation of local government organisations.

PARA.TAB: I stand here as a Commonwealth minister with the task of presenting that agreement to the parliament. Since I represent a government which has entered into this agreement, obviously I have to conscientiously uphold the terms of that agreement, albeit that some parts of it are a trade-off or a compromise and not perfect from our point of view. Nonetheless, as a job lot and as an agreement between the Commonwealth, state and territory governments, an appropriate thing for me to do is to support it.

Any agreement reached by government is subject to legislative approval; therefore, the chamber is free to move amendments and, if it can persuade the chamber and the other place, to adopt amendments. That is open, because the agreement is subject to legislative passage. I think that one of the toughest calls in Australian politics is getting federal, state and territory governments to agree. When they do agree, there is great force behind that agreement. What causes them to agree usually is a matter of great moment. That is the case here. Competition policy is a matter of considerable moment offering greater efficiencies to the community and greater competitiveness to Australian industry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —It reminds me so much of the WTO, the World Trade Organisation, debate we had here. Minister, I heard part of your second reading speech. I heard you accuse us of a lack of rigour and of being incorrect when we asserted that there had not been sufficient public consultation, and then you cited all the COAG meetings and a list of other meetings which you thought added up to wide public consultation.

PARA.TAB: I have a different view of how you start the process. You do not start the process by consulting after you have made all the decisions, which I think is what really did happen. However, we are here, we are debating it and we are being asked to ratify it. We have a great deal of sympathy with the points that have been made previously by Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine about the growing trend to go outside government. It is like the principle of getting things off the budget so you cannot adopt the level of scrutiny that you did in previous times. It is all terribly convenient, but it does a lot to weaken accountability processes.

With regard to amendment No. 1, we agree that there has to be very close attention to the implementation of the competition principles agreement. We have talked to the government about this. We have talked to the Greens about it. It may well be that we need to refer it to one of the standing committees to get that closer monitoring.

We strongly support Greens amendment No. 11. We have been saying for such a long time—I guess it will happen one day—that, when we talk about cost, we do not mean just the economic cost; we do mean the real cost, the social cost and the environmental cost. While I acknowledge that our systems are not set up to do that, they could be and we really do need to start moving in that direction.

I refer to the second part of that amendment. Consumer organisations have made the comment to us that it is not a good idea to codify what `public interest' means. They argue that there is too much case law and legal history which leads to a flow-on of benefits to consumers and which would be upset by this codification. Unless we can split parts one and two of the amendment, I would need to vote against it. But as it is going to be lost, we probably do not need to waste the time of the committee. I agree with you on amendment No. 12. It is really important that conservation elements of utilities continue to serve the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem here is that we will not really get another bite of this cherry. That is the reality of it. If that means it is anarchic, I am prepared to wear that title; so I would press these amendments.
—Are you going to divide on this?

—I do not know that in this case there is a concern about supporting some and not supporting the others. There is no necessity to divide. We know that concerns have not been met. Part of the way that this has been written and part of this whole process is necessitated by the rush to get this into legislative form, despite what the government has said. I gather from the words of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) that there are probably areas that the government was not happy about. Its making such a substantial change and leaving an area which, in my opinion, is substantially flawed will be the outcome of this. I am quite prepared to register the support of my colleague Senator Chamarette on this amendment and whichever amendments any other Democrat senators are prepared to put at this stage.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 32, page 14, paragraph (a), lines 34 and 35, omit " `Australian Competition and Consumer' ", substitute " `Australian Competition, Public Protection and Benefit' ".
4.Clause 32, page 15, paragraph (c), line 3, omit " `Australian Competition Tribunal' ", substitute " `Australian Public Protection and Benefit Tribunal' ".
5.Clause 33, page 15, line 19 and 20, omit the proposed heading to Part II, substitute the following heading:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "PART II—THE AUSTRALIAN COMPETITION, PUBLIC PROTECTION AND BENEFIT COMMISSION".

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Clause 34, page 15, omit proposed subsection 6A(1), substitute:
"(1) The Australian Competition, Public Protection and Benefit Commission is established by this section.".
7.Clause 50, page 18, line 14, omit the proposed heading to Part IIA, substitute the following heading:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "PART IIA—THE NATIONAL COMPETITION, PUBLIC PROTECTION AND BENEFIT COUNCIL".

SPEECH.PARA: 8.Clause 50, page 18, line 16, omit proposed section 29A, substitute the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Establishment of Council

SPEECH.PARA: "29A. The National Competition, Public Protection and Benefit Council is established by this section.".
9.Clause 51, page 22, line 16, omit the proposed heading to Part III, substitute the following heading:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "PART III—THE AUSTRALIAN PUBLIC PROTECTION AND BENEFIT TRIBUNAL".

SPEECH.PARA: 10.Clause 52, page 22, proposed subsection 30(1), line 22, omit "Australian Competition Tribunal", substitute "Australian Public Protection and Benefit Tribunal".

These amendments relate to the name of the various bodies. I am sure that the government will be rapt in this. Names are a mantra; we hear them over and over and they infuse our psyche, especially a name like `Competition Commission'. Obviously the goal is competition; there is nothing about the public interest. With such a concentration of power, it is worth looking at purpose. We have this wonderful Competition Commission, National Competition Council and Competition Tribunal. We are suggesting that the names should be changed to incorporate some idea that there are other objectives.

PARA.TAB: In amendments 3, 5 and 6, we are suggesting that the name of the commission should be changed from `Australian Competition and Consumer' to the `Australian Competition, Public Protection and Benefit Commission'. In amendments 3, 7 and 8, we are suggesting that the name of the National Competition Council should change to the National Competition, Public Protection and Benefit Council. In amendments 4, 9 and 10, we are suggesting that the name of the Australian Competition Tribunal should be changed to the Australian Public Protection and Benefit Tribunal. Somehow we are hoping—I do not know whether it is a faint hope—that by including the words `public protection and benefit' in the names of these organisations, something will rub off.

We are coming to the end of our amendments. We will support the Democrats' amendments, as we supported Senator Spindler's. We will all seek to extend and direct consideration to the public good. I feel that there is a good balance here. We have both looked at different areas. Our approaches obviously work well together. It must be a case of the strength of diversity in pursuing common concerns. I know that this is flag flying and wishful thinking, but I am putting them anyway.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I pose this observation: would it not be awful if these passed, the government's bill remained intact and we had a totally Orwellian situation where they mean exactly the opposite of what is intended.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Against my better judgment, Robespierre's body was called the Commission for Public Protection. It sounds an awful lot like this. This does say `consumer' and `competition'.

—There were three people on that committee for public safety. I do not know that any of them ended up too well, to be quite frank. I certainly hope that the person in charge of this is not stabbed in the back in his bath anyhow. I do not reflect on anybody past, present or future in that respect.

PARA.TAB: I think the bureaucrats have devised this in such a way that it has been presented as a fait accompli to the responsible ministers. As I said in the debate on the second reading, nobody is against fair competition. My goodness, if you ran out into the street and said, `I am against fair and free competition,' you would be run over. But this is not going to achieve that. I am afraid that if we persist with these amendments the bodies will have a nomenclature which would not reflect what they were doing and would represent the antithesis of what the commission would be attempting to achieve.
Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a question about the part of this Competition Policy Reform Bill that talks about compensation for acquisition of property. I remind the committee that there is a provision for the Commonwealth to pay compensation in certain respects if a determination results in an acquisition of property. If the determination would not be valid apart from this section because a particular person has not been sufficiently compensated, the Commonwealth must pay that person certain amounts.

PARA.TAB: I am asking what is estimated to be the contingent liability of the Commonwealth as a result of this particular clause? The structure of this bill really means that any owner of infrastructure is to be open to any would-be user. What happens if, for example, the commission came down with the decision that such a user could have access to infrastructure on terms which would not normally be regarded as just? Under this particular section we are acknowledging that that would be tantamount to acquisition of property and therefore the commission could determine the amount to be paid in compensation. I am asking the minister what are the contingent liabilities under this particular clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This particular clause is included because of a constitutional obligation on the Commonwealth that if properties are acquired there be compensation. This clause spells out the way in which that compensation would be provided. There is nothing in the financial impact statement attached to the memorandum to the bill which suggests that there is any provision for a contingent liability. We do not expect and do not foresee any contingent liability at all at this point. That is as well as I can answer the question.

—That raises the immediate question as to why the minister does not expect any liability. I ask this quite deliberately: do you consider that the user of infrastructure owned by another—whether it be a state government or a private enterprise—would have to pay commercial rates for access to that infrastructure? Is that what you are saying?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am saying is that this bill grandfathers all the existing arrangements. Any new arrangements that come into being are entered into in full knowledge of this bill. Therefore, we do not foresee any question of acquisition of property or the need for compensation. As I said, the provision is there as a proviso so that if some unforeseen event occurred there is a provision to cover it.

—But I am looking ahead. Consider the case where a state government privatises a particular road and there is a payment made by an entrepreneur for that road. What is envisaged under this legislation is that that infrastructure comes within the scope of this legislation and a particular user may demand access to that road. The private entrepreneur could say, `You will have to pay commercial rates'. Those rates will be determined on the basis of the usual guidelines that determine commercial rates. The user objects and says that he is denied use of the road and takes the matter to the Competition Commission. What will the Competition Commission do in those circumstances? The Competition Commission might say, `Yes, maybe the private owner of that road has a point'. The Competition Commission might agree that what the owner has said about commercial rates being applied for the use of that road are just rates. But those rates are impossible for the user. In other words, the user should have been able to expect to use that road without having to pay these commercial rates.

PARA.TAB: Under those circumstances, can the competition commission say that these roads normally would be subsidised roads; it is subsidised infrastructure; therefore, the user should not have to pay commercial rates? Under those circumstances, the infrastructure owner would have a claim against the commission. Under this provision there could be a claim on the Commonwealth or the state, whoever previously owned the road. Is this provision likely to mean that there will be substantial moneys awarded in respect of the acquisition of property, as I indicated, or is it envisaged that commercial rates will apply for access?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of elements to your question. The first one is that this bill does not in any way express a view about whether or not infrastructure should be privatised—whether it should be in public or private ownership. They are decisions for the relevant authority. If a state government makes that decision, that is its decision.

PARA.TAB: The question of ownership is a separate matter. There will also be an obligation for the state governments to consider what the community service obligation might be. If it were to privatise, how does it meet that type of criteria for the privatised item of infrastructure? Obviously, anyone who purchases it does so against a knowledge of the conditions of this bill. By doing so against the knowledge of the provisions of this bill, it seems to me that there is no claim of compensation for them if they believe that somehow or other, by their ownership, the property has been reduced in value.

Clause 44ZZJ(1) relates to compensation where property has been acquired. With great respect, it seems to me that your example related not to the Commonwealth or the state authority acquiring property but to a private holder of an infrastructure having imposed on him some community service obligation. My advice is that in those circumstances there is no claim for compensation against the Commonwealth.

I do need to speak to these amendments, so I will make a start. On amendment No. 2, I make the point that this is an amendment that the ACTU originally raised with the government. We have had a look at it because we think it makes a couple of important points. It seeks to broaden the exemptions on what constitutes government business.

PARA.TAB: I think this is important because anything which does not fall within this exemption will, by virtue of this bill, be expected to move to a competitive neutrality basis, and that means it will be open to competition. Competitive neutrality, the way it is defined, will, in our view, hamstring public sector organisations. As I said in the second reading debate, public sector organisations will be expected to assume the same full cost basis as the private sector, with the same rates of imputed taxation and the same imputed cost of finance and no advantage from any so-called anti-competitive regulations.

At the same time, public sector agencies will still be expected to be accountable for their decisions—politically, through the parliament; financially, through the Auditor-General; and, legally, through the administrative tribunals. As we have seen in this place, accountability comes at a significant cost, and this is a cost which the public sector has to meet in a democracy, but which the private sector largely does not have to meet, other than a limited accountability to shareholders for performance.

So competitive neutrality really does have the capacity to hamstring the public sector, and that is why I think it is important that we seek to ensure that the exempt activities cover as many of the vital core pieces of government where accountability is a vital and necessary component. This amendment seeks to exclude from activities which can be deemed to constitute a business service in education, health, welfare, community support and labour market assistance.

The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), in his second reading speech, sought to assure public sector unions and workers that competition policy would not mean wholesale dismantling of the public sector because, he said, competitive neutrality would only apply to significant business activities. What does that mean? What does `significant business activities' mean?

He went on to say that in sectors such as health and education competition would be limited to enterprises engaged in a business activity, which might be a small part of their overall role or ancillary to their core activities. Maybe the Assistant Treasurer is right. I do not think—and I think Senator Margetts has already alluded to this—in this brave new world we are launching into that we should underestimate the pressure that governments will come under to allow the private sector into a whole range of activities.

One private sector submission to the Industry Commission contracting out inquiry argues that the core business of government covers only policy formulation and analysis. Everything else, the submission argues, is ancillary and capable of being competitive and being contracted out.
Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee tabled its first report in relation to soccer. Contained therein was a dissenting report. Senator Carr spoke to it earlier today. I felt compelled to make some response to the comments made by Senator Carr at the time of the tabling of the report.

PARA.TAB: I understand that one of the fundamental rules of soccer is that you play the ball and not the opponent. Senator Carr's attack on the integrity of the committee is such that a red card should have been shown to him and he should have been sent off. Indeed, I have never seen or witnessed a person so offside on so many occasions as Senator Carr in relation to this report.

I defend the integrity of the committee on which I had the privilege to serve. Senator Coulter, as chairman of that committee, dealt with absolute proprietary, as I would suggest did the other members. The committee had its genesis in the allegations circulating within the media, which then led to the Australian Soccer Federation establishing the Stewart inquiry. Justice Stewart's so-called findings then became known as the Stewart report. That report was leaking everywhere. As a result, a lot of people became concerned that only elements of it were being leaked and allowed into the hands of the media, whereas other parts were not. There was concern within the soccer community as to whether or not the whole truth was being revealed or whether the public was being subjected to subjective leaks.

People's reputations had already been maligned prior to this committee embarking upon its inquiry. For Senator Carr to suggest that that is what the committee did—namely, malign people—is, to say the least, disingenuous and flies in the face of the facts.

It is also noteworthy—it is shown in the front of the report—that Senator Carr did not serve on this committee for the first four months of its operations and Senator Wheelwright, who joined in the dissenting report, was only a member of the committee for one month. So they cannot approach this topic with any degree of expertise or knowledge as to what the committee did throughout its duration. Indeed, the only Labor senator who was there for the duration was Senator Margaret Reynolds. I note that she has not made any comments. I am disappointed that she lent her name to the minority report because I believe it is out of character with her usual style of politics.

We in this chamber know that Senator Carr becomes vitriolic when cornered. His ferocious attack on the integrity of the committee has no real basis in logic. It may have been foundered on his concern at what we might discover. Senator Carr headed his minority report `In defence of civil liberties'. I am still waiting to hear from the left faction leader, Senator Carr, about his writings on the defence of civil liberties in the old communist bloc countries. There has been not a squeak out of him and it sounds very hollow that he should now try to start building a reputation on civil liberties.

I am astounded by Senator Carr's comments. Other members of the committee will confirm this—and I have to be careful that I do not divulge what happened in the private meetings of the committee: I can assure this Senate that I was one who absolutely ulcerated over whether or not the Stewart report ought be released under Senate privilege. Senator Ferguson nods his head in agreement confirming that. I can assure this Senate that I was very concerned about the implications for people and their civil liberties. That was at the forefront of my mind. However, I was persuaded on balance, given all the leaks that had occurred, that this needed a complete and open airing such as has been given by the Senate committee.

I cannot comment on what happened at the private meeting about whether or not the Stewart report ought be released, but let me simply say that I gave that matter a great degree of attention. My initial thought—when I was advised that I would have to consider it—was against releasing the report. But, on balance, I was persuaded to alter my state of mind in that particular area.
I move to two sections of the dissenting report to which I take quite considerable umbrage. I refer to paragraph 1.6, in which Senator Carr and his colleagues state:

SPEECH.PARA: During the course of the Committee's inquiry, the civil liberties of individuals were trampled on by a gross abuse of the processes of the Senate.

Senator Carr is very fortunate that he did not try to identify those that he alleges were responsible for this alleged trampling. I believe that a lot of people were allowed to put on record their genuine concerns about soccer in a situation where they did not have to fear the possibility of defamation proceedings. I realise that that has difficulties in that people can make unsubstantiated allegations and are clothed with privilege in doing so. But I believe that, in general terms, the committee and the witnesses that appeared before it were genuinely concerned about soccer and its future direction.

PARA.TAB: Paragraph 1.7 is grossly offensive. I should indicate to the Senate that we on the committee were not given the courtesy of being allowed to read the minority report prior to it going to the printers. Therefore, we were not aware of its contents. Paragraph 1.7 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition sought to sensationalise the inquiry in the media by encouraging witnesses to come forward and present unfounded allegations and malicious hearsay as evidence . . .

To make the assertion that any single one of my colleagues on that committee sought to try to get people to the committee hearings to present unfounded allegations and malicious hearsay is a reflection that defies any basis in logic. Indeed, it imputes a grossly improper motive on my colleagues and me, and indeed on Senator Coulter who chaired this committee.

PARA.TAB: To suggest that we were actively encouraging people to make unfounded allegations and to make malicious hearsay assertions just cannot be sustained in any shape or form. The only quote that is put into this report in support of that outrageous assertion and allegation is Senator Carr quoting himself. What a dynamic piece of evidence to support an argument! It was just self-serving nonsense about a drunk driver who allegedly knocked somebody over.

One would have to wonder about the state of sobriety of Senator Carr when he wrote such an outrageous allegation. I completely reject it. I know that my colleagues do. I do not think Senator Carr has served himself or, indeed, the committee process well by his outrageous activities in relation to the dissenting report on this soccer inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rarely rise to speak in the adjournment debate, but I felt compelled to do so this evening. I wish to speak on exactly the same matter as Senator Abetz. I commend him for the comments he made.

PARA.TAB: Today saw the tabling of the report Soccer: A first report. I think it is important that we realise this is a first report. Although it was not highlighted today, the reason it is the first report is that we determined we would put down a report prior to the finish of this session of parliament, purely in order to help the Australian Soccer Federation. The federation had some decisions it wanted to make and we promised it that we would have a report down by the end of this session of parliament although there were many matters that were still under consideration. Certainly, all those people who had been adversely commented on in evidence have not had a chance to reply. I anticipate that at some stage in the future the committee will be hearing from many of these people. What actions will need to be taken once that happens remains to be seen.

I did make some comments in the short time available this afternoon. It was a short time because of the restriction of time that now applies to the tabling of committee reports. Invariably that means that one government senator, one Democrat senator and one Liberal senator can speak, and that is it. I was courteously given some three or four minutes and I may repeat some things I said this afternoon, but I think it is absolutely important that what I have to say is recorded in Hansard tonight.

I start by dissociating myself completely from the comments by Senator Kim Carr this afternoon. I would describe him as, and he has proven to be, an inquiry wrecker. I believe that the minority report, which I gather was formulated by Senator Carr but signed by other government members on the inquiry, was an outrageous attack on a committee that has at all times tried to act with the utmost propriety. From the time Senator Carr became a member of the soccer inquiry, he has sought to do nothing but destroy the workings of the committee by taking sensational stands and seeking to publicise himself for political ends.

Senator Carr also appears to have defied the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, who stated that the government would cooperate with the inquiry and not stand in its way. This was said at the time the terms of reference were first put to the Senate, when matters had been aired, the Stewart inquiry report had been brought down and many people were very concerned about the state of soccer and the direction things were going. There were also hints of corruption in that sport. Senator Faulkner himself said that the government would cooperate with the inquiry and not stand in its way.

Senator Carr in his report has accused the committee of sensationalising the inquiry by encouraging witnesses to come forward to present unfounded allegations and hearsay as evidence. Nothing could be further from the truth. At every stage, the committee conducted itself with propriety and I resent the implications contained in Senator Carr's minority report. In fact, it is a matter of regret for the majority of the committee that potential witnesses, particularly soccer players who had previously provided information in many cases to the media, did not come before the committee to repeat those assertions.

If Senator Carr had bothered to regularly attend committee meetings and public hearings and to keep an open mind, he might have been able to contribute something to the benefit of soccer. But he did not even have the courtesy to attend the final meetings where we discussed the content of the committee's report.

Instead, Senator Carr assumed the role of the wrecker and did not make one contribution to the final report, which is in the best interests of the people we are trying to help—that is, the entire soccer community of Australia. My interest in this inquiry was to make sure that the thousands of Australians who play this sport could do so without fear or favour, under a sound administration and in the knowledge that there was no hint of corruption anywhere within the sport.

I must say that I am not totally convinced that there is no hint of corruption, but I hope that this report will help the federation in its efforts to make sure that soccer in Australia is in a far better state than it was prior to the inquiry by Justice Stewart. It is a great pity that Senator Carr was unable to put aside his desire to wreck the workings of the committee and make a positive contribution to the development of soccer in Australia.

Instead, all he has demonstrated is that he will do and say anything to try to discredit Senate inquiries, even those which his own minister has stated the government will cooperate with. It is obvious that Senator Carr does not have the slightest interest in the future of Australian soccer, and his minority report should be treated with the contempt that it deserves.

I note that the minority report he has written is entitled In defence of civil liberties. I wonder where on earth Senator Carr actually chose the title for his minority report. It would seem to me that by his actions he has done anything but defend the civil liberties of people involved. I am wondering whether it might not have been better called `Protect your mates', because I believe Senator Carr had no concern for soccer. His only concerns were politics, his political mates and people he knew were actually involved in the inquiry.

I am concerned that in the minority report there are a lot of quotes, most of which are Senator Carr's. If we take into account the number of days and hearings he attended and the number of times he actually spoke during those inquiries, the minority report probably has just about all the things he said during the inquiry in it. His only concern was to make sure that he stage managed a particular point of view that was well written up in the media so that the headlines could read `Victorian senator slams Senate committee', or words to that effect. I do not know if that is the exact headline, but it is very similar.

In the minority report there is actually a quote from Senator Wheelwright—and I do not want to criticise Senator Wheelwright. He attended only the last day of our inquiry. But Senator Carr chose to use a comment that Senator Wheelwright made at that meeting when he had very little to say. I do not think it is fair to criticise Senator Wheelwright, because he became a member of that committee only at a very late stage.

Senator Reynolds attended very few meetings—only two or three and then only for a short time. In the minority report we also find quotes from Mr David Hill—a very late appointment as Chairman of the Soccer Federation. I should say that the Soccer Federation itself welcomed the Senate inquiry, which enabled many people to clear their names from any innuendoes that may have been brought about by the publication of the Stewart report.

We want to remember one thing. We want to remember that the Stewart report, which was the basis of this inquiry being called, was commissioned by the Australian Soccer Federation. The Senate had nothing to do with the Stewart report. The Senate certainly suggested in June 1994 that it did not believe that all was well in soccer and that an inquiry might be necessary, but it was felt that the Soccer Federation should first have the option itself of trying to do something for its own sport—and that was done.

When the Stewart report was brought down we all know what happened. Some people leaked some of the contents of the Stewart report before the Soccer Federation had published it. The Senate then believed that, as a result of that, people needed an opportunity to clear their names. I believe we have done that. I think Senator Carr's unwarranted attack on the attitudes of the committee and its report does not do him any credit.

I also want to comment on the fact that Senator Carr put in a minority report. I do not want to comment on the fact that he did; he is quite at liberty to put in a minority report. But I believe that there ought to be some courtesies observed in this place. When a minority report is written, having the full facts available in a majority report—where all the amendments are shown—I think it is only a common courtesy that a minority report should be shown to members of the committee prior to that report going to print. It is certainly a matter that I will be asking the Privileges Committee to take up.

Let me say that I think that signifies just how Senator Carr felt about his report. He did not want anybody else to see what he was saying before it went to the printer. The first thing we knew about the contents of that report was when we received it some time after 4.00 p.m. today, which I think is disgraceful. I thought it was only right that I should put those feelings on the record. I thank you, Madam Deputy President, for your indulgence. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to take a point of order during Senator Ferguson's speech, but I decided to leave it and make a very brief comment. It is not without precedence that minority reports are added at the last moment to a committee majority report. I think if you get a piece of manly behaviour of that sort—
—Is this a speech or a point of order?
—The minister has the call to speak on the adjournment.
—She said it was a point of order.

—I am very making a brief comment. The point that minority reports are not always given to the majority of the committee is not without precedent. Senator Ferguson's comments could well be used against him in many other committees. As a matter of fact, I agree strongly with the business of the manly behaviour of at least advising the committee. I need to say that I do not know the full account of this or of any of the timing. I believe it is entirely appropriate for Senator Carr to come into this place and refute Senator Ferguson's claims.

PARA.TAB: The concern that I had was that the claims by Senator Ferguson implied an imputed motive by Senator Carr. It is perfectly reasonable to disagree, argue the points and so on. But in this place, it is unparliamentary, disorderly and against the standing orders to impute motive to another senator. If Senator Ferguson wants to bag him, that is perfectly legitimate. But to ascribe to Senator Carr what he understood to be his motive, intention or the state of his mind is drawing a long bow, particularly with regard to the standing orders of this place—although they are often stretched very long.

For the record, I would simply suggest that some of Senator Ferguson's comments went beyond what I would call reasonable debate. No doubt Senator Carr will stand up in this place at some stage and make a reply on his own behalf. I simply think this was a point worth making, particularly as the standing orders are very clear about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to again draw the attention of the Senate to a race discrimination complaint lodged with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission by Canberra public servant John Bell against his then employer, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, on 4 March 1990.

PARA.TAB: This case received notoriety almost five years later in February 1995 when the full bench of the High Court upheld a constitutional challenge by one of the guilty parties, Mr Harry Brandy, against the powers of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to enforce the federal government's racial discrimination legislation. There is no doubt that this emasculation of the authority of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission can be attributed significantly to the efforts of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

Following Mr Brandy's attacks on Mr Bell in the workplace on 16 February 1990, Mr John Bell approached the then chief executive officer of ATSIC, Bill Gray, with a request for a handshake apology from Mr Brandy. When Mr Gray refused the request, Mr Bell was obliged to lodge a formal complaint against ATSIC with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

In the next 2 1/2 years, Mr Bell and HREOC made attempts to resolve the matter with ATSIC, but to no avail. A formal inquiry into the complaint was conducted under Mr Ron Castan QC in August 1992. Mr Castan had been legal counsel representing Eddie Mabo in the High Court Mabo land rights case; therefore, one would think that his credentials at this inquiry would stand detailed scrutiny.

At this inquiry, Mr Bell presented his own case without legal assistance because of the costs involved. Although Mr Bell won the case on 2 October 1992, ATSIC successfully had it reopened, causing Mr Bell to incur substantial legal costs. Several reconciliation meetings convened by HREOC followed, at which Commissioner Castan indicated there was a prime facie case against ATSIC. These matters drew little support as ATSIC refused to accept Mr Castan's advice. Subsequent to these hearings, Mr Castan brought down findings unfavourable to ATSIC on 2 October 1992, finding ATSIC guilty of breaching the Racial Discrimination Act.

The chief executive of ATSIC Mr Peter Shergold was successful in having the matter reopened, despite the fact that ATSIC had been given every opportunity to resolve this racial matter before it went to a formal hearing. By 22 December 1993, nearly four years after Mr John Bell lodged his original complaint with HREOC, Ron Castan QC found that an Aboriginal officer of ATSIC, Harry Brandy, had on at least one occasion attacked Mr Bell in a racist and offensive manner in the ATSIC workplace. In a 60-page document, Mr Castan was critical of ATSIC management practices and the sworn evidence of several ATSIC senior managers, including the chief executive officer, a general division manager, branch heads and a number of section directors.

It is history that Mr Harry Brandy, in a case funded by ATSIC through the Aboriginal Legal Service, was able to destroy the federal government's discrimination legislation. I have grave concerns that Mr Brandy's High Court action would not have occurred if Mr Gray from ATSIC had taken appropriate disciplinary action in February 1990.

Further, I take the opportunity to bring to the attention of the Senate that the innocent victim of this matter, Mr Bell, has suffered considerably during the last 5 1/2 years. During this period Mr Bell has been subject to extreme harassment and victimisation by elements within ATSIC, with the result that on 13 June he was forced to leave ATSIC and the Public Service after a 27-year career working with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Mr Bell, a victim, has received no support from ATSIC, nor from the Public Service Commission through the Public Service Merit Protection and Review Agency. The actions by the Merit Protection and Review Agency in the Bell matter demonstrate that it is clearly unable to service the needs of its clients.

ATSIC, throughout this case, made several unsuccessful attempts to discredit Mr Bell as being an individual of unsound mind. On each occasion these allegations could not be substantiated. Mr Bell, the complainant, was forbidden to enter ATSIC premises and to contact ATSIC staff. He was eventually arrested and placed in gaol at the instigation of ATSIC. Mr Bell made numerous attempts to resolve this matter, including a personal approach to the chief executive officer of ATSIC Ms Patricia Turner. At the end of the day ATSIC indicated that it would negotiate with Mr Bell only on the basis that he accept a redundancy package. I have advice that the chief executive officer of ATSIC Pat Turner advised the Racial Discrimination Commissioner that there was an element in ATSIC totally out to destroy Mr Bell.

We now must acknowledge that Mr Bell, the victim of racist allegations, has suffered ill health and has been financially destroyed by legal costs and litigation as a result of ATSIC failing to support his genuine concerns. His 27 years in the Public Service and in the Aboriginal community have been destroyed. At the end of the day, under considerable duress Mr Bell was forced to sign an agreement with ATSIC which terminated his services. Mr Bell's treatment in this whole affair as the victim raises serious questions concerning current workplace management practices in ATSIC and the Public Service. I think we also need to ask why neither Harry Brandy nor any ATSIC senior manager has ever been disciplined for proven breaches of the Public Service Act and the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.

We must acknowledge that at a farewell luncheon recently organised on behalf of Mr Bell by rank and file ATSIC staff, many of whom were Aboriginals, his service and dedication to the Aboriginal community were widely acknowledged. Tributes were received from eminent Aboriginal sporting identities, administrators, academics and the author Professor Colin Tatz.

I believe that as a Senate there should be an obligation upon us to re-examine the circumstances which have befallen Mr Bell as a result of the claims which he made and which were legitimately proven to be correct. No individual who comes forward in honesty to report a matter of racial discrimination should suffer loss. The actions of ATSIC to date provide little comfort, and Mr Bell has received no justice whatsoever.
