TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—During my speech on the adjournment I mentioned referring a matter concerning minority reports to the Privileges Committee. I meant to say the Procedures Committee. I would like it recorded that I would not want to send that sort of thing to the Privileges Committee; I did mean the Procedures Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend speaking on the adjournment tonight but, in passing the chamber, I heard Senator Ferguson railing against the behaviour of Senator Carr in the soccer inquiry. Senator Ferguson tonight dissociated himself completely from the comments of Labor senator Kim Carr, whom he described as an inquiry wrecker. I found that fascinating because I have served on a number of Senate committees with Kim Carr. Before I served with him I knew of him by reputation on the print media inquiry where he fulfilled a similar wrecking role.
—He thinks he is in a Labor Party meeting.

—I think you are right, Senator. He thinks he is in Tammany Hall in Victoria. He should realise that the Senate is a very different place. My first involvement directly with him in committee work was on the ABC select committee. I thought it was a great pity that when we really had an opportunity as a total committee to reshape the direction of the ABC Senator Carr took a wrecking role on this committee, not only in relation to the final report but also in terms of procedures involved as the committee went about its work.

PARA.TAB: At one point, he made allegations against Senator Alston in terms of improperly influencing a witness. When this was disproved, he persisted. The witness came before the committee and was asked whether he spoke to Senator Alston before the inquiry. He said he had never, in his life, spoken to Senator Alston. Quite incredibly, Senator Carr persisted. The Hansard record will show that I interjected, `Quit while you are behind, Senator Carr,' but he persisted. The matter, between two senators, ended up in court. That is extremely unfortunate.

I am currently involved with Senator Carr in other inquiries, particularly the long-term unemployment inquiry. This is an inquiry which Senator Carr fought tooth and nail to stop getting to the Senate as a reference. Also, in the processes of the committee he has done all he can to disrupt the committee's work, to the extent of trying to shut down hearings one day before they occurred.

In Tweed Heads, suddenly the Labor members of the committee were not available the next day in Campbelltown. With the assistance of the officers of the Senate, we found a way around the problem and the hearing did go ahead without the Labor members. A similar thing was tried in Broadmeadows in Melbourne. The hearing the next day was to be in Ballarat and, again, under Senator Carr's leadership, the Labor people tried to pull the plug. Again, we found a way around this, through proper forms of the Senate. Senator Carr did not turn up in Ballarat—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he know where it is?

—You would wonder; he is the duty senator there. The local member, Michael Ronaldson, came along and he pointed out that the duty senator was not present even though he was a member of the committee. He asked whether Senator Carr did not feel that as a member of the committee and as the duty senator he should be there to listen to the problems of the long-term unemployed in Ballarat. Senator Carr was suitably enraged.
—He accused you of playing politics.

—He did accuse me of playing politics. What happened in that committee is a very far cry from the days several years ago when Senator Terry Aulich of the Labor Party was the chair, I was deputy chair from the Liberal Party and Senator Karen Sowada was the Democrat, and we worked in a very cooperative relationship.
—Achieved things.
—We did achieve things. Senator Aulich, to his great credit, was not backward at having a go at the Labor Party.
—He was dropped from the ticket.

—He was then dropped from the ticket because he had the temerity to produce reports like the one on new directions in higher education, which absolutely outraged Minister Dawkins because it was an honest, up-front critique of government policy.
—Dawkins attacked the committee structure after that.

—Because that committee was so effective, he attacked the committee at that point and the whole committee structure. What we have is a longstanding record of someone who has been here for a short time and is creating problems in this committee. It is really a great pity.

PARA.TAB: We often have an opportunity to produce reports that are critical of the Australian government. Senator Carr came up with an approach where he was going to be critical of the Victorian government. When Labor had the majority on the committee, before the committee structure was changed, we had a situation where Senator Carr was quite prepared to set up an inquiry into Commonwealth-state relations with the intent of bagging the Kennett government and the Western Australian government in particular on their accountability for spending federal money. Unfortunately for him, that backfired. It showed, largely, that Commonwealth mechanisms are greatly deficient in accounting for the expenditure of public money. I felt it was an interesting irony that that is the way the report turned out.

Despite this disruption that has occurred over the last few months, we have managed to come up with a report that is almost unanimous on that inquiry. There were a few dissenting points from the Labor members of the committee on the Austudy report, which we have now completed and which will be tabled tomorrow. That was a unanimous report which we struggled through. One waits to see what will happen with long-term unemployment, because that revealed a great shortcoming in government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another speech from Senator Carr tomorrow.

—We might get another speech from Senator Carr on that issue. As I mentioned before, it is a pity that Labor members of the committee, particularly Senator Carr, are not really prepared to come out and—
—Be parliamentarians.

—Be parliamentarians, and to be critical of government policy where criticism is needed. It has fulfilled a longstanding pattern where Senator Carr has been extremely disruptive in a number of committees. We have yet again today from Senator Ferguson the example of how that has happened with the Senate soccer inquiry. We have had the previous example with the ABC committee. That particular final report was most outrageous because Senator Carr was not even prepared to look at the majority report. He prepared his own 90-page report, but the ABC officials have said that they will implement our report—that is, the majority report of the coalition. Those changes are taking place at this time.

PARA.TAB: I think it is unfortunate that, across a range of committees, we have a maverick senator who is creating great disruption to the committee process. It is a process which really brings government to account. It puts government well and truly under the spotlight. I think in the 25-year history of committees in this parliament it has made an enormous contribution to democracy in this country. It is a pity that one senator, as evidenced across a very wide range of committees, has chosen to

SPEECH.PARA: act in this way to bring the committee process into disrepute and to reduce the amount of cooperation that we have seen across all parties. That work has been diminished because of those actions. I commend what Senator Ferguson has had to say tonight on this matter because it fulfils a total pattern. (Time expired).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senate adjourned at 11.40 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 13 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Tarremah School at Kingston in Tasmania:
(1) What is the current categorisation of the school under Commonwealth guidelines for funding.
(2) What are the grounds for the school being placed in the category.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the school's current funding is based on an incorrect assessment by the Department of Employment and Training (DEET) that the school paid over award salaries to teachers, when in fact the amount given by the school for its total salaries included specialist teachers working less than half a day per week who, according to the guidelines, did not have to be listed.
(4) Why have no officers from DEET actually visited the school site and made a physical inspection of its premises.
(5) Will an undertaking be given that officers from DEET will visit the school to review the funding categorisation which has been based on incorrect information.
(6) Is the Educational Resource Index the only measure used by the Commonwealth to determine funding levels for non-government schools.
(7) Are there other funding criteria available to the Minister in reviewing funding for the school.

(8) Does the Minister agree that it is incongruous for Tarremah School, which operates on limited resources and depends heavily on parental helpers, to be considered in the same category as other Category 3 schools such as Launceston Grammar, Hutchins School and Fahan School, while other schools similar to Tarremah are Category 9 or 10.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Tarremah School is in funding category 3.

(2) The original assessment of the school for funding at the category 3 level was based on financial data provided by the school's proponents in support of their application for Commonwealth funding and on a financial viability assessment, as required by the legislation then in effect, prepared for the Commonwealth by an independent firm of accountants from these data.

(3) The assessment of the school's funding category was carried out in accordance with the procedures applying for all commencing non-government schools. Part-time specialist support staff are included in this assessment.

(4) Site visits are not made when assessing a school's funding level. The funding level of non-government schools is based on projected operational data provided by the proponents in the case of new schools and on actual operating data for continuing schools.

(5) The Commonwealth has established the Non-government Schools Funding Review Committee as an independent body to assess and recommend to the Minister on applications for reviews of funding category. The school is able to apply to this Committee for a review at any time. DEET officers do not undertake reviews or visit schools to assess or review funding categories.
(6) The Education Resources Index is the principal indicator of need when assessing funding categories. Whether the school has maintained its

ANSWER.PARA: level of private recurrent expenditure and improved its private income are also taken into account.

PARA.TAB: (7) The only grounds for review are that a school has experienced a significant change in need for financial assistance.

(8) The school was assessed for funding in the same way as other commencing non-government schools. It has had the opportunity to have its funding category reviewed. Comparisons with other schools are not part of the assessment or review process.
